After testing and rejecting numerous weapons, he claimed the Ruyi Jingu Bang - a magical iron pillar that had been used to measure the depths of the Heavenly River. He also demanded and received a suit of golden chain mail, cloud-walking boots, and a phoenix-feather cap from the terrified Dragon Kings.

myths.title: The White Dragon Horse
myths.content: In Journey to the West, the third son of the Dragon King of the West Sea was condemned to death for burning the palace's pearl. Guanyin intervened and transformed him into a white horse to carry the monk Xuanzang on his journey to India, thus achieving redemption through service.

myths.title: The Origin of Rain
myths.content: The Dragon Kings are responsible for delivering rain according to the Jade Emperor's decrees. Each region of China has a designated dragon who must release the proper amount of rainfall. Stories abound of dragons who delivered too much or too little rain and faced celestial punishment.

myths.title: The Dragon Gate
myths.content: According to legend, carp that successfully leap over the Dragon Gate (é¾™é—¨) at the Yellow River are transformed into dragons. This myth symbolizes success through perseverance, particularly in the imperial examination system.

myths.title: Prayers for Rain
myths.content: Throughout Chinese history, during droughts, emperors and commoners alike would pray to the Dragon Kings for rain. Elaborate rituals were performed at Dragon King temples, sometimes including the dramatic display of dragon bones (often dinosaur fossils) to entreat the dragons' assistance.

family.Ao Bing (æ•–ä¸™): Third son of Ao Guang, slain by Nezha
family.Dragon Princesses: Feature in various romantic legends with mortals
family.Ao Lie: Another prince mentioned in various tales

worship.sacredSites: Dragon King temples (é¾™çŽ‹åº™) are found throughout China, particularly near bodies of water:
festivals: Dragon Boat Festival (ç«¯åˆèŠ‚): Fifth day of the fifth lunar month - dragon boat races honor the Dragon Kings and the poet Qu Yuan
Dragon Raising Head Day (é¾™æŠ¬å¤´): Second day of the second lunar month - marks when dragons awaken from winter sleep and begin bringing spring rains
Rain Prayer Ceremonies: Performed during droughts with elaborate rituals
worship.offerings: The Dragon Kings are especially important to:

myths.title: Divine Birth and Family Tragedy
myths.content: Erlang Shen (Yang Jian) was born from the union of a mortal man, Yang Tianyou, and the Jade Emperor's sister, the goddess Yaoji. This forbidden marriage enraged the Jade Emperor, who imprisoned Yaoji beneath Mount Tao. Young Erlang Shen eventually grew powerful enough to cleave the mountain with his axe and free his mother, only to witness her die from the Jade Emperor's punishment.

myths.title: Splitting the Mountain
myths.content: The tale of Erlang Shen splitting Mount Tao to save his mother (or in some versions, Mount Hua) became one of the most beloved stories in Chinese folklore, symbolizing filial devotion and the willingness to defy heaven itself for family. This story inspired later tales of similar heroic rescues.

myths.title: Taming the Floods
myths.content: In some traditions, Erlang Shen is credited with controlling devastating floods by channeling rivers and defeating water demons. He is associated with the ancient flood-control hero Li Bing of Sichuan and worshipped at Guankou (Dujiangyan), where he is believed to protect against flooding.

myths.title: Battle with Sun Wukong
myths.content: In Journey to the West, when all other celestial warriors failed to capture the rebellious Monkey King, Erlang Shen was dispatched. The two engaged in an epic battle of transformations - Sun Wukong transformed into a sparrow, Erlang became a hawk; the monkey became a fish, the god became a cormorant. Erlang Shen's third eye could see through each disguise, making him the only warrior who could match Sun Wukong in combat.

myths.title: The War Against the Shang
myths.content: In the Fengshen Yanyi, Yang Jian serves as one of the greatest generals in the campaign to overthrow the tyrannical King Zhou. He battles numerous powerful demons and sorcerers, using his transformations and combat skills to turn the tide of many battles.

myths.title: Conflict with the Jade Emperor
myths.content: Despite being the Jade Emperor's nephew, Erlang Shen maintains a complicated relationship with heaven. He often acts independently, is said to "listen to the celestial decrees but not the celestial summons" (å¬è°ƒä¸å¬å®£), and dwells at Guankou rather than in the celestial court. This independence reflects his resentment over his mother's fate.

family.Mother: Yaoji (ç‘¶å§¬), the Jade Emperor's sister, imprisoned and killed for marrying a mortal
family.Uncle: Jade Emperor (çŽ‰çš‡å¤§å¸), with whom he has a strained relationship
family.Sister: Yang Chan (æ¨å©µ), who in some stories also has divine children
family.Nephew: Chenxiang (æ²‰é¦™), who similarly split a mountain to save his mother (in later legends)

worship.sacredSites: Erlang Shen's worship is particularly strong in Sichuan province:
festivals: Erlang Shen's Birthday (äºŒéƒŽç¥žè¯ž): Celebrated on the 6th day of the 6th lunar month with temple fairs, opera performances, and offerings
Qingming Festival: Special rites at Dujiangyan honoring both Erlang Shen and Li Bing for flood control
worship.offerings: Erlang Shen is particularly invoked by:

name: Guan Yu
subtitle: é—œç¾½ (GuÄn YÇ”) - God of War, Righteousness, and Loyalty
description: Guan Yu is one of China's most revered deities, a historical general from the Three Kingdoms period (220-280 CE) who was deified for his unwavering loyalty, righteousness, and martial prowess. Worshipped by warriors, police, merchants, and gangsters alike, he represents the ideal of honorable conduct and brotherhoodâ€”a mortal who earned godhood through exemplary virtue.

attributes.Titles: Lord Guan (é—œå…¬), Emperor Guan (é—œå¸), Martial God of Wealth, Saint of War
attributes.Domains: War, righteousness, loyalty, brotherhood, justice, commerce, protection
attributes.Symbols: Green Dragon Crescent Blade (guandao), red face, long beard, Confucian texts
attributes.Colors: Red (righteousness, courage), green (his dragon blade), imperial yellow

myths.title: Peach Garden Oath (æ¡ƒåœ’çµç¾©)
myths.content: Guan Yu, Liu Bei, and Zhang Fei swore brotherhood under blooming peach trees, vowing: "Though born on different days, we wish to die on the same day." This oath became the model for loyalty and sworn brotherhood (ç¾©æ°£) throughout Chinese culture. The three declared: "We do not seek to be born on the same day, but we do hope to die on the same day."

myths.title: Slaying Hua Xiong
myths.content: When the allied forces cowered before the mighty general Hua Xiong, Guan Yu volunteered to fight. Cao Cao offered him warm wine before battle. Guan Yu returned so quickly that the wine was still warm, carrying Hua Xiong's severed head. This demonstrated his superhuman martial prowess.

myths.title: Riding Alone for a Thousand Li (åƒé‡Œèµ°å–®é¨Ž)
myths.content: When separated from Liu Bei, Guan Yu was temporarily under Cao Cao's service. Upon learning his brother's location, he traveled 1,000 li (500 km) through enemy territory, cutting down five generals and passing through six military outposts, to rejoin Liu Bei. This journey exemplifies absolute loyaltyâ€”he refused Cao Cao's generous gifts and high position to return to his sworn brother.

myths.title: Scraping Poison from Bone (åˆ®éª¨ç™‚æ¯’)
myths.content: After being shot with a poisoned arrow, physicians said they must scrape the poison from his boneâ€”excruciatingly painful. Guan Yu sat calmly playing Go (Chinese chess) without anesthesia, continuing his game without a tremor while the doctor operated. This story exemplifies his legendary composure and endurance.

myths.title: Death and Apotheosis
myths.content: After his execution, Guan Yu's spirit appeared to a Buddhist monk, seeking enlightenment. Recognizing his virtue, the monk helped him achieve divine status. Guan Yu's ghost then appeared to the Jade Emperor, who appointed him Guardian of Buddhist and Taoist temples and protector of righteousness.

myths.title: The Green Dragon Blade
myths.content: His legendary weapon, the Green Dragon Crescent Blade (é’é¾åƒæœˆåˆ€), weighed 82 jin (about 40 kg/88 lbs). Legend says it was forged with the soul of a dragon, making it supernaturally sharp and able to extend to strike distant enemies.

festivals: Guan Yu's Birthday: 13th day of the 5th lunar month (historically 24th day of the 6th month). Celebrated with operas, martial arts demonstrations, and processions. Businesses close for ceremonial worship.
Death Anniversary: Commemorated in the 12th lunar month. Devotees reflect on loyalty unto death and honor Guan Yu's ultimate sacrifice.
worship.offerings: Offerings to Guan Yu reflect his dual nature as warrior and scholar:

sources: Romance of the Three Kingdoms (ä¸‰åœ‹æ¼”ç¾©) by Luo Guanzhong, Records of the Three Kingdoms (ä¸‰åœ‹å¿—) by Chen Shou, Classical Chinese texts, Extensive folklore and temple traditions

name: Guanyin
subtitle: è§‚éŸ³ / è¦³éŸ³ (GuÄn YÄ«n) - Goddess of Compassion and Mercy
description: Guanyin, also known as Kuan Yin or Avalokiteshvara, is the East Asian Bodhisattva of compassion and mercy. Originally a male deity in Indian Buddhism, Guanyin transformed into a beloved feminine figure in Chinese religious culture, embodying the ideal of infinite compassion who hears the cries of all suffering beings.

myths.title: Ascension to Supreme Rule
myths.content: After 1,750 eons of cultivation (each eon lasting 129,600 years), the mortal prince who would become the Jade Emperor achieved perfect virtue. When the previous supreme god retired, all deities unanimously elected him as the new ruler. His authority derives not from force but from unparalleled moral perfection.

myths.title: The Zodiac Race
myths.content: To establish the calendar, the Jade Emperor decreed a race across a great river. The first twelve animals to reach his palace would become the zodiac signs. Through cunning and determination, the Rat won first place (riding on the Ox), followed by Ox, Tiger, Rabbit, Dragon, Snake, Horse, Goat, Monkey, Rooster, Dog, and Pig. This explains the order of the Chinese zodiac.

myths.title: Journey to the West Encounters
myths.content: In the epic Journey to the West, Sun Wukong (Monkey King) causes chaos in heaven, eating the Peaches of Immortality and disrupting the celestial order. The Jade Emperor ultimately must seek Buddha's help to subdue the rebellious monkey. This story illustrates the Jade Emperor's role as administrator rather than warriorâ€”he delegates tasks to specialists, embodying wise rulership.

myths.title: The Celestial Inspection
myths.content: Each New Year, the Kitchen God (Zao Jun) reports to the Jade Emperor on every household's behavior. Based on these reports, the Jade Emperor adjusts each family's fortune for the coming year. This reflects the belief that divine justice is precise, personalized, and annually reviewed.

family.Parents: Various traditions; some say he was the son of a king, others that he emerged from primordial qi
family.Consort(s): Traditionally paired with Queen Mother of the West (è¥¿çŽ‹æ¯), though their relationship is complexâ€”she often functions independently
family.Children: Seven daughters (the Seven Fairies, ä¸ƒä»™å¥³), including the one who fell in love with a mortal cowherd in the famous Qixi legend
family.Siblings: Not emphasized in traditional mythology; his authority comes from merit, not lineage

festivals: Jade Emperor's Birthday (å¤©å…¬ç”Ÿ): Ninth day of the first lunar month. Celebrated with offerings, firecrackers, and theatrical performances. This is one of the most important dates in the Chinese religious calendar, even surpassing Chinese New Year in some communities. Devotees stay awake all night to welcome the deity's birthday at dawn.

Chinese New Year: The Kitchen God returns to report to the Jade Emperor on the 23rd/24th day of the 12th lunar month. Families offer sweet foods to the Kitchen God so he'll give a favorable report, then welcome him back on New Year's Eve.
worship.offerings: Offerings to the Jade Emperor must be pure and respectful, reflecting his supreme status:

myths.title: Miraculous Birth
myths.content: Nezha was born to Lady Yin after three years and six months of pregnancy. He emerged as a ball of flesh, which his father Li Jing (later the Pagoda-Bearing Heavenly King) struck with his sword. From the flesh emerged a fully-formed child wearing the Universe Ring and Red Armillary Sash, gifts from his immortal teacher Taiyi Zhenren.

myths.title: Slaying of Ao Bing
myths.content: While bathing in the sea, young Nezha's magical sash stirred the Dragon King's underwater palace. When the Dragon King sent his third son Ao Bing to investigate, Nezha killed him in the ensuing confrontation. This act triggered divine retribution from the Dragon Kings of the Four Seas, who demanded justice from the Jade Emperor.

myths.title: Filial Sacrifice
myths.content: To protect his parents from the Dragon Kings' wrath, Nezha committed suicide by cutting out his own flesh and returning it to his mother and his bones to his father. This extreme act of filial piety released his parents from responsibility for his deeds, but left his spirit wandering without a body.

myths.title: Lotus Rebirth
myths.content: His teacher Taiyi Zhenren reconstructed Nezha's body from lotus roots, lotus leaves, and lotus flowers, giving him immortal form and even greater powers. Reborn as the Lotus Prince, Nezha sought revenge against his father Li Jing for destroying his temple, but was ultimately reconciled through Buddha's intervention.

myths.title: War Against the Shang
myths.content: In the Fengshen Yanyi, Nezha serves as a general in King Wu's army against the tyrannical King Zhou of Shang. He battles numerous demons and enemy generals, contributing to the establishment of the Zhou Dynasty and the investiture of the gods.

myths.title: Journey to the West
myths.content: Nezha attempts to capture Sun Wukong on behalf of the Jade Emperor. Despite his formidable powers, he is defeated by the Monkey King, demonstrating both his warrior prowess and the exceptional nature of Sun Wukong's abilities.

family.Father: Li Jing (æŽé–), the Pagoda-Bearing Heavenly King, with whom Nezha had a complex and troubled relationship
family.Mother: Lady Yin (æ®·å¤«äºº), who carried him for three years and six months
family.Brothers: Jinzha (é‡‘å’) and Muzha (æœ¨å’), both also celestial warriors
family.Master: Taiyi Zhenren (å¤ªä¹™çœŸäºº), the immortal who gave him his weapons and later his lotus body

worship.sacredSites: Nezha is widely worshipped throughout China, Taiwan, and Southeast Asian Chinese communities:
festivals: Nezha's Birthday (å“ªå’è¯ž): Celebrated on the 9th day of the 9th lunar month (some regions observe different dates). Features lion dances, opera performances, and spirit medium rituals.
Ghost Month Ceremonies: Nezha is invoked to protect against malevolent spirits during the seventh lunar month.
worship.offerings: Nezha is particularly popular among:

myths.title: Ancient Origins
myths.content: In the earliest texts (Shanhaijing/Classic of Mountains and Seas), Xi Wangmu appears as a fearsome goddess with a human face, leopard's tail, and tiger's teeth. She dwells in a cave on Jade Mountain, controlling plague, punishment, and the five calamities. Her three blue birds bring her food.

myths.title: Meeting King Mu of Zhou
myths.content: One of the most famous tales describes Emperor Mu of Zhou (c. 10th century BCE) who journeyed west in his chariot drawn by eight magical horses. He reached Mount Kunlun and was received by Xi Wangmu. They exchanged poems and gifts, and she hosted a banquet by the Jade Pool. When they parted, both expressed sorrow, and the king promised to return - but never did.

myths.title: Chang'e and the Moon
myths.content: Xi Wangmu gave the elixir of immortality to the hero Houyi as a reward for shooting down nine of the ten suns. His wife Chang'e drank the elixir and floated to the moon, where she still dwells. This story connects Xi Wangmu to the Mid-Autumn Festival.

myths.title: Journey to the West
myths.content: In the novel, Xi Wangmu's Peach Banquet is disrupted when Sun Wukong, appointed guardian of the orchard, eats all the ripened peaches, drinks the immortal wine, and consumes Laozi's pills of immortality. This triple offense contributed to the Monkey King's rebellion against heaven.

myths.title: The Weaver Girl (Zhinu)
myths.content: In some versions of the famous Cowherd and Weaver Girl legend, Xi Wangmu is the grandmother or mother of Zhinu (the Weaver). She separated the lovers by creating the Milky Way with her jade hairpin, allowing them to meet only once per year on the seventh day of the seventh month.

myths.title: Han Dynasty Worship
myths.content: During the Han dynasty, a messianic cult of Xi Wangmu swept across China, with people believing she would soon descend to grant immortality to her faithful. Worshippers wore special talismans and performed ecstatic rituals in her honor.

worship.sacredSites: Xi Wangmu worship remains active throughout the Chinese world:
festivals: Xi Wangmu's Birthday (çŽ‹æ¯å¨˜å¨˜åœ£è¯ž): Third day of the third lunar month - celebrated with peach-shaped offerings and elaborate rituals
Double Seven Festival (ä¸ƒå¤•): Connected to her through the Weaver Girl story
Mid-Autumn Festival: Chang'e's story links this festival to Xi Wangmu's elixir
worship.offerings: Xi Wangmu is particularly honored by:

myths.title: The Tale of Zhang Lang
myths.content: The most popular origin story tells of Zhang Lang, a mortal man who abandoned his faithful wife Guo Dingxiang to marry a younger woman. His new wife was cruel and wasteful, and eventually left him. Zhang Lang became a beggar, wandering until he arrived by chance at the door of his former wife, who had remarried and prospered. She recognized him and kindly gave him food. Overcome with shame, Zhang Lang threw himself into her kitchen fire. The Jade Emperor, moved by this act of remorse, appointed him Kitchen God - condemned forever to watch over the domestic realm he had once betrayed.

myths.title: Alternative Origin - The Loyal Servant
myths.content: Another tradition holds that Zao Jun was originally a devoted servant who protected his master's household at the cost of his own life. The Jade Emperor rewarded his loyalty by making him protector of all households.

myths.title: The Jade Emperor's Spy
myths.content: Some tales describe Zao Jun as a spirit specifically created by the Jade Emperor to monitor mortal behavior. He was placed in the kitchen because it is the heart of the home, where family members gather and true natures are revealed.

myths.title: Zao Jun and His Wife
myths.content: Zao Jun is often depicted with his wife, Zao Jun Nainai (ç¶å›å¥¶å¥¶), who assists in observing the household. In some traditions, she softens his reports, interceding for families who show genuine effort despite their mistakes.

myths.title: The Sweet Bribe
myths.content: A famous story explains why sweet foods are offered to Zao Jun before his journey to heaven. One family, anxious about their misbehavior throughout the year, smeared honey on Zao Jun's lips so he would only speak sweet words to the Jade Emperor - or so his lips would stick together and he could not report at all! This custom became universal.

family.Zao Jun Nainai (ç¶å›å¥¶å¥¶): His wife, often depicted alongside him
family.Guo Dingxiang: His first wife in the Zhang Lang origin story
family.Household Members: Every family becomes his temporary "family" to watch over

name: Gabriel
subtitle: Divine Messenger, Herald of God
description: God's primary messenger, entrusted with delivering the most important divine revelations in salvation history. His name means "God is my strength," reflecting his role as the bearer of God's powerful word. Gabriel appears at pivotal moments to announce God's plans, particularly those concerning the coming of the Messiah.

attributes.Name Meaning: "God is my strength" or "Mighty one of God" (Hebrew: ×’Ö·Ö¼×‘Ö°×¨Ö´×™×Öµ×œ)
attributes.Role: Chief messenger of God, Herald of divine revelations, Announcer of the Incarnation
attributes.Symbols: Trumpet, Lily (purity), Scroll, Lantern

name: God the Father
subtitle: The First Person of the Holy Trinity
description:
The transcendent Creator, eternal source of all being, loving Father who sent the Son and pours out
                the Spirit. Revealed in the Old Testament as YHWH ("I AM WHO I AM"), worshipped as the sovereign
                Lord who governs all creation with wisdom, justice, and mercy.

attributes.Titles: Ancient of Days, Almighty, Most High, Abba (Father), Lord of Hosts
attributes.Domains: Creation, Providence, Authority, Sovereignty, Justice, Mercy
attributes.Symbols: Throne, Crown, All-Seeing Eye, Hand from Clouds, Triangle
attributes.Sacred Names: YHWH, Elohim, El Shaddai, Adonai, Jehovah

name: The Holy Spirit
subtitle: The Third Person of the Holy Trinity
description:
The divine presence actively working in the world and in believers' hearts. The Comforter, Advocate,
                and Paraclete promised by Jesus. The Spirit of truth who guides, empowers, sanctifies, and transforms.
                Manifests as wind, fire, dove, water, and oil - the mysterious breath of God moving through creation.

attributes.Titles: Comforter, Advocate, Paraclete, Spirit of Truth, Spirit of God, Breath of Life
attributes.Domains: Inspiration, Transformation, Gifts, Guidance, Conviction, Sanctification
attributes.Symbols: Dove, Flame, Wind, Water, Oil, Breath
attributes.Sacred Manifestations: Tongues of fire, Rushing wind, Descending dove, Living water, Anointing oil
attributes.Sacred Number: Seven (seven gifts, seven spirits before throne)

name: Jesus Christ
subtitle: The Second Person of the Holy Trinity - God Incarnate
description:
The Word (Logos) made flesh, fully God and fully human. Born of the Virgin Mary in Bethlehem, lived
                a sinless life, performed miracles, proclaimed the Kingdom of God, died sacrificially on the cross
                for humanity's sins, rose from the dead on the third day, and ascended to the Father's right hand.
                The central figure of Christianity, mediator between God and humanity.

attributes.Titles: Christ, Messiah, Son of God, Son of Man, Lamb of God, Good Shepherd, Light of the World
attributes.Domains: Redemption, Salvation, Love, Sacrifice, Healing, Teaching, Resurrection
attributes.Symbols: Cross, Lamb, Fish (Ichthys), Sacred Heart, Alpha & Omega, Chi-Rho
attributes.Sacred Plants: Grape vine (true vine), Lily (purity), Olive (peace), Crown of thorns

name: Michael
subtitle: Prince of the Heavenly Host, Defender Against Evil
description: The greatest of all angels, commander of the heavenly armies and champion of God's people. His name, meaning "Who is like God?", is itself a rhetorical question affirming God's supremacy. Michael is portrayed as the warrior-protector who defends against the forces of evil, particularly Satan and his demons.

attributes.Role: Commander of Heaven's armies, Protector of Israel and the Church, Defeater of Satan
attributes.Symbols: Sword, Shield, Scales of Justice, Dragon beneath feet

name: Amun-Ra Amen-Ra
subtitle: King of the Gods, The Hidden Sun
description: Amun-Ra is the syncretic fusion of Amun (the hidden one) and Ra (the sun). Supreme god of the New Kingdom, combining Amun's mysterious transcendence with Ra's manifest solar power. 'King of the Gods' worshipped at Karnak's vast temple complex. Consort of Mut, father of Khonsu. Pharaohs claimed divine descent from Amun-Ra.

name: Anhur Onuris  êœ¥ná¸¥r
subtitle: God of War and Hunting
description: Anhur is the warrior god and divine hunter, 'He Who Brings Back the Distant One.' Associated with bringing Hathor/Tefnut back from Nubia when she fled Egypt in rage. Depicted as bearded man with four feathers on head, holding spear or lance. Patron of the Egyptian army and royal hunting expeditions.

name: Anubis Inpu Anpu  jnpw
subtitle: Guardian of the Dead, Lord of Mummification, Guide of Souls
description: Anubis is the ancient jackal-headed god of death, mummification, and the afterlife. As the original lord of the necropolis and guide of souls through the Duat, Anubis stands as protector of the dead and guardian of the scales of judgment. His presence ensures proper burial rites and safe passage to the realm of Osiris.

attributes.Titles: Lord of the Sacred Land, He Who Is Upon His Sacred Mountain, Master of Secrets, Guardian of the Scales, Foremost of the Divine Booth
attributes.Domains: Death, mummification, embalming, the afterlife, judgment of souls, protection of tombs, necropolis
attributes.Symbols: Jackal, black dog, embalming tools, scales of justice, ankh, was scepter, flail
attributes.Sacred Animals: Jackal, black dog (associated with desert scavengers who frequented burial grounds)
attributes.Colors: Black (regeneration, fertile Nile soil, putrefaction that precedes rebirth), gold (divine flesh)

myths.title: The Mummification of Osiris
myths.content: When Set murdered and dismembered Osiris, Anubis invented mummification to preserve Osiris's body. Working with Isis and Nephthys, Anubis performed the first embalming, creating the techniques that would be used throughout Egyptian history. This established mummification as a sacred act that could grant eternal life.

myths.title: Guardian of the Scales
myths.content: In the Hall of Two Truths, Anubis oversees the weighing of the heart ceremony. He places the deceased's heart on one side of the scales and the feather of Ma'at (truth and justice) on the other. If the heart is lighter than the feather, the soul may pass to the Field of Reeds. If heavier with sin, the heart is devoured by Ammit. Thoth records the judgment, but Anubis ensures the scales remain true.

myths.title: Battle Against Set
myths.content: After helping restore Osiris, Anubis fought alongside Horus against Set. In some versions, Anubis captured Set and flayed him, wearing his skin as a warning to those who would desecrate tombs. This established Anubis as protector against forces of chaos that threaten the dead.

myths.title: Guide Through the Duat
myths.content: Anubis leads souls through the perilous twelve regions of the Duat, protecting them from demons and guiding them past obstacles. His knowledge of secret paths and passwords allows the properly prepared dead to navigate safely to judgment.

family.Parents: Osiris and Nephthys (in most traditions), though some texts claim Ra or Set as father
family.Consort: Anput (female form of Anubis), Input
family.Children: Kebechet (goddess of purification and cooling water for the dead)
family.Siblings: Various, depending on parentage tradition

worship.sacredSites: Anubis's primary cult center was Cynopolis (Hardai, "City of the Dog") in Upper Egypt. He was also worshipped at necropolis sites throughout Egypt, particularly at Abydos, Memphis, and Thebes. Every tomb and embalming workshop was considered sacred to Anubis, and his priests (called "Imy-ut" or "He who is in the place of embalming") performed funerary rites.
festivals: The Festival of Wag: Celebrated during the first month of the flood season, honoring the dead with offerings and processionals to tombs. Anubis received special offerings as guardian of the necropolis.

Opening of the Mouth Ceremony: Performed on mummies and tomb statues, this ritual reanimated the deceased's senses. Anubis priests presided, using ritual instruments to symbolically open the mouth, eyes, and ears of the dead.
worship.offerings: Offerings to Anubis included: myrrh and frankincense (embalming materials), natron (purification salt), linen bandages, black dogs or jackals (symbolic), bread and beer, ox meat, incense. Offerings were placed at tomb entrances and in funerary temples, asking for Anubis's protection of the deceased and safe passage through the underworld.

sources: Pyramid Texts, Book of the Dead (especially Spell 125 - Judgment Scene), Papyrus of Ani, Temple inscriptions at Abydos, Coffin Texts, Amduat

name: Apep Apophis
subtitle: Serpent of Chaos, Enemy of Ra
description: Apep is the monstrous chaos serpent who attacks Ra's solar barque nightly during its journey through the Duat. Embodiment of isfet (chaos, disorder, darkness), eternally battling ma'at (order). Defeated nightly by Set and Ra's defenders, but never permanently destroyed. Apep's victory would mean the end of creation itself.

name: Atum Tem Temu
subtitle: The Complete One, First God, Setting Sun
description: Atum is the self-created primordial deity who emerged from the waters of Nun at creation. He represents completion and the setting sun. Often merged with Ra as Atum-Ra, he masturbated or spat to create Shu (air) and Tefnut (moisture), beginning the Ennead. He is both the first and last god, present at creation and at the end of time.

name: Bastet Bast Baast
subtitle: Goddess of Cats, Protection, Home, and Fertility
description: Bastet is the beloved feline goddess of ancient Egypt, protector of the home, guardian against evil spirits and disease, and embodiment of joy and feminine power. Originally depicted as a fierce lioness warrior, she evolved into the gentle domestic cat goddess, though she retained her fierce protective nature when defending those under her care. As daughter of Ra, she represents the warming, nurturing aspect of the sun, in contrast to her fiercer leonine counterpart Sekhmet.

attributes.Titles: Lady of the East, Goddess of the Rising Sun, Eye of Ra, Lady of Bubastis, Mistress of Joy, Protector of the Two Lands, Lady of Perfumed Ointments, The Cat Goddess, She of the Ointment Jar
attributes.Domains: Cats, protection, home, fertility, motherhood, music, dance, joy, perfume, ointments, the sun's warmth, women's secrets, childbirth, sexuality
attributes.Symbols: Cat (domestic), lioness (earlier form), sistrum (sacred rattle), ankh, solar disk, was scepter, perfume jar, kittens
attributes.Sacred Animals: Domestic cat (primary), lioness (ancient form), sometimes associated with wildcats
attributes.Sacred Plants: Catnip, myrrh (for perfumes and ointments), lotus
attributes.Colors: Gold (divine radiance, solar connection), bronze (earthly protection), green (fertility), black (night protection), white (purity)

myths.title: Daughter of Ra
myths.content: Bastet was born from the fire of Ra's eye, making her one of the solar deities. As the Eye of Ra, she represents the sun's gentler, nurturing warmthâ€”the morning sun that brings joy and awakening, rather than the scorching midday heat. She was said to accompany Ra on his daily journey across the sky, her feline eyes watching for threats to the sun god. In some myths, she helped defend Ra against the serpent Apophis, who sought to devour the sun each night.

myths.title: The Lioness Who Became a Cat
myths.content: In the Old Kingdom, Bastet was depicted as a fierce lioness, nearly indistinguishable from Sekhmet. Some theologians considered them two aspects of the same goddessâ€”Sekhmet being her wrathful form, Bastet her peaceful one. As Egypt moved from constant warfare to periods of peace and prosperity, Bastet's iconography shifted from the wild lioness to the domestic cat, reflecting the civilization's own transformation. However, she never lost her protective ferocityâ€”like a house cat that purrs gently but can turn deadly when her kittens are threatened.

myths.title: Protector Against Evil
myths.content: Bastet was invoked to protect homes from evil spirits, disease, and misfortune. Cats were considered magical guardians, their ability to see in darkness suggesting they could perceive supernatural threats invisible to humans. Bastet was particularly called upon during childbirth and to protect young children, much as cats protect their kittens. Her presence was believed to drive away the demons of illness and the spirits that caused miscarriage or infant death.

myths.title: Guardian of the Pharaoh
myths.content: As a solar deity and protector, Bastet was closely associated with the pharaoh's divine protection. The king was said to be suckled by Bastet in her lioness form, granting him divine strength and protection. Her fierce nature defended the throne against enemies, while her nurturing aspect ensured the land's fertility and prosperity.

myths.title: Goddess of Joy and Celebration
myths.content: Bastet's festivals were among the most joyous in Egypt. Her annual celebration at Bubastis drew hundreds of thousands of pilgrims who traveled by boat, playing music, singing, dancing, and drinking wine liberally. This reflected her domain over joy, music, dance, and the pleasures of life. She represented the balance between duty and enjoyment, protection and celebration.

family.Consort(s): Ptah (in some traditions), Atum (in others)
family.Children: Maahes (lion-headed god of war and protection), Nefertem (god of perfume and lotus, in some traditions)
family.Associated With: Sekhmet (sometimes considered her fierce counterpart or alternate form)

worship.sacredSites: Bastet's primary cult center was at Bubastis (Per-Bast, modern Tell Basta) in the Nile Delta, where her massive temple complex included cat catacombs and hosted the most famous festival in Egypt. She was also worshipped at Memphis (as consort of Ptah), Saqqara, and in household shrines throughout Egypt.
festivals: The Festival of Bastet at Bubastis: Herodotus described this as one of the most popular and well-attended festivals in Egypt, drawing some 700,000 pilgrims. Participants traveled by boat to Bubastis, with women playing sistrums, men playing flutes, and people singing, clapping, and dancing. Wine flowed freely, and the atmosphere was one of uninhibited celebration. At the temple, elaborate rituals honored Bastet, and offerings of mummified cats were presented. The festival celebrated life, joy, fertility, and protectionâ€”all aspects of the goddess.
worship.offerings: Offerings to Bastet included: mummified cats (most common), milk, fish, perfumes and scented oils, sistrums and musical instruments, jewelry, small cat figurines (often made of bronze), flowers, beer and wine. Households kept small shrines with cat images where daily offerings ensured the goddess's protection.

sources: Pyramid Texts, Coffin Texts, Temple inscriptions at Bubastis (Tell Basta), Herodotus's "Histories" (Book 2, description of Bastet festival), Book of the Dead, various protective amulets and household shrines

name: Geb Seb Keb
subtitle: God of the Earth
description: Geb is the earth god, depicted lying beneath his sister-consort Nut (sky). Father of Osiris, Isis, Set, and Nephthys. His laughter causes earthquakes, and vegetation grows from his body. As earth god, he judged disputes between Horus and Set, ultimately awarding rulership to Horus.

name: Hathor Het-Heru
subtitle: Goddess of Love, Joy, Music, Beauty, and Motherhood
description: Hathor is the cow-horned goddess of love, beauty, music, dance, motherhood, and joy. Mother or wife of Horus (depending on tradition), she could transform into Sekhmet when angered. Patron of miners, musicians, and dancers. The Eye of Ra in wrathful form, but usually benevolent goddess who brings joy and abundance.

name: Horus Heru Hor
subtitle: God of Kingship, Sky, and Vengeance
description: Horus is the falcon-headed god of the sky, kingship, and divine right to rule. As the son of Osiris and Isis, he avenged his father's murder by defeating Set and became the divine prototype of the pharaoh. The living king was considered Horus incarnate, while the dead king became Osiris.

name: Imhotep
subtitle: Deified Sage, Architect, and Physician
description: Imhotep was a historical figure (c. 2650 BCE) who served Pharaoh Djoser as architect, physician, and sage. He designed the Step Pyramid at Saqqara, revolutionizing Egyptian architecture. Later deified as god of medicine, wisdom, and writing. Greeks identified him with Asclepius. Worshipped by scribes and healers seeking his wisdom and healing power.

name: Isis Aset Iset Eset  êœ£st
subtitle: Goddess of Magic, Motherhood, and Healing
description: Isis is the great mother goddess of ancient Egypt, the most powerful magician in the cosmos, and the devoted wife who resurrected her husband Osiris from death. As the throne of Egypt personified, she represents divine motherhood, protective magic, healing wisdom, and the triumph of love and persistence over death itself. Her cult spread far beyond Egypt, making her one of history's most widely worshipped goddesses.

attributes.Titles: Queen of Heaven, Great of Magic, Mother of the Gods, The Divine Mother, Lady of Ten Thousand Names, Throne of Egypt, Mistress of the House of Life, She Who Knows How to Make Right Use of the Heart
attributes.Domains: Magic (heka), motherhood, healing, protection, wisdom, throne/kingship, resurrection, marriage, fertility, navigation, agriculture
attributes.Symbols: Throne headdress (hieroglyph of her name), tyet knot (Isis knot/blood of Isis), wings, sistrum (musical rattle), solar disk between cow horns (when merged with Hathor), ankh
attributes.Sacred Animals: Kite bird (bird of prey, form she took to resurrect Osiris), cow (when syncretized with Hathor), scorpion (protected child Horus from scorpion stings), sow
attributes.Sacred Plants: Cedar (used to find Osiris's body), tamarisk (tree that grew around Osiris's coffin), myrrh, frankincense, rose, lotus, wheat
attributes.Colors: Red (blood, life force, the tyet knot), blue (lapis lazuli, heavens), white (purity, milk), gold (divinity), green (fertility)

myths.title: The Resurrection of Osiris
myths.content: When her husband Osiris was murdered and dismembered by Set, Isis embarked on the most famous quest in Egyptian mythology. She traveled throughout Egypt and beyond, searching for every piece of his body. With her sister Nephthys, she collected all the parts except his phallus (devoured by fish). Using her supreme magical knowledge, Isis reassembled Osiris, fashioned a golden phallus, and through powerful heka (magic) temporarily restored him to life. Transforming into a kite bird, she hovered over his body, fanning life into him with her wings. In this moment she conceived their son Horus. Though Osiris could not remain among the living and descended to rule the underworld, Isis had accomplished what no other hadâ€”she defeated death itself through magic and love. This myth established her as the greatest magician and the prototype for all healing and resurrection magic.

myths.title: Learning Ra's Secret Name
myths.content: Isis, though powerful, sought the ultimate magical authorityâ€”knowledge of Ra's true name, which contained the essence of his power. The sun god Ra, aging and weakened, would drool during his daily journey. Isis collected his saliva, mixed it with earth, and fashioned a magical serpent. She placed it on Ra's path, and when it bit him, the venom caused excruciating pain no god could heal. Ra called out for help, and Isis came, saying she could cure him only if he revealed his secret name. Ra tried to deceive her with his many public names (Khepri, Ra-Horakhty, Atum), but the pain only worsened. Finally, desperate, Ra allowed his true name to pass from his heart into hers. Immediately Isis commanded the poison to leave, and Ra was healed. From that moment, Isis possessed ultimate magical power, surpassing even the sun god himself. This myth explains Isis's supremacy in heka and demonstrates that wisdom and cunning can triumph over raw power.

myths.title: The Seven Scorpions and the Rich Woman
myths.content: While hiding in the Delta marshes to protect infant Horus from Set, Isis traveled disguised as a poor woman, accompanied by seven magical scorpions as guardians. She sought shelter at the house of a wealthy woman, who slammed the door in her face, refusing hospitality. The scorpions, angered by this insult, pooled their venom into one scorpion named Tefen, who entered the rich woman's house and stung her innocent child. Hearing the mother's anguished cries, Isis returned and, despite being rejected, used her healing magic to save the childâ€”because an innocent should not suffer for his mother's cruelty. The rich woman, humbled, gave all her possessions to the poor woman who had first offered Isis hospitality. This myth teaches compassion, proper hospitality, and that Isis protects the innocent even when she has been wronged. It also established her as the patron goddess of healing magic and childbirth.

myths.title: Protecting Horus in the Marshes
myths.content: After Osiris's death, Isis knew Set would try to kill her son Horus, the rightful heir. She fled to the papyrus marshes of the Nile Delta (Khemmis), one of the most dangerous places in Egypt, infested with crocodiles, hippos, and serpents. There she raised Horus in secret, using her magic to protect him from both divine and natural threats. In one story, Horus was stung by a scorpion and lay dying. Isis's own magic could not save him, so she called out to the heavens. Ra halted the solar barque, and Thoth descended to teach Isis additional spells. With these, she revived Horus. This myth established the "Cippi of Horus" (magical stelae showing child Horus trampling crocodiles and grasping snakes), used for protective magic. Isis's fierce maternal protection became legendaryâ€”she would face any danger to defend her child.

myths.title: Isis and the Fisherman
myths.content: After Set murdered Osiris, he attempted to claim the throne by force. The gods were divided, with some supporting Set's strength and others supporting Horus's legitimate claim. During one trial, the gods decided to hear only the testimony of deities, not mortals. Isis, knowing she must testify, disguised herself as an old woman and approached a fisherman, asking him to ferry her to the Island of Aegileia where the gods were deliberating. The ferryman had been ordered not to transport any woman to the island. Isis bribed him with a gold ring. Once on the island, she transformed into a beautiful young woman and approached Set. She told him a story of a widow whose son was robbed of his inheritance by a stranger. Set, not recognizing Isis, declared: "Shall the cattle be given to the stranger while the son of the herdsman is still alive?" Isis immediately transformed and revealed herself, declaring Set had condemned himself by his own judgmentâ€”the rightful son must inherit. Ra and the Ennead agreed, awarding the throne to Horus. The ferryman who had disobeyed orders had his toes cut off as punishment. This myth demonstrates Isis's cunning, her ability to outwit even gods, and her role in establishing rightful succession.

family.Parents: Geb (earth god) and Nut (sky goddess) - born on the fourth epagomenal day added to the year by Thoth
family.Consort(s): Osiris (brother-husband whom she loved so deeply she resurrected him from death)
family.Children: Horus the Younger (conceived after Osiris's death, raised in secret in the marshes), sometimes considered mother of the four Sons of Horus
family.Siblings: Osiris (brother-husband), Set (brother and enemy), Nephthys (sister and ally in mourning and magic)

worship.sacredSites: Isis's primary temple was at Philae (on an island in the Nile near Aswan), which remained active into the 6th century CEâ€”the last functioning pagan temple in the ancient world. Other major sites included Behbeit el-Hagar (Delta region, her birthplace), Giza (Temple of Isis near the pyramids), Dendera (shared with Hathor), Abydos (associated with Osiris mysteries), and temples throughout the Mediterranean world after her cult spread to Greece, Rome, and beyond. The "Iseum" temples in Italy, Gaul, Iberia, and even Britain testify to her universal appeal.
festivals: The Isia (Greco-Roman Festival of Isis): October 28 - November 3. This multi-day festival reenacted Isis's search for Osiris, her mourning, the discovery of his body, and his resurrection. Participants engaged in ritual lamentation, fasting, and then joyful celebration when the god was "found." Priests carrying sacred vessels of Nile water blessed the people. This festival spread throughout the Roman Empire.

The Navigium Isidis (Ship of Isis): March 5 in Roman calendar. Celebrated Isis as patron of sailors and navigation. A ceremonial ship was launched, blessed by Isis priests, marking the opening of sailing season. This festival acknowledged Isis's protection over Mediterranean trade routes and demonstrated how her Egyptian origins merged with Greco-Roman maritime needs.

The Lychnapsia (Festival of Lights): August 12. Thousands of oil lamps were lit in honor of Isis, symbolizing her bringing light (knowledge, magic, hope) into darkness. Participants kept vigil through the night, celebrating her role as the divine light that guides through darknessâ€”both literal and spiritual.
worship.offerings: Offerings to Isis emphasized nourishment, healing, and beauty: milk (motherhood), honey (sweetness and preservation), roses (love and beauty), myrrh and frankincense (incense for sacred rites), linen (especially white), sistrum instruments (her sacred rattle, played during rituals), bread and beer, water from the Nile, perfumed oils, jewelry (especially the tyet knot amulet). Mothers seeking to conceive or protect children offered votive images of Isis nursing Horus. Healers seeking knowledge offered scrolls and writing implements.

sources: Pyramid Texts (Old Kingdom), Coffin Texts, Book of the Dead, Plutarch's "De Iside et Osiride" (most complete Greek account), Metternich Stela (magical healing texts), Temple inscriptions at Philae (primary Isis temple), Dendera, Behbeit el-Hagar, "Lamentations of Isis and Nephthys" ritual texts, Greco-Roman Isis aretalogies (hymns of praise)

name: Maat Maat
subtitle: Goddess of Truth, Justice, Cosmic Order, and Balance
description: Ma'at is both goddess and cosmic principle, embodying truth, justice, harmony, balance, order, and righteousness. She is the foundation of Egyptian civilization and the moral law that governs both gods and humans. Ma'at represents the opposite of chaos (isfet) and her feather weighs souls in the afterlife. To "do ma'at" meant to live righteously, maintain social order, and uphold divine law.

attributes.Titles: Lady of Truth, Mistress of the Gods, Daughter of Ra, Eye of Ra, She Who Guides, Regent of the Two Lands
attributes.Domains: Truth, justice, cosmic order, balance, harmony, morality, law, righteousness, proper conduct
attributes.Symbols: Ostrich feather (her primary symbol), scales of justice, ankh, was scepter, pedestal (symbol of foundation)
attributes.Colors: White (purity), gold (divine truth), green (life and growth in balance)
attributes.Depiction: Woman wearing ostrich feather on her head, sometimes shown with wings, seated on heels with feather, or simply as the feather itself

family.Consort: Thoth (god of wisdom and writing, her perfect complement)
family.Siblings: Sometimes described as twin of Shu (air) or paired with Thoth as cosmic principles

worship.sacredSites: Ma'at was honored in every temple throughout Egypt, as she was essential to all divine worship. She had no major independent temples, as her presence was required everywhere. Every act of worship, every offering, every prayer was an affirmation of ma'at.

sources: Pyramid Texts, Book of the Dead (Spell 125), Coffin Texts, Instructions of Ptahhotep, Loyalist Instruction, Temple inscriptions throughout Egypt, Wisdom Literature

name: Montu Month Menthu  mntw
subtitle: God of War and the Bull
description: Montu is the falcon-headed war god associated with the bull. Once supreme god of Thebes before being supplanted by Amun. God of military victory, martial prowess, and the raging bull's strength. Depicted with bull horns and sun disk. Pharaohs called themselves 'Mighty Bull, Son of Montu' when emphasizing military might.

name: Neith Nit Net Neit
subtitle: Goddess of War, Weaving, Wisdom, and Primordial Creation
description: Neith is one of the most ancient and complex goddesses of Egypt, predating even the creation of the world. Self-created and emerging from the primordial waters of Nun, she wove the cosmos into being with her shuttle and thread. She is simultaneously the fierce warrior goddess protecting Egypt with bow and arrows, the wise arbiter who judges disputes among the gods, and the cosmic weaver who spins fate and reality itself. Her cult center at Sais made her one of the most important deities of Lower Egypt, and her multifaceted natureâ€”warrior and creator, mother and virgin, cosmic and domesticâ€”makes her unique among Egyptian deities.

attributes.Titles: Mother of the Gods, Opener of the Ways, Lady of the West, Mistress of the Bow, She Who Weaves the World, The Terrifying One, Eldest of the Divine Mothers, Great Goddess, Lady of Sais
attributes.Domains: War, hunting, weaving, wisdom, primordial waters (Nun), creation, funeral rites, the cosmos, fate, domestic crafts, judgment, Lower Egypt
attributes.Symbols: Crossed arrows and shield, weaving shuttle, bow and arrows, Red Crown of Lower Egypt (Deshret), two crossed arrows, the was scepter, ankh
attributes.Sacred Animals: Cow (ancient mother goddess aspect), crocodile (as mother of Sobek), bee (industriousness and Lower Egypt), lates fish (Nile perch)
attributes.Sacred City: Sais (Zau, capital of Lower Egypt during the 26th Dynasty, site of her primary temple and burial place of Osiris according to local tradition)
attributes.Colors: Red (Red Crown of Lower Egypt, warfare, creation fire), green (primordial waters, fertility, regeneration), white (linen, weaving, purity)

myths.title: The Primordial Creatrix
myths.content: In the beginning, before earth and sky existed, there was only the dark waters of Nun, the primordial chaos. From these waters Neith emerged, self-created and needing no other. Some traditions say she spoke thirty words of power to bring creation into being; others say she wove the world on her loom, her shuttle moving back and forth to create the warp and weft of reality itself. Each thread she wove became a part of existenceâ€”land, sky, gods, humans, animals, plants. Her weaving was not merely creation but the establishment of cosmic order (Ma'at), the patterns and laws that would govern all existence. This makes her not just a creator but the architect of reality's very structure. As the self-created one, she needed no consort, making her both mother and father of creationâ€”an androgynous primordial force predating gender itself. Her temple at Sais bore the inscription: "I am all that has been, that is, and that will be. No mortal has yet been able to lift the veil that covers me."

myths.title: Mother of Ra and the Sun
myths.content: In some cosmological traditions, particularly those centered in Sais, Neith was said to be the mother of Ra, the sun god himself. She birthed him from the primordial waters and sent him on his first journey across the newly created sky. Each dawn, when Ra rises, it is Neith who opens the way for himâ€”hence her title "Opener of the Ways." In this role, she predates and supersedes even the great sun god, making her the ultimate source of light, warmth, and life itself. Other traditions suggest she gave birth to Apep, the serpent of chaos who opposes Raâ€”making her the mother of both order and chaos, demonstrating the totality of her primordial nature. She contains all possibilities, all potentials, the seed of everything that is and could be.

myths.title: The Arbitrator of Gods - Judgment of Horus and Set
myths.content: When the gods were deadlocked over who should inherit Osiris's throneâ€”Horus, the legitimate son, or Set, the powerful brotherâ€”they turned to Neith for judgment, acknowledging her as the wisest of all deities. Her arbitration is recorded in the Contendings of Horus and Set. Neith declared that Horus should receive the throne as rightful heir, but to appease Set's wounded pride and prevent cosmic warfare, she proposed that Set should receive two foreign goddesses (Anat and Astarte) as wives and be honored as the god of storms and foreign lands. She essentially brokered a cosmic peace treaty, using her wisdom to balance justice with pragmatism, legitimate succession with political reality. The gods accepted her judgment without questionâ€”even Ra, the king of gods, deferred to her wisdom. This myth establishes Neith as the supreme arbiter, whose judgments carry absolute authority.

myths.title: Judge of Osiris and Guardian of the Dead
myths.content: In funerary traditions, Neith played a crucial protective role. She was one of the four goddesses (along with Isis, Nephthys, and Serket) who protected the canopic jars containing the deceased's organs. Specifically, Neith guarded the canopic jar protected by Duamutef (the jackal-headed son of Horus), which contained the stomach. Her presence ensured the deceased could receive nourishment in the afterlife. In the Book of the Dead, she appears as a protector who provides the deceased with weapons and armor for their journey through the Duat. Some texts describe her as present at the weighing of the heart ceremony, her wisdom contributing to the judgment of souls. Her role as "Lady of the West" (the direction of the dead) meant she received and protected the deceased as they entered the afterlife.

myths.title: The Warrior Goddess and Protector of Egypt
myths.content: Neith was the patron goddess of Lower Egypt's armies and hunters. Pharaohs, particularly those of the 26th Dynasty who made Sais their capital, called upon Neith for victory in battle. She was depicted with bow and arrows, leading armies and striking down Egypt's enemies. Unlike other war deities who embodied raw violence, Neith combined strategic wisdom with martial prowessâ€”she was the thinking warrior, the general who planned campaigns, not merely the soldier who fought. Hunters offered prayers and first kills to Neith, acknowledging her mastery of the hunt. Her arrows never missed, and her enemies fell before her unerring aim. Yet she was not bloodthirstyâ€”her warfare served protective and defensive purposes, maintaining Ma'at against the forces of chaos (isfet).

myths.title: Weaving the Mummy Wrappings
myths.content: Neith's aspect as goddess of weaving extended to the sacred craft of preparing the dead. She was said to have woven the first mummy wrappings for Osiris, creating the prototype for all funerary linens. The bandages that wrapped mummies were called "the tapes of Neith," and embalmers invoked her blessing as they wrapped the deceased. This connected her creative weaving (making the cosmos) with her funerary role (preparing souls for rebirth). Just as she wove the world into existence, she wove the wrappings that would protect and transform the dead into akh (effective spirits) capable of navigating the afterlife. The act of wrapping became a sacred repetition of cosmic creationâ€”each mummy a microcosm being prepared for new existence.

family.Parents: Noneâ€”Neith is self-created, emerging from the primordial waters of Nun without mother or father
family.Consort(s): None in most traditions (virgin creator goddess); in some local traditions married to Sobek or Set
family.Children: Ra (in Saite tradition as mother of the sun), Sobek (crocodile god, in some traditions), Apep (serpent of chaos, in some cosmogonies), sometimes considered mother of all gods collectively
family.Siblings: Noneâ€”as primordial deity she predates the Ennead and other divine generations

worship.sacredSites: Neith's primary cult center was at Sais (modern Sa el-Hagar) in the western Nile Delta, which served as Egypt's capital during the 26th Dynasty (664-525 BCE). Her temple there, called "Hwt-Nit" (House of Neith), was one of Egypt's most important religious sites. According to tradition, Sais also contained a hidden tomb of Osiris and a sacred lake where his resurrection mysteries were performed annually. Other worship sites included Esna (Iunyt) in Upper Egypt where she was honored alongside Khnum and Heka, temples throughout the Delta region, and shrines in royal capitals where pharaohs sought her wisdom for matters of state.
festivals: The Feast of the Lamps (Festival of Neith): Herodotus records a major festival at Sais where devotees lit countless lamps throughout the night, creating a "sea of lights." This celebrated Neith as the primordial light-bringer who illuminated the darkness of Nun and brought forth creation. The lamps symbolized both the light of wisdom and the first light of creation. This festival later influenced Greco-Roman lamp festivals and may have contributed to various "festival of lights" traditions.

The Mysteries of Osiris at Sais: Sacred mysteries depicting Osiris's death and resurrection were performed at night on the sacred lake at Neith's temple. Herodotus considered these too sacred to describe in detail. These mysteries connected Neith's creative powers (bringing forth life from the primordial waters) with resurrection themes (bringing forth renewed life from death). Initiates underwent ritual rebirth, echoing both cosmic creation and personal transformation.

Royal Coronation Rites: Pharaohs, particularly those of Lower Egyptian origin, included invocations to Neith in coronation ceremonies. She blessed the Red Crown (Deshret) of Lower Egypt and was called upon to grant the king wisdom in judgment and strength in defending Ma'at. Her role as "Opener of the Ways" made her essential to inaugurating new reigns.
worship.offerings: Offerings to Neith reflected her multiple aspects: weapons (bows, arrows, shields dedicated by warriors and hunters), woven goods (fine linens, textiles, representing her weaving aspect), the first kill from hunts (acknowledging her as mistress of the hunt), incense and myrrh (for funerary rites), water from the Nile (representing primordial Nun), lamps and torches (light against darkness), written petitions for judgment (seeking her wisdom in disputes), and cow's milk (honoring her nurturing mother aspect). Weavers offered their finest work, seeking her blessing on their craft.

sources: Pyramid Texts (particularly spells 300-302 mentioning Neith's primordial nature), Coffin Texts, Book of the Dead (Spell 137 - Neith providing torches for the deceased), Temple of Neith at Sais inscriptions (recorded by Plutarch and Proclus), The Contendings of Horus and Set (her arbitration), Esna Temple texts (Late Period cosmological texts), Greek accounts by Herodotus (Histories 2.28, 2.59, 2.62, 2.169-171), Plutarch's "De Iside et Osiride"

name: Nephthys Nebet-Het
subtitle: Lady of the House - Goddess of Death, Funerary Rites, and Hidden Things
description: Nephthys is the mysterious goddess of death, night, and mourning in ancient Egyptian mythology. As the "Lady of the House" and "Lady of Hidden Things," she presides over funerary rites, protects the dead on their journey through the underworld, and stands as the divine mourner alongside her sister Isis. Though wife of Set, she aided Isis in resurrecting Osiris and is mother to Anubis through a union with Osiris. Her presence represents the unseen aspects of existenceâ€”darkness, secrets, and the transition between life and death.

attributes.Titles: Lady of the House (Nebet-Het), Lady of Hidden Things, Goddess of the Night, Mistress of the Temple, Friend of the Dead, Revealer of the Unseen, Divine Mourner
attributes.Domains: Death, funerary rites, mourning, night, darkness, hidden things, protection of the dead, transition, secrets, temples, service
attributes.Symbols: House/basket hieroglyph on her head, wings (spread over the dead), ankh, tyet knot, funerary bed, temple enclosure
attributes.Sacred Animals: Kite bird (bird of prey, form she took when mourning Osiris), jackal (through association with son Anubis), night birds
attributes.Sacred Plants: Myrrh (funerary incense), frankincense, lotus (rebirth), acacia (associated with death rituals)
attributes.Colors: Indigo (deep night), purple (mourning), black (death and mystery), white (funerary linen), silver (moonlight)

myths.title: Aiding Isis in Resurrecting Osiris
myths.content: When Set murdered and dismembered Osiris, Nephthys betrayed her husband to help her sister Isis. Together, the two sisters searched throughout Egypt, gathering the scattered pieces of Osiris. They transformed into kite birds, circling over the reassembled body while chanting the "Lamentations of Isis and Nephthys," powerful magical incantations that helped restore Osiris to temporary life. This ritual became the prototype for all Egyptian funerary rites, with professional mourners reenacting the roles of Isis and Nephthys at every funeral. Nephthys represented the hidden, darker aspects of mourning and deathâ€”the night to Isis's day, the shadow to her light.

myths.title: The Birth of Anubis
myths.content: In one tradition, Nephthys was childless in her marriage to the sterile Set. Desiring a child and attracted to the vitality of Osiris, she disguised herself as Isis and seduced him. From this union was born Anubis, the jackal-headed god of mummification. Fearing Set's wrath, Nephthys abandoned the infant in the wilderness. Isis, discovering the child, raised him as her own with compassion rather than jealousy. Anubis grew to become the divine embalmer who would prepare his father Osiris for resurrectionâ€”a fitting role that connected mother and son through death rites. This myth explains Nephthys's association with hidden things (the secret affair) and her deep connection to funerary practices through her son.

myths.title: Guardian of the Coffin
myths.content: In funerary texts and art, Nephthys stands as one of the four protective goddesses guarding the corners of the coffin and the canopic shrine. She specifically protects the canopic jar containing the lungs (guarded by the god Hapy, one of the Four Sons of Horus). Her wings spread protectively over the deceased, shielding them from malevolent forces in the underworld. In the Book of the Dead, she speaks protective spells that guide the deceased through the dangerous passages of the Duat. Unlike Isis, who represents resurrection and return to life, Nephthys ensures peaceful passage into death and protection within the realm of the dead.

myths.title: The Invisible Companion
myths.content: Nephthys was called "Lady of Hidden Things" because she represented everything unseenâ€”the darkness of night when mysteries occur, the hidden processes of decay that must happen before rebirth, the secret knowledge possessed only by priestesses and embalmers. While Isis performed visible, active magic, Nephthys worked in shadows and silence. She was present at every death but rarely invoked directly, her power operating through subtle influence rather than dramatic intervention. Her name itselfâ€”"Lady of the House"â€”refers to the temple enclosure or the "house" of death (tomb), the hidden dwelling place where the dead reside.

family.Parents: Geb (earth god) and Nut (sky goddess) - born on the fifth and final epagomenal day
family.Consort(s): Set (brother-husband), though she betrayed him to aid Isis and had a union with Osiris
family.Children: Anubis (by Osiris, raised by Isis)
family.Siblings: Osiris, Isis (sister and closest ally), Set (brother-husband)

sources: Pyramid Texts, Coffin Texts, Book of the Dead, "Lamentations of Isis and Nephthys" ritual texts, Temple inscriptions at Kom Ombo and Edfu, Plutarch's "De Iside et Osiride"

name: Nut Nuit
subtitle: Goddess of the Sky and Heavens
description: Nut is the sky goddess whose body arches over the earth, swallowing the sun at dusk and giving birth to it at dawn. Mother of Osiris, Isis, Set, and Nephthys, born on the five epagomenal days won by Thoth. Her star-spangled body represents the night sky, and souls ascend to join her after death.

name: Osiris Asar Wesir Ausar  wsjr
subtitle: Lord of the Afterlife, God of Death and Resurrection
description: Osiris is the ancient Egyptian god of the dead, resurrection, and agriculture. Murdered by his brother Set and resurrected by his wife Isis, Osiris became the eternal king of the underworld (Duat), judge of the deceased, and symbol of eternal life. His myth of death and rebirth mirrors the agricultural cycle and offers hope of immortality to all who live by Ma'at.

attributes.Titles: Lord of the Dead, King of the Underworld, Lord of Eternity, The Great God, Foremost of the Westerners (the dead), Lord of Abydos, He Who is Permanently Benign and Youthful
attributes.Domains: Death, afterlife, resurrection, rebirth, agriculture, fertility, vegetation, judgment of the dead, kingship, transformation
attributes.Symbols: Crook and flail (royal regalia), atef crown (white crown with ostrich feathers), djed pillar (stability/backbone), was scepter, grain/wheat (sprouting from his body)
attributes.Sacred Animals: Bull (Apis bull of Memphis associated with Osiris), ram, phoenix (Bennu bird of resurrection)
attributes.Sacred Plants: Wheat and barley (grain represents death and resurrection), cedar (used in mummification), acacia (tree of life), willow, tamarisk, sycamore fig
attributes.Colors: Green (vegetation, renewal, life), black (fertile Nile soil, death, regeneration), white (mummy wrappings, purity)

myths.title: The Murder of Osiris
myths.content: Osiris ruled Egypt as a wise and beneficent king, teaching humanity agriculture, civilization, and law. His jealous brother Set (god of chaos and desert) conspired to seize the throne. Set crafted an ornate chest precisely fitted to Osiris's measurements and held a great feast. He promised to give the chest to whomever fit inside perfectly. When Osiris lay down in it, Set and 72 conspirators slammed the lid shut, sealed it with molten lead, and cast it into the Nile. The chest floated to Byblos (in Phoenicia) where a tamarisk tree grew around it, encasing the god's body within its trunk.

myths.title: Isis's Quest and First Resurrection
myths.content: Isis, Osiris's devoted wife and sister, searched desperately for her husband's body. She found the tree in Byblos, serving as a pillar in the king's palace, and brought Osiris's body back to Egypt, hiding it in the Nile Delta marshes. But Set discovered the body and tore it into fourteen pieces (or forty-two in some versions, one for each nome of Egypt), scattering them throughout the land. Isis, aided by her sister Nephthys (Set's wife), traveled Egypt collecting every piece. The only part never found was his phallus, devoured by an oxyrhynchus fish (forever after forbidden as food). Isis fashioned a replacement from gold and, using her powerful magic, temporarily resurrected Osiris long enough to conceive their son Horus. She transformed into a kite (bird) and hovered over Osiris's body, fanning life into him with her wings.

myths.title: Mummification and Transformation
myths.content: After conception, Osiris could not remain in the world of the living. Anubis, the jackal-headed god of embalming, performed the first mummification on Osiris's body, establishing the prototype for all Egyptian funerary rites. Osiris descended to become eternal ruler of the Duat, the underworld realm of the dead. Though he could not return to life, he achieved transformation into an eternal state, becoming the first being to die and be reborn. His green skin represents this regenerated stateâ€”life emerging from death, like crops from planted seeds.

myths.title: The Judgment of the Dead
myths.content: In his role as Lord of the Duat, Osiris presides over the weighing of the heart ceremony in the Hall of Ma'at. The deceased's heart is weighed against the feather of Ma'at (truth and justice) by Anubis, while Thoth records the result. Osiris sits enthroned, attended by the 42 divine judges, observing whether the heart is lighter than the feather (indicating a life lived by Ma'at) or heavier (laden with sin). If the heart is light, the deceased is declared "justified" (maa-kheru) and welcomed into the Field of Reeds, a paradise version of Egypt. If heavy, the heart is devoured by Ammit (the devourer), and the soul ceases to exist. Justified souls are called "Osiris [Name]," becoming one with the god.

myths.title: Horus Avenges His Father
myths.content: After Osiris's death, Isis raised their son Horus in secret in the Delta marshes, protecting him from Set's murderous intent. When Horus reached maturity, he challenged Set for the throne of Egypt. Their contendings lasted eighty years, involving battles, trials before the divine tribunal (presided over by Ra), and tests of strength and cunning. Ultimately, the gods awarded kingship to Horus, establishing the principle that the living pharaoh embodies Horus while the dead pharaoh becomes Osiris. This myth legitimized royal succession and linked every pharaoh to divine ancestry.

family.Parents: Geb (earth god) and Nut (sky goddess) - born on one of the five epagomenal days added to the calendar by Thoth
family.Consort(s): Isis (his sister and devoted wife who resurrected him); Nephthys (briefly, resulting in Anubis)
family.Children: Horus the Younger (by Isis - conceived after death), Anubis (by Nephthys, who disguised herself as Isis), sometimes considered father of the four Sons of Horus (guardians of canopic jars)
family.Siblings: Isis (sister-wife), Set (brother and murderer), Nephthys (sister)

worship.sacredSites: Abydos was Osiris's primary cult center, believed to be his burial place (or at least the location of his head). It became the most sacred pilgrimage site in Egyptâ€”every Egyptian hoped to be buried at Abydos or at least have a cenotaph there to participate in Osiris's resurrection. The Osiris Temple at Abydos housed mysterious underground chambers called the Osireion. Other major sites included Busiris (Delta, ancient cult center where his djed pillar was erected), Philae Temple (where his left leg was supposedly buried), and Memphis (where Apis bull merged with Osiris as Osorapis/Serapis in later periods).
festivals: The Osiris Mysteries (Khoiak Festival): Held during the month of Khoiak (roughly November-December), this was Egypt's most important festival. It reenacted Osiris's death, dismemberment, search, reassembly, and resurrection over multiple days. Priests performed mystery plays depicting the myth. Grain was planted in "Osiris beds" (mummy-shaped planters) and the sprouting grain symbolized resurrection. The djed pillar was ritually raised, symbolizing Osiris's resurrection and the stability of kingship. Massive processions carried Osiris's statue from temple to symbolic tomb and back.

The Beautiful Festival of the Valley (Wag Festival): Celebrated during the second month of Shomu (roughly April-May). The living visited tombs of their ancestors, bringing food offerings and flowers. Families would feast with the dead, believing the ba (soul) of the deceased could partake. This festival emphasized Osiris's role as king of the ancestors and intermediary between living and dead.
worship.offerings: Offerings to Osiris emphasized regeneration and sustenance: bread, beer, grain (especially wheat and barley), water, incense, oils for anointing, linen, ox, fowl, onions (symbolic of eternal life due to concentric layers), lettuce (sacred to Osiris, associated with fertility), wine, milk. The deceased were provided "Osiris beds"â€”ceramic or wooden mummy-shaped containers filled with soil and planted with grain, placed in tombs. When the grain sprouted, it demonstrated Osiris's resurrection and promised the same for the deceased.

sources: Pyramid Texts (Old Kingdom, ~2400 BCE - earliest references), Coffin Texts (Middle Kingdom), Book of the Dead (New Kingdom), Plutarch's "De Iside et Osiride" (Greco-Roman period - most complete narrative), Temple inscriptions at Abydos, Philae Temple, Shabaka Stone (Memphite Theology), Osiris Mysteries texts

name: Ptah  ptá¸¥
subtitle: Creator God, Patron of Craftsmen and Architects
description: Ptah is the creator god of Memphis who brought the world into being through thought and speech. Patron of craftsmen, architects, and artisans, depicted as mummified man holding staff. He created through divine utterance, speaking the names of all things to bring them into existence. Husband of Sekhmet, father of Nefertum.

name: Ra Re Atum-Ra  rêœ¥
subtitle: The Sun God, Creator, King of the Gods
description: Ra is the supreme solar deity of ancient Egypt, the self-created god who emerged from the primordial waters of Nun to bring light, life, and order to the cosmos. As the sun traversing the sky in his golden barque, Ra embodies divine kingship, the eternal cycle of death and rebirth, and the ultimate source of all existence.

attributes.Titles: The Sun God, Lord of the Sky, King of the Gods, The Great Illuminator, Atum-Ra (when self-created), Amun-Ra (merged with Amun)
attributes.Domains: Sun, light, creation, kingship, cosmic order (Ma'at), life force (ka), time
attributes.Symbols: Solar disk, golden barque (solar boat), scarab beetle (Khepri), falcon, ankh, was scepter, benben stone (primordial mound)
attributes.Sacred Animals: Falcon, scarab beetle (Khepri form), phoenix (Bennu bird), serpent (Mehen - protector)
attributes.Sacred Plants: Blue Lotus (Nymphaea caerulea) - opens at sunrise, closes at sunset
attributes.Colors: Gold, yellow, crimson (sunset), scarlet, white (solar light)

myths.title: Creation from Nun
myths.content: In the beginning was only Nun, the primordial waters of chaos. From these waters arose the benben stone, the first land, and upon it Ra (as Atum-Ra) created himself through an act of will and divine masturbation or spitting. He spoke his own name, bringing himself into existence, then created Shu (air) and Tefnut (moisture), beginning the Ennead lineage. Ra's tears became the first humans.

myths.title: The Daily Solar Journey
myths.content: Each day, Ra travels across the sky in his golden solar barque called the Mandjet (Day Boat). He is accompanied by Ma'at (order), Thoth (wisdom), and defenders against chaos. At noon he reaches his zenith as Ra-Horakhty. At dusk, he boards the Mesektet (Night Boat) and descends into the Duat (underworld), where he must traverse twelve hours of night, facing demons and the chaos serpent Apep. Each dawn he is reborn as Khepri (the scarab), emerging victorious from darkness.

myths.title: The Secret Name of Ra
myths.content: Ra possessed a secret true name which held the source of his power. Isis, desiring ultimate magical authority, crafted a serpent from Ra's spittle and earth, which bit him. Only Isis could heal the poison, but demanded his true name as payment. Reluctantly, Ra whispered his secret name into Isis's ear, transferring immense magical power to her. This myth explains Isis's supremacy in magic and shows even the greatest god could be manipulated through knowledge.

myths.title: Ra's Eye and the Destruction of Humanity
myths.content: When Ra grew old and humanity rebelled against his rule, he sent his Eye - manifesting as the goddess Sekhmet (or Hathor in wrathful form) - to punish them. Sekhmet became drunk on bloodlust and nearly destroyed all humanity. Ra relented and tricked her into drinking beer dyed red with pomegranate juice, which she mistook for blood. Intoxicated, she ceased her slaughter. This myth established the Sekhmet festival where beer was consumed to commemorate humanity's salvation.

myths.title: The Contendings of Horus and Set
myths.content: Ra presided over the divine tribunal that judged between Horus and Set for rulership of Egypt. Though Ra initially favored Set (who defended his barque nightly from Apep), the other gods and Ra's own daughter Hathor persuaded him to award kingship to Horus, establishing the principle of rightful succession.

family.Parents: Self-created from Nun (primordial waters); no parents, emerged through his own will and utterance of his secret name
family.Consort(s): Various, including Hathor (mother/daughter paradox), Iusaaset (grandmother of the Ennead in some texts), Ra-et (feminine counterpart)
family.Children: Shu (air) and Tefnut (moisture) - his first creations, born from his spit or tears; the Eye of Ra (Sekhmet, Hathor, Bastet) - extensions of his power; Ma'at - cosmic order personified
family.Siblings: None (as self-created primordial deity)

worship.sacredSites: Ra's primary cult center was Heliopolis (Iunu, "City of the Sun") in Lower Egypt, where the benben stone was housed in the Temple of Ra. Other major worship sites included Karnak Temple (as Amun-Ra), Luxor Temple, Abu Simbel (where Ramesses II built temples aligned so sunlight illuminates the inner sanctum twice yearly), and throughout Egypt where solar temples oriented to capture the rising or setting sun.
festivals: The Wepet Renpet (New Year Festival): Celebrated the heliacal rising of Sirius (Sopdet) which coincided with the Nile flood and Ra's cosmic renewal. Marked the beginning of the Egyptian calendar year. Involved processions, offerings of first fruits, and renewal of temple fires from the sun's rays.

Solar Alignment Festivals: At Abu Simbel, twice yearly (February 21 and October 21), the sun's rays penetrate 60 meters into the temple to illuminate statues of Ra-Horakhty, Amun-Ra, and Ramesses II in the inner sanctuary. Celebrated as the sun god's direct blessing upon the pharaoh.
worship.offerings: Morning offerings at sunrise were essential: bread, beer, oxen, fowl, incense (frankincense and myrrh), blue lotus flowers (which open at dawn), gold and precious metals (solar substances), linen, natron for purification. The morning hymn declared: "Awake in peace, Great God, awake in peace!" Offerings ensured Ra's strength to complete his daily journey and defeat Apep.

sources: Pyramid Texts (Old Kingdom, ~2400 BCE), Coffin Texts (Middle Kingdom), Book of the Dead (New Kingdom), Papyrus of Ani, Temple inscriptions at Heliopolis (largely destroyed), Karnak Temple Complex, Amduat ("That Which is in the Underworld"), Book of Gates

name: Satis Satet Satjit
subtitle: Goddess of the Nile Flood and Southern Border
description: Satis is the swift arrow goddess of ancient Egypt, who personifies the flooding of the Nile and guards Egypt's southern frontier. As part of the Elephantine Triad alongside Khnum and Anuket, she represents the swift, life-giving waters of the annual inundation and the protective fury that defends Egypt's borders from invaders. Her arrows fly true like the rushing flood waters that bring fertility to the land.

attributes.Titles: The Arrow, Mistress of Elephantine, She Who Shoots Forth, Guardian of the Southern Gate, Lady of the Flood, The Swift One
attributes.Domains: Nile flood, southern border protection, arrows and archery, fertility (through flooding), water abundance, swift justice
attributes.Symbols: Bow and arrow, antelope horns, white crown of Upper Egypt, water jar, ankh
attributes.Colors: River blue, water blue, white (crown and purity), silver (arrows)

worship.offerings: Offerings to Satis included water libations, arrows (symbolic of her protective power), white linen, and images of antelopes or gazelles. During flood season, special prayers and offerings were made to ensure the waters would come swiftly and abundantly.

sources: Pyramid Texts, Temple inscriptions at Elephantine Island, Sehel Island stelae, texts from the Temple of Khnum at Elephantine

name: Sekhmet Sakhmet  sá¸«mt
subtitle: Goddess of War, Healing, and Divine Vengeance
