description: Sekhmet is the lioness-headed goddess of war, plague, and healing. The Eye of Ra sent to punish rebellious humanity, she became drunk on bloodlust until tricked by Ra into drinking beer dyed red. Consort of Ptah, mother of Nefertum. Both destroyer and healer - her priests were physicians who could cause or cure disease.

name: Set Seth Sutekh
subtitle: God of Chaos, Desert, Storms, and Foreigners
description: Set is the god of chaos, the desert, storms, and disorder. Red-haired and fierce, Set murdered his brother Osiris but was defeated by Horus. Though often cast as villain, Set also defended Ra's solar barque against the chaos serpent Apep nightly. He represents necessary disorder, the wild desert, and the power of storms.

name: Sobek Sebek
subtitle: God of the Nile, Crocodiles, and Fertility
description: Sobek is the crocodile god of the Nile, military prowess, and fertility. Fierce protector and symbol of pharaonic power. Associated with both creation (emerged from primordial waters) and danger (crocodiles in the Nile). Sometimes considered son of Neith. Crocodiles were kept in sacred pools at his temples.

name: Tefnut Tefenet Tefnet  tfnt
subtitle: Goddess of Moisture, Dew, and Rain
description: Tefnut is one of the primordial deities of the Ennead of Heliopolis, the first goddess brought into existence by Atum's creative act. As the personification of moisture and atmospheric water, she represents the vital humidity needed for life in the arid Egyptian landscape. Sister-wife to Shu (air) and mother to Geb (earth) and Nut (sky), Tefnut embodies the moisture that pervades the airâ€”from morning dew to rain cloudsâ€”and the life-giving power of water in all its atmospheric forms.

attributes.Titles: Lady of the Dew, Mistress of Moisture, The Eye of Ra, Lady of the Flame, She of the Water
attributes.Domains: Moisture, dew, rain, atmospheric water, humidity, divine order (paired with Shu), solar eye
attributes.Symbols: Lion-headed woman, water droplets, moisture, solar disk, uraeus serpent, ankh, was scepter
attributes.Colors: Blue (water, sky moisture), steel blue (atmospheric water), cadet blue (rain), white (dew)

myths.title: The Distant Goddess
myths.content: One of Tefnut's most important myths describes her becoming angry and fleeing to Nubia (or sometimes Libya), abandoning Egypt. In her absence, moisture disappeared from the land, causing drought and suffering. Ra sent Thoth and Shu to retrieve her. Thoth disguised himself and told her stories and parables, gradually persuading her to return. When Tefnut came back to Egypt, she brought moisture and rain, restoring fertility to the land. This myth explains seasonal changes in moisture and the importance of the goddess's presence for agricultural prosperity.

myths.title: The Eye of Ra
myths.content: Tefnut is identified with the solar eye, the fierce protective aspect of the sun god. In this role, she embodies both creative moisture and destructive fireâ€”the dual nature of water and the burning sun. As the Eye, she could become wrathful and dangerous, requiring appeasement. This connects her moisture aspect with solar theology, showing her role in cosmic balance.

myths.title: Creation with Shu
myths.content: With her brother-husband Shu, Tefnut formed the primordial couple that gave birth to the physical world. Their union of air and moisture created the conditions for earth and sky to come into being. They represent the inseparable nature of atmospheric elementsâ€”air cannot exist without some moisture, and moisture requires air to be dispersed.

family.Parents: Atum (creator god, self-generated from the primordial waters)
family.Consort(s): Shu (god of air and light, her twin brother)
family.Children: Geb (earth god) and Nut (sky goddess)
family.Siblings: Shu (twin brother and husband, created alongside her by Atum)

sources: Pyramid Texts, Coffin Texts, The Myth of the Distant Goddess (various papyri), Temple inscriptions at Karnak and Dendara, Heliopolitan creation accounts

name: Thoth Djehuty Tehuti
subtitle: God of Wisdom, Writing, Magic, and the Moon
description: Thoth is the ibis-headed god of knowledge, writing, science, and magic. As the divine scribe, he records the judgment of souls and maintains the cosmic order. Master of hieroglyphs and sacred wisdom, Thoth embodies the intellectual and magical power of the written word and serves as mediator, messenger, and keeper of divine secrets.

attributes.Titles: Lord of Divine Words, Scribe of Ma'at, Reckoner of Time, He Who Balances, Master of Knowledge, Moon God, Three Times Great (Thoth Trismegistus in Hellenistic period)
attributes.Domains: Writing, wisdom, magic, science, mathematics, astronomy, medicine, judgment, arbitration, the moon, time, languages, knowledge
attributes.Symbols: Ibis bird, baboon, writing palette and reed pen, papyrus scroll, lunar disk and crescent, ankh, was scepter, scales
attributes.Sacred Animals: Ibis (represents wisdom, curved beak like crescent moon), baboon (sacred to the moon, intelligent)
attributes.Sacred Plants: Papyrus (writing material), palm fronds (used in time reckoning)

myths.title: Invention of Writing
myths.content: Thoth created hieroglyphs, the sacred writing of the gods. He presented this gift to humanity through the pharaohs, enabling the recording of history, magic spells, and divine wisdom. The Egyptians called hieroglyphs "medu netjer" (words of the gods), believing them to possess inherent magical power.

myths.title: Healing the Eye of Horus
myths.content: During the battle between Horus and Set, Set tore out Horus's eye. Thoth restored it through magic and mathematics, making it whole again. The restored Eye of Horus (Wedjat) became a symbol of healing, wholeness, and protection. This myth established Thoth as patron of medicine and healing arts.

myths.title: Arbitrator Between Horus and Set
myths.content: Thoth served as mediator in the divine tribunal judging between Horus and Set for rulership of Egypt. His wisdom and impartiality helped resolve the conflict, advocating for justice and rightful succession. His role as arbitrator established him as god of law and fair judgment.

myths.title: Scribe of the Judgment
myths.content: In the Hall of Two Truths, while Anubis weighs hearts against the feather of Ma'at, Thoth records the results. His perfect record-keeping ensures cosmic justice. He announces whether souls are "justified" and may enter the afterlife, or must be devoured by Ammit.

myths.title: The Gambling with the Moon
myths.content: When Nut (sky goddess) was cursed by Ra not to give birth on any day of the year, Thoth gambled with the moon god Khonsu and won 1/72nd of the moon's light from each day. With this light, he created five extra days (epagomenal days) outside the regular 360-day calendar, allowing Nut to give birth to Osiris, Isis, Set, Nephthys, and Horus the Elder.

myths.title: Partner in Mummification
myths.content: Thoth spoke the magical spells necessary for successful mummification and resurrection. His words of power, recorded in funerary texts, gave the dead power to navigate the underworld and transform into akh (effective spirits).

family.Parents: Self-created or born from the head of Set (depending on tradition); sometimes described as born from Ra's heart
family.Consort: Ma'at (goddess of truth and justice), Seshat (goddess of writing and measurement), Nehemetawy
family.Children: Seshat (in some traditions), Hornub

worship.sacredSites: Thoth's primary cult center was Hermopolis Magna (Khmun, "City of Eight") in Middle Egypt, where he was worshipped as creator god and leader of the Ogdoad (eight primordial deities). Sacred baboons and ibises were kept, mummified, and buried in catacombs at Tuna el-Gebel near Hermopolis. He was also venerated at Abydos, Memphis, and throughout Egypt in temples where scribes worked.
festivals: Festival of Thoth: Celebrated on the first month (Thoth) of the Egyptian calendar year. Involved offerings to ensure accurate record-keeping and maintenance of cosmic order for the coming year.
Epagomenal Days: The five extra days Thoth won from the moon were celebrated as birthdays of the gods, with Thoth honored as the clever deity who made them possible.
worship.offerings: Offerings to Thoth included: papyrus scrolls, writing implements, incense (frankincense), white linen, ibis feathers, offerings of baboon or ibis (symbolic or actual mummies), wine, milk, bread. Scribes made offerings before beginning important writings, asking for Thoth's guidance to write accurately and powerfully.

sources: Pyramid Texts, Coffin Texts, Book of the Dead, Papyrus of Ani, Temple inscriptions at Hermopolis, Contendings of Horus and Set, Medical papyri (Ebers Papyrus, Edwin Smith Papyrus)

name: Aphrodite
subtitle: Goddess of Love, Beauty, and Desire
description: Born from the sea foam, Aphrodite embodies love, beauty, pleasure, and procreation. Her powers extend to gods and mortals alike, causing desire, passion, and sometimes chaos in matters of the heart.

attributes.Titles: Foam-Born, Cyprian, Cytherea, Laughter-Loving, Golden Aphrodite
attributes.Domains: Love, beauty, desire, sexuality, pleasure, procreation
attributes.Symbols: Dove, swan, rose, myrtle, scallop shell, mirror, girdle
attributes.Sacred Plants: Rose, myrtle, apple, pomegranate, lime tree
attributes.Colors: Pink, rose gold, pearl white, sea foam green

myths.title: Birth from the Sea
myths.content: According to Hesiod, when Kronos castrated his father Uranus and cast the genitals into the sea, Aphrodite emerged from the resulting foam near Cyprus. She floated ashore on a scallop shell, fully grown and radiantly beautiful.

myths.title: The Judgment of Paris
myths.content: When Eris threw a golden apple inscribed "to the fairest" among the goddesses, Aphrodite, Hera, and Athena each claimed it. Paris, prince of Troy, was chosen to judge. Aphrodite promised him the love of the most beautiful mortal woman, Helen of Sparta. Paris awarded her the apple, leading to the Trojan War when he abducted Helen.

myths.title: Aphrodite and Ares
myths.content: Though married to Hephaestus, Aphrodite had a passionate affair with Ares, god of war. When Hephaestus discovered their affair, he crafted an invisible net and trapped them in the act, summoning the other gods to witness their shame.

myths.title: Adonis
myths.content: Aphrodite fell deeply in love with the beautiful mortal Adonis. When he was killed by a wild boar (sent by the jealous Ares or Artemis in various versions), Aphrodite's tears and his blood created the anemone flower. Zeus allowed Adonis to spend part of each year with Aphrodite.

family.Parents: Born from Uranus's severed genitals and sea foam (Hesiod), or daughter of Zeus and Dione (Homer)
family.Lovers: Ares (most famous), Adonis, Anchises, Hermes, Poseidon, Dionysus
family.Children: Eros (Cupid), Harmonia, Phobos, Deimos (by Ares), Aeneas (by Anchises), Hermaphroditus (by Hermes), Priapus (by Dionysus)

worship.sacredSites: Aphrodite's primary cult centers were on Cyprus (especially Paphos, where she was said to have come ashore) and Cythera. Major temples also existed at Corinth (where temple prostitution was practiced), Athens, and throughout the Greek world. Her sanctuaries were often near the sea or in gardens.
festivals: Aphrodisia: Celebrated throughout Greece in midsummer, honoring Aphrodite with processions, offerings of flowers, and private celebrations of love and beauty.
Adonia: Women-only festival mourning Adonis and celebrating his resurrection, featuring gardens planted in his honor that quickly bloomed and withered.
worship.offerings: Worshippers offered flowers (especially roses and myrtle), perfumes, incense, doves, and personal items of beauty. Her altars received garlands and wreaths. Unlike gods receiving blood sacrifices, offerings to Aphrodite emphasized beauty, fragrance, and sensual pleasure.

sources: Hesiod's Theogony, Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, Homeric Hymn to Aphrodite, Ovid's Metamorphoses, Apollodorus's Bibliotheca

name: Apollo
subtitle: God of Light, Music, Prophecy, and Healing
description: The most Greek of gods, Apollo embodies the ideals of kouros (beautiful youth), artistic excellence, rational thought, and divine order. As sun god, prophet, healer, and musician, he represents the civilized arts that elevate humanity above mere survival.

attributes.Titles: Phoebus Apollo (Bright), Musagetes (Leader of Muses), Paean (Healer), Pythian (of Delphi)
attributes.Domains: Sun/light, music, poetry, prophecy, healing, plague, archery, truth, order
attributes.Symbols: Lyre, silver bow and arrows, laurel wreath, tripod, raven, swan
attributes.Sacred Animals: Swan, raven, crow, dolphin, wolf, mouse, snake

myths.title: Slaying of Python
myths.content: Shortly after birth, the infant Apollo sought to avenge his mother Leto, whom the she-dragon Python had persecuted at Hera's command. Apollo tracked Python to Mount Parnassus and slew the serpent with his silver arrows. On this site he established his greatest oracle at Delphi, where the Pythia (priestess) would deliver his prophecies. Apollo served nine years of servitude to atone for the killing, even though Python was monstrous. This myth establishes Delphi's sanctity and Apollo's role as prophet.

myths.title: Daphne and the Laurel
myths.content: After mocking Eros's archery, Apollo was struck by a golden arrow causing him to fall in love with the nymph Daphne, while Daphne was struck by a lead arrow causing her to flee from love. Apollo pursued her relentlessly until, exhausted, Daphne prayed to her father the river god for escape. She was transformed into a laurel tree just as Apollo reached her. Heartbroken, Apollo declared the laurel his sacred tree, wearing its leaves as a crown and awarding laurel wreaths to victors in the Pythian Games.

myths.title: Contest with Marsyas
myths.content: The satyr Marsyas found Athena's discarded aulos (double flute) and became supremely skilled, eventually challenging Apollo to a music contest. The Muses judged Apollo's lyre superior. As punishment for hubris, Apollo flayed Marsyas aliveâ€”a brutal reminder that mortals must not challenge divine supremacy. This myth contrasts the civilized lyre with the wild, orgiastic aulos, and warns against pride.

family.Parents: Zeus (king of gods) and Leto (Titaness)
family.Consort(s): Never married; numerous lovers including Daphne (transformed to laurel), Cassandra (priestess of Troy), Coronis (mother of Asclepius), Cyrene (mother of Aristaeus), Hyacinthus (Spartan prince)
family.Children: Asclepius (god of medicine, from Coronis), Aristaeus (rustic god, from Cyrene), Orpheus (legendary musician, possibly Apollo's son), Ion (ancestor of Ionians), and various others
family.Siblings: Artemis (twin sister, born just before Apollo), plus all Zeus's other children including Athena, Hermes, Dionysus, Ares

worship.sacredSites: Delphi, on the slopes of Mount Parnassus, housed Apollo's most famous oracle and was considered the omphalos (navel/center) of the world. Pilgrims from across the Mediterranean sought the Pythia's prophecies, delivered in trance states over volcanic vapors. The sanctuary at Delos, Apollo's birthplace, was a sacred island where no one could be born or die. Major temples also stood at Didyma (with its own oracle), Claros, Delphinion at Athens, and numerous cities that claimed Apollo as patron. The Pythian Games at Delphi, second only to the Olympics, featured musical and athletic contests.
festivals: Pythian Games: Held every four years at Delphi to commemorate Apollo's slaying of Python. Featured musical competitions (especially lyre and aulos), poetry, drama, and athletic contests. Winners received laurel crowns from Apollo's sacred tree.

Thargelia: Athens's major Apollo festival in late spring, celebrating his birth. Included purification rites, singing of paeans (hymns to Apollo), offerings of first fruits, and the pharmakoi ritual (scapegoat expulsion). Also honored Apollo Patroos (ancestral Apollo).
worship.offerings: Apollo received libations of wine and honey, offerings of first fruits from harvest, and sacrifices of unblemished white animals (sheep, goats, cattle). Musicians dedicated their lyres and poets their works. Athletes and warriors offered victory spoils. At Delphi, petitioners paid hefty fees for prophecies. Laurel leaves were burned as incense. Temples displayed golden tripods, lyres, and arrows as votive offerings. The sick seeking healing left anatomical votives representing the body parts they wished cured.

sources: Homeric Hymn to Apollo, Homer's Iliad, Ovid's Metamorphoses, Pausanias's Description of Greece, Apollodorus's Bibliotheca, Euripides's plays, Delphic oracle traditions

name: Ares
subtitle: God of War, Bloodlust, and Violence
description: The fierce god of war in its brutal aspect - bloodshed, violence, and the chaos of battle. Unlike Athena who represents strategic warfare, Ares embodies raw physical aggression and the savage thrill of combat.

attributes.Titles: God of War, Bane of Mortals, Insatiable in Battle, Shield-Piercer
attributes.Domains: War, battle, bloodlust, violence, courage, civil order
attributes.Symbols: Spear, sword, shield, helmet, chariot, vulture, dog
attributes.Sacred Animals: Vulture, dog, serpent, barn owl, woodpecker

myths.title: Ares and Aphrodite
myths.content: Though Aphrodite was married to Hephaestus, she carried on a passionate affair with Ares. When Hephaestus learned of their adultery, he forged an invisible net and trapped them together in bed, then summoned the gods to witness their shame.

myths.title: Humbled by Heracles
myths.content: During the Trojan War and other conflicts, Ares frequently supported one side but was often wounded or defeated. Heracles twice wounded him in battle, causing Ares to flee to Olympus in pain.

myths.title: Imprisoned by the Aloadae
myths.content: The giant twin brothers Otus and Ephialtes captured Ares and imprisoned him in a bronze jar for thirteen months. He would have perished had not Hermes discovered and freed him.

myths.title: The Areopagus
myths.content: When Ares's son was killed, Ares slew the murderer and was put on trial by the gods. He was acquitted, and the Hill of Ares (Areopagus) in Athens was named after him and became the site of the Athenian homicide court.

family.Parents: Zeus and Hera
family.Children: Phobos (Fear), Deimos (Terror), Harmonia, the Amazons (various daughters), Eros (in some traditions)
family.Siblings: Hephaestus, Hebe, Eileithyia, and half-siblings including Athena, Apollo, Artemis, Hermes

worship.sacredSites: Unlike other Olympians, Ares had relatively few temples in Greece, reflecting his unpopularity. Sparta honored him more than other cities, as befits a warrior culture. Thebes also had an important cult of Ares. His primary worship occurred in Thrace, considered his homeland.
worship.offerings: Warriors dedicated armor and weapons from defeated enemies to Ares. Dogs and boars were sacrificed before battle. In Sparta, captured armor was hung in his temple. Blood offerings were common, befitting the god of bloodshed.

sources: Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, Hesiod's Theogony, Ovid's Metamorphoses, Apollodorus's Bibliotheca

name: Artemis
subtitle: Goddess of the Hunt, Wilderness, and the Moon
description: Virgin goddess of the hunt, wild animals, and the moon. Twin sister of Apollo, Artemis roams the wilderness with her band of nymphs, protecting young creatures and punishing those who offend her.

attributes.Titles: Huntress, Maiden, Lady of Wild Things, Moon Goddess, Protector of Youth
attributes.Domains: Hunt, wilderness, wild animals, moon, childbirth, virginity, young girls
attributes.Symbols: Bow and arrows, crescent moon, deer, cypress, hunting dogs
attributes.Sacred Animals: Deer, bear, boar, hunting dog, guinea fowl

myths.title: Birth and Early Deeds
myths.content: Artemis was born on the island of Delos, twin to Apollo. According to some accounts, she was born first and helped her mother Leto deliver Apollo. As a young girl, she asked Zeus for eternal virginity and dominion over the wilderness.

myths.title: Actaeon
myths.content: The hunter Actaeon accidentally saw Artemis bathing naked in a stream. As punishment for violating her privacy, she transformed him into a stag, and his own hunting dogs tore him apart.

myths.title: Niobe
myths.content: When the mortal queen Niobe boasted that her fourteen children made her superior to Leto (who had only two), Artemis and Apollo slew all of Niobe's children with arrows. Artemis killed the daughters, Apollo the sons.

myths.title: Orion
myths.content: Various myths tell of Artemis's relationship with the giant hunter Orion. In some versions she loved him; in others she killed him for trying to seduce her or one of her nymphs. After his death, Zeus placed him in the stars.

myths.title: Iphigenia
myths.content: When Agamemnon killed a sacred deer and boasted he was a better hunter than Artemis, she becalmed the Greek fleet at Aulis. She demanded the sacrifice of his daughter Iphigenia, though in some versions she replaced the girl with a deer at the last moment.

family.Parents: Zeus and Leto (Titaness)
family.Half-Siblings: Numerous children of Zeus including Athena, Hermes, Dionysus, Heracles

worship.sacredSites: Artemis's most famous temple was at Ephesus (one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World). Major cult sites also existed at Brauron in Attica, Sparta (as Artemis Orthia), and throughout wilderness areas. Her shrines were often in forests, on mountains, or near springs.
festivals: Brauronia: Every four years at Brauron, young Athenian girls performed "bear dances" in saffron robes, honoring Artemis and marking transitions in girlhood.
Artemisia: Celebrated in various locations, honoring Artemis with processions and games.
worship.offerings: Hunters offered Artemis the first fruits of the hunt. Young girls dedicated their toys and childhood garments to her before marriage. Pregnant women and new mothers made offerings seeking her protection during childbirth. Goats and deer were sacrificed, and her altars received cakes shaped like animals.

sources: Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, Homeric Hymn to Artemis, Euripides' Iphigenia plays, Ovid's Metamorphoses, Apollodorus's Bibliotheca

name: Athena
subtitle: Goddess of Wisdom, Strategic Warfare, and Crafts
description: Virgin goddess of wisdom, strategic warfare, handicrafts, and reason. Born fully grown and armored from Zeus's head, Athena embodies disciplined intelligence, just warfare, and civilized arts. Patron of Athens and protector of heroes.

attributes.Titles: Pallas Athena, Athena Parthenos (Virgin), Athena Promachos (Who Fights in Front), Glaukopis (Bright-Eyed)
attributes.Domains: Wisdom, strategic warfare, crafts, weaving, reason, intelligent courage, civilization
attributes.Symbols: Aegis (shield/breastplate), spear, helmet, owl, Gorgoneion (Medusa's head)

myths.title: Birth from Zeus's Head
myths.content: Zeus swallowed his first wife Metis (Wisdom) when pregnant, fearing their child would overthrow him. When terrible headaches plagued Zeus, Hephaestus split his skull with an axe, and Athena sprang forth fully grown, clad in golden armor, and giving a mighty war cry. This birth symbolizes wisdom emerging from the mind of authority, and Athena's status as Zeus's most trusted offspring.

myths.title: Contest for Athens
myths.content: Athena and Poseidon competed to become patron deity of the greatest city in Attica. Poseidon struck the Acropolis rock with his trident, producing a salt-water spring (or horse, in some versions). Athena planted an olive tree, symbol of peace and prosperity. The citizens chose Athena's gift, and the city became Athens in her honor. The sacred olive tree on the Acropolis was tended for centuries.

myths.title: Arachne's Hubris
myths.content: The mortal weaver Arachne boasted she could weave better than Athena herself. In a weaving contest, Arachne's tapestry depicted the gods' shameful deeds, while Athena's showed the gods' majesty and mortals punished for hubris. Though Arachne's work was flawless, her insolence enraged Athena, who transformed her into a spider, doomed to weave forever. This myth warns against hubris while acknowledging craft excellence.

family.Parents: Zeus (king of gods) and Metis (Titaness of wisdom and cunning, swallowed by Zeus)
family.Consort(s): None (eternal virgin goddess)
family.Children: Erichthonius (adopted; born when Hephaestus's seed fell on Athena and was received by Gaia)
family.Siblings: Apollo, Artemis, Hermes, Dionysus, Ares, Hephaestus, and many others (half-siblings through Zeus)

worship.sacredSites: The Parthenon atop the Acropolis in Athens stands as Athena's most magnificent temple, housing Phidias's massive chryselephantine (gold and ivory) statue of Athena Parthenos. The Erechtheion nearby marked the spot where her sacred olive tree grew and where she competed with Poseidon. Other major sanctuaries existed at Sparta (Athena Chalkioikos, of the Bronze House), Tegea, and Lindos on Rhodes. The Panathenaic Way led through Athens to her temples.
festivals: Panathenaea: Athens's greatest festival, held annually with a grand celebration every four years. Featured athletic contests, musical competitions, and a procession carrying a newly woven peplos (robe) to dress Athena's statue. The Great Panathenaea rivaled the Olympic Games in grandeur.

Plynteria: Late spring festival when Athena's ancient wooden statue was ceremonially bathed, dressed in new robes, and honored with secret rites performed by women. The temple was closed to the public during this purification.
worship.offerings: Athena received offerings of olive oil (from her sacred tree), honey cakes, and bloodless sacrifices reflecting her civilized nature. Craftspeople dedicated their first works to her. Warriors offered armor and weapons after victories. Sheep and cattle were sacrificed on major festivals. Libations of wine, milk, and honey were poured. The Parthenon's treasury held votive offerings from across the Greek world.

sources: Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, Hesiod's Theogony, Homeric Hymn to Athena, Ovid's Metamorphoses (Arachne), Pausanias's Description of Greece, Apollodorus's Bibliotheca

name: Cronos - Titan Lord of Time
description: Cronos (also spelled Kronos or Cronus) was the youngest and most powerful of the twelve Titans, ruling over the Golden Age before being overthrown by his own children. As lord of time and harvest, he embodied both agricultural abundance and the inexorable passage of ages. His most notorious act - devouring his own children to prevent the prophecy of his downfall - has become one of mythology's most powerful symbols of time consuming all things.

name: Demeter
subtitle: Goddess of the Harvest, Agriculture, and Sacred Law
description: Mother goddess who presides over the grain harvest, fertility of the earth, and the cycle of life and death. Demeter's grief over her daughter's abduction created the seasons and established the Eleusinian Mysteries, the most sacred rites of ancient Greece promising hope for the afterlife.

attributes.Titles: Earth Mother, Bringer of Seasons, Lady of the Fruits, Giver of Laws, Thesmophoros (Lawgiver)
attributes.Domains: Harvest, agriculture, grain, fertility, seasons, sacred law, cycle of life and death
attributes.Symbols: Wheat sheaves, cornucopia, torch, poppy, sickle, basket
attributes.Sacred Animals: Serpent, pig, turtle dove, crane, screech owl
attributes.Colors: Golden yellow, green, brown, harvest gold

myths.title: The Rape of Persephone
myths.content: Hades, lord of the underworld, abducted Demeter's beloved daughter Persephone while she picked flowers in a meadow. Demeter, hearing her daughter's cries but unable to find her, wandered the earth for nine days and nights carrying torches, refusing nectar and ambrosia, consumed by grief. When she learned the truth - that Zeus had permitted the abduction - she withdrew her gifts from the earth.

myths.title: The First Winter
myths.content: In her grief and rage, Demeter caused all crops to fail and prevented new growth. She disguised herself as an old woman and went to Eleusis, where the king's family took her in. She would have made the infant prince Demophon immortal by anointing him with ambrosia and holding him in fire, but the queen interrupted in horror. Demeter revealed her true identity and demanded a temple be built in her honor. There she sat, refusing to let anything grow, bringing humanity to the brink of extinction by famine.

myths.title: The Compromise and the Seasons
myths.content: As mortals starved and the gods received no sacrifices, Zeus commanded Hades to return Persephone. However, Persephone had eaten pomegranate seeds in the underworld (either tricked by Hades or out of hunger), binding her to that realm. A compromise was reached: Persephone would spend part of the year with Hades as Queen of the Underworld (autumn and winter, when Demeter mourns and the earth lies barren) and part with her mother (spring and summer, when Demeter rejoices and the earth blooms).

myths.title: The Eleusinian Mysteries
myths.content: Before returning to Olympus, Demeter taught the Eleusinian princes her sacred rites. These Mysteries became the most important secret religious ceremonies in ancient Greece, promising initiates a blessed afterlife and revealing profound truths about death and rebirth. The rites were so sacred that revealing them was punishable by death, and they remained secret for nearly 2,000 years.

myths.title: Punishment of Erysichthon
myths.content: When the Thessalian king Erysichthon cut down trees in Demeter's sacred grove, even after a dryad pleaded for mercy, Demeter cursed him with insatiable hunger. He devoured all his possessions trying to satisfy the hunger, then sold his own daughter into slavery for food money. Finally, in his madness, he began to consume his own flesh.

family.Parents: Kronos (Titan of Time) and Rhea (Titaness, Mother of Gods)
family.Consort: Zeus (father of Persephone); also Iasion (mortal lover, father of Plutus)
family.Children: Persephone (by Zeus, Queen of the Underworld), Plutus (by Iasion, god of agricultural wealth), Despoina (by Poseidon, in Arcadian tradition), Arion (divine horse, by Poseidon)
family.Siblings: Zeus, Poseidon, Hades, Hera, Hestia (all swallowed and later regurgitated by Kronos)

worship.sacredSites: Eleusis, near Athens, was Demeter's primary cult center and home of the Eleusinian Mysteries. The sanctuary complex included the Telesterion (hall of initiation) where the secret rites were performed. Major temples also existed on Sicily (where Persephone was said to have been abducted), Hermione, Thebes, and throughout the Greek world. Rural shrines marked the boundaries of cultivated fields.
festivals: Eleusinian Mysteries: The greatest and most secret religious rites of ancient Greece, held annually in autumn. Lesser Mysteries in spring prepared initiates; Greater Mysteries in fall revealed sacred knowledge about death, rebirth, and the afterlife. Initiates processed from Athens to Eleusis, fasted, drank the kykeon (ritual drink), and witnessed sacred dramas revealing divine secrets.

Thesmophoria: Women-only autumn festival celebrating Demeter Thesmophoros (Lawgiver). Women left their homes, built temporary shelters, performed purification rites, and celebrated female solidarity while ensuring agricultural fertility for the coming year.
Haloa: Winter festival celebrating the threshing of grain, featuring ribald humor, cakes shaped like genitals, and women-only feasting, honoring Demeter, Persephone, and Dionysus.
Proerosia: Pre-plowing festival in autumn, asking Demeter's blessing before sowing the year's grain crop.
worship.offerings: First fruits of the harvest were always dedicated to Demeter. Offerings included grain, barley cakes, honey cakes, and libations of milk, honey, and wine. Pigs were her primary sacrificial animal, especially at the Thesmophoria (piglets were thrown into sacred pits and later retrieved, their remains mixed with seeds). Torches featured prominently in her rites, recalling her search for Persephone. Poppies were offered both for their connection to sleep/death and their growth among grain fields.

sources: Homeric Hymn to Demeter (primary source for Persephone myth), Hesiod's Theogony, Ovid's Metamorphoses, Apollodorus's Bibliotheca, Pausanias's Description of Greece

name: Dionysus
subtitle: God of Wine, Ecstasy, and Theater
description: The twice-born god of wine, revelry, and divine madness. Dionysus brings liberation through wine and ecstatic ritual, breaking down barriers between mortal and divine, civilization and nature.

attributes.Titles: Bacchus, The Twice-Born, Liberator, Ivy-Crowned, Bull-Horned
attributes.Domains: Wine, ecstasy, fertility, theater, ritual madness, vegetation
attributes.Symbols: Thyrsus (fennel staff), wine cup, grape vine, ivy crown, leopard skin
attributes.Sacred Animals: Leopard, tiger, bull, serpent, dolphin, panther
attributes.Sacred Plants: Grape vine, ivy, fig, pine cone, fennel
attributes.Colors: Purple, wine red, deep green, gold

myths.title: The Twice-Born
myths.content: Zeus fell in love with the mortal Semele. When jealous Hera tricked Semele into asking Zeus to reveal his true form, his divine radiance incinerated her. Zeus rescued the unborn Dionysus from her womb and sewed him into his thigh until the child was ready to be born.

myths.title: Journey to the East
myths.content: Dionysus traveled throughout Asia Minor and India, teaching viticulture and establishing his cult. He was accompanied by his followers, the Maenads and Satyrs, spreading divine madness and liberation.

myths.title: Pentheus and the Bacchae
myths.content: King Pentheus of Thebes refused to acknowledge Dionysus as a god and banned his worship. Dionysus drove the women of Thebes into a frenzy. Pentheus's own mother, Agave, tore him apart in her divine madness, thinking him a lion.

myths.title: Pirates and Dolphins
myths.content: When Tyrrhenian pirates kidnapped Dionysus (not recognizing him as a god), he caused vines to grow around the ship, and transformed into a lion. The terrified pirates leapt overboard and were transformed into dolphins.

family.Parents: Zeus and Semele (mortal princess of Thebes)
family.Wife: Ariadne (princess of Crete, abandoned by Theseus)
family.Children: Priapus, Hymen, various minor deities of fertility and festivity
family.Foster Parents: Raised by nymphs of Mount Nysa after his mother's death

worship.sacredSites: Dionysus was worshipped throughout Greece, with major cult centers at Thebes (his birthplace), Athens (where the theater festivals honored him), and Delphi (where he was said to reside in winter when Apollo was absent). Natural settings like mountains and forests were also sacred to him.
festivals: Dionysia: Major Athenian festival featuring theatrical performances of tragedies and comedies. Both the City Dionysia (spring) and Rural Dionysia (winter) honored the god.
Lenaia: Winter festival celebrating wine production, featuring dramatic competitions and processions.
Anthesteria: Spring festival of flowers and new wine, including a day to honor the dead.
worship.offerings: Wine libations, ivy wreaths, grape vines, and theatrical performances. Goats were sacrificed (the word "tragedy" comes from "tragos" - goat). His rituals involved music, dance, and the consumption of wine to achieve altered states of consciousness.

sources: Euripides' The Bacchae, Homeric Hymn to Dionysus, Ovid's Metamorphoses, Apollodorus's Bibliotheca, Nonnus's Dionysiaca

name: Eros
subtitle: Primordial Force of Desire and God of Love

family.Wife: Psyche (Soul), whom he married after her trials and apotheosis
family.Daughter: Hedone (Pleasure/Voluptas), born of his union with Psyche

sources: Hesiod's Theogony, Apuleius's The Golden Ass (Books 4-6, Psyche tale), Plato's Symposium, Homeric Hymn to Aphrodite, Apollonius Rhodius's Argonautica, Ovid's Metamorphoses, various lyric poetry and philosophical texts

name: Gaia
subtitle: Primordial Earth Mother, Foundation of All Life
sources: Hesiod's Theogony (primary source), Homeric Hymn to Earth, Apollodorus's Bibliotheca, Pausanias's Description of Greece, Aeschylus's Prometheus Bound, various other fragments and references

name: Hades
subtitle: Lord of the Underworld, God of the Dead
description: Ruler of the underworld and keeper of the dead, Hades is one of the three great brothers who divided the cosmos. Though feared and rarely worshipped openly, he maintains the balance between life and death, ensuring souls reach their proper destination.

attributes.Titles: Lord of the Dead, The Unseen One, Pluto (The Wealthy), Receiver of Many
attributes.Domains: Underworld, death, the dead, hidden wealth, precious metals
attributes.Symbols: Helm of darkness, bident, Cerberus, cypress, narcissus, keys

myths.title: The Division of the Cosmos
myths.content: After defeating the Titans, Zeus, Poseidon, and Hades drew lots to divide the cosmos. Zeus received the sky, Poseidon the sea, and Hades the underworld. The earth and Olympus were shared by all.

myths.title: The Abduction of Persephone
myths.content: Hades fell in love with Persephone, daughter of Demeter. With Zeus's permission but without Demeter's knowledge, he abducted her while she picked flowers. Demeter's grief caused eternal winter until Persephone was returned. However, having eaten pomegranate seeds in the underworld, Persephone must spend part of each year with Hades, creating the seasons.

myths.title: Orpheus and Eurydice
myths.content: When the musician Orpheus descended to the underworld to retrieve his dead wife Eurydice, his music moved even Hades. The god agreed to release her on one condition: Orpheus must not look back until they reached the surface. Tragically, Orpheus looked back too soon, losing Eurydice forever.

myths.title: Heracles' Twelfth Labor
myths.content: Heracles was tasked with capturing Cerberus, the three-headed guard dog of the underworld. Hades agreed to allow it, provided Heracles could subdue the beast without weapons. Heracles succeeded and later returned Cerberus to the underworld.

family.Parents: Kronos (Titan of Time) and Rhea (Titaness, Mother of Gods)
family.Consort: Persephone (Queen of the Underworld, daughter of Demeter and Zeus)
family.Siblings: Zeus, Poseidon, Hera, Demeter, Hestia
family.Children: Few or none in most traditions (the Erinyes sometimes attributed to him)

worship.sacredSites: Hades had few temples as Greeks feared to invoke his name. Most worship occurred at necropolises (cities of the dead) or at sites associated with entrances to the underworld, such as caves and deep chasms. The oracle at Epirus consulted the dead through rituals to Hades.
worship.offerings: Black animals (sheep, cattle) were sacrificed with their blood poured into the earth. Unlike offerings to Olympian gods, sacrifices to Hades were completely burned or buried rather than shared in feasts. Libations of water, wine, milk, and honey were poured for the dead. Worshippers would avert their faces during Hades' rituals.

sources: Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, Hesiod's Theogony, Homeric Hymn to Demeter, Apollodorus's Bibliotheca, Ovid's Metamorphoses

name: Hephaestus
subtitle: God of Fire, Metalworking, and Craftsmanship
description: Master smith of the gods, Hephaestus forges divine weapons, magical artifacts, and wondrous automata in his volcanic workshops. Despite his lameness and rejection, he creates objects of unparalleled beauty and power, embodying the transformative power of craftsmanship and perseverance.

attributes.Titles: The Lame God, Divine Smith, Master Craftsman, Fire-Wielder, Maker of Marvels
attributes.Domains: Fire, metalworking, craftsmanship, blacksmiths, sculpture, technology, volcanoes
attributes.Symbols: Hammer, anvil, tongs, quail, donkey, forge
attributes.Colors: Bronze, copper, fiery orange, charcoal black

myths.title: Cast from Olympus
myths.content: Two accounts exist of Hephaestus's lameness. In one version, Hera cast him from Olympus in disgust at his deformity; he fell for a day and landed on the island of Lemnos, crippled. In Homer's version, Zeus hurled him down for siding with Hera during a quarrel. Either way, his lameness became his defining characteristic alongside his skill.

myths.title: The Golden Throne
myths.content: To punish Hera for rejecting him, Hephaestus crafted a magnificent golden throne and sent it to her as a gift. When she sat upon it, invisible chains bound her fast. None of the gods could free her or convince Hephaestus to release the trap. Finally, Dionysus got Hephaestus drunk and brought him back to Olympus on a donkey, where he freed his mother in exchange for recognition and the hand of Aphrodite in marriage.

myths.title: The Invisible Net
myths.content: When Hephaestus learned of his wife Aphrodite's affair with Ares, he forged an incredibly fine, unbreakable net invisible to the eye. He placed it above his marriage bed, and when the lovers next met, the net trapped them in their adultery. Hephaestus summoned all the gods to witness their shame - though the goddesses tactfully stayed away, and some gods joked they'd gladly suffer such shame for Aphrodite's love.

myths.title: Birth of Athena
myths.content: When Zeus suffered terrible headaches after swallowing Metis, Hephaestus split the god's skull with an axe (or wedge), releasing Athena fully grown and armored - armor likely forged by Hephaestus himself from within Zeus's head.

myths.title: Creation of Pandora
myths.content: On Zeus's orders, Hephaestus molded the first woman, Pandora, from clay as punishment for Prometheus stealing fire. Hephaestus crafted her with incredible beauty and skill, while the other gods granted her various gifts - and one curse in the form of a sealed jar.

family.Parents: Hera (mother, either parthenogenetically or by Zeus)
family.Consort: Aphrodite (wife, though she was unfaithful); also associated with Aglaea (one of the Graces) in some traditions
family.Children: Erichthonius (Athenian hero, born from his seed), Thalia, Eucleia, Eupheme, Philophrosyne, Cabeiri (smithing daimones)
family.Siblings: Ares, Hebe, Eileithyia, and half-siblings including Athena, Apollo, Artemis, Hermes

worship.sacredSites: Hephaestus was worshipped primarily in industrial and volcanic regions. Athens honored him alongside Athena as patron of crafts; the Hephaisteion temple still stands in the Athenian Agora. Lemnos, where he fell from heaven, maintained major cult centers. His association with volcanoes made Mt. Etna in Sicily and volcanic islands sacred to him - said to be sites of his forges.
festivals: Hephaistia: Annual festival on Lemnos featuring torch races and athletic contests, celebrating his connection to fire and craft
Chalkeia: Joint festival with Athena in late autumn, honoring metalworkers, potters, and all craftspeople
Apaturia: Hephaestus received honors during this Athenian festival due to Erichthonius's role in Athenian mythology
worship.offerings: Craftsmen dedicated their first works and tools to Hephaestus. Offerings included worked metal objects, especially those demonstrating exceptional skill. Fire offerings were common. In Athens, a sacred fire burned perpetually in his honor. Donkeys were occasionally sacrificed, as they were his sacred animal (possibly because smiths used them to power bellows).

sources: Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, Hesiod's Theogony and Works and Days, Homeric Hymn to Hephaestus, Apollodorus's Bibliotheca

name: Hera
subtitle: Queen of the Gods, Goddess of Marriage and Family
description: Wife and sister of Zeus, Hera rules as Queen of Olympus and protector of marriage, women, and childbirth. Though her mythology is dominated by Zeus's infidelities and her vengeful responses, she represents the sacred institution of marriage and the sovereignty of divine queenship.

attributes.Titles: Queen of Heaven, Cow-Eyed (BoÃ¶pis), Hera Gamelia (of Marriage), Hera Teleia (Perfected/Fulfilled)
attributes.Domains: Marriage, women, childbirth, family, queenship, fidelity, sovereignty
attributes.Symbols: Diadem (crown), scepter, peacock, pomegranate, cow, cuckoo
attributes.Colors: Royal purple, gold, white, peacock blue

myths.title: Marriage to Zeus
myths.content: After the Titanomachy, Zeus courted Hera, who initially rejected him. Zeus transformed into a cuckoo, pretending to be cold, and Hera took pity on the bird, holding it to her breast. Zeus then resumed his true form and seduced her. Their marriage was celebrated with divine splendor, though Zeus's subsequent infidelities would define their relationship. Despite conflicts, Hera retained her position as Queen of Olympus.

myths.title: Persecution of Heracles
myths.content: When Zeus's mortal lover Alkmene bore Heracles, Hera's jealous rage manifested in lifelong persecution. She sent serpents to kill the infant (he strangled them), drove him mad to kill his family (requiring the Twelve Labors as penance), and obstructed each labor. Only after Heracles died and ascended to Olympus did Hera relent, allowing him to marry her daughter Hebe.

myths.title: The Judgment of Paris
myths.content: At Peleus and Thetis's wedding, Eris threw a golden apple marked "for the fairest." Hera, Athena, and Aphrodite each claimed it. Zeus appointed Paris of Troy to judge. Hera offered him political power and kingship over all Asia; Paris chose Aphrodite (who offered Helen), beginning the Trojan War. Hera became the Greeks' fierce patron, seeking Troy's destruction.

myths.title: Birth of Hephaestus
myths.content: In some versions, Hera birthed Hephaestus through parthenogenesis (without Zeus) to spite him for birthing Athena from his head. Finding the infant deformed, she cast him from Olympus. He landed on the island of Lemnos, and eventually returned to Olympus as the divine craftsman, though his relationship with Hera remained complex.

family.Parents: Kronos (Titan of Time) and Rhea (Titaness, Mother of Gods)
family.Consort: Zeus (husband, king of gods) - tumultuous marriage defined by his infidelities and her vengeance
family.Children: Ares (god of war), Hebe (goddess of youth), Eileithyia (goddess of childbirth), Hephaestus (disputed - some say born from Hera alone)
family.Siblings: Hestia, Demeter, Zeus, Hades, Poseidon (all swallowed and regurgitated by Kronos)

worship.sacredSites: Hera's most important sanctuary was the Heraion at Argos, one of the oldest and grandest temples in Greece, where a massive chryselephantine statue rivaled those at Athens and Olympia. The Heraion of Samos, on her legendary birthplace, housed another magnificent temple. Major sanctuaries also existed at Olympia (separate from Zeus's temple), Corinth, Sparta, and throughout the Greek world. Annual processions and festivals celebrated her divine marriage and queenship.
festivals: Heraia: Female athletic festivals held at Argos and Olympia in Hera's honor. Women competed in foot races wearing short tunics with one shoulder bare, their hair unbound. Winners received olive crowns and portions of a cow sacrificed to Hera.
Theogamia/Gamelia: Celebrated the sacred marriage (hieros gamos) of Zeus and Hera, blessing mortal marriages. Couples would invoke Hera Gamelia when marrying, seeking her protection for their union.

Tonaia: Annual ritual at Argos where Hera's statue was bathed in a sacred spring, symbolically renewing her virginity and her marriage vowsâ€”representing marriage as continual renewal rather than static state.
worship.offerings: Hera received offerings of cows (hecatombs), pomegranates (symbol of marriage and fertility), honey cakes, and libations of wine and milk. Brides offered locks of hair before marriage. Married women dedicated clothing and jewelry. Peacock feathers adorned her altars. Temples displayed votive offerings from women seeking successful childbirth, marital harmony, or vindication against unfaithful spouses. As Queen of Heaven, she received magnificent gifts befitting her status.

sources: Homer's Iliad, Hesiod's Theogony, Homeric Hymn to Hera, Apollodorus's Bibliotheca, Pausanias's Description of Greece, Ovid's Metamorphoses

name: Hermes
subtitle: Messenger of the Gods, God of Travel, Commerce, and Thieves
description: Fleet-footed messenger of the Olympian gods, Hermes is the divine herald, psychopomp, patron of travelers, merchants, thieves, and eloquence. Wearing winged sandals and carrying the herald's staff, he moves freely between worlds, guiding souls to the underworld and delivering divine messages to mortals.

attributes.Titles: Argeiphontes (Slayer of Argus), Psychopompos (Guide of Souls), Hermes Trismegistus (Thrice-Greatest), Kerdoos (The Gainful)
attributes.Domains: Messengers, travel, commerce, thieves, heraldry, eloquence, cunning, boundaries, transitions
attributes.Symbols: Caduceus (herald's staff), winged sandals (talaria), petasos (traveler's hat), tortoise, lyre

myths.title: The Infant Trickster
myths.content: On the day of his birth, Hermes escaped his cradle and stole Apollo's sacred cattle, driving them backwards to confuse trackers. To celebrate, he killed a tortoise and invented the lyre by stretching strings across its shell. When Apollo discovered the theft and confronted the infant god, Hermes charmed him with music from the lyre. Apollo forgave the theft in exchange for the instrument, and Zeus, impressed by his son's cleverness, appointed Hermes as divine messenger.

myths.title: Slayer of Argus
myths.content: When Hera set the hundred-eyed giant Argus to guard Io (one of Zeus's lovers transformed into a cow), Zeus commanded Hermes to free her. Hermes disguised himself as a shepherd and lulled all hundred eyes to sleep with music and storytelling, then swiftly beheaded Argus. From this deed came the epithet Argeiphontes (Slayer of Argus). Hera honored her servant by placing his hundred eyes on the peacock's tail.

myths.title: The Infant Dionysus
myths.content: After Dionysus's mortal mother Semele was destroyed by Zeus's divine glory, Hermes rescued the premature infant from her ashes and delivered him to be sewn into Zeus's thigh until ready for birth. Later, Hermes spirited the twice-born god to the nymphs of Nysa to protect him from Hera's wrath.

family.Parents: Zeus (king of gods) and Maia (Titaness, daughter of Atlas)
family.Consort(s): Aphrodite (secretly), Peitho (goddess of persuasion), various mortal lovers
family.Children: Hermaphroditus (with Aphrodite), Pan (goat-legged nature god), Autolycus (master thief), and numerous others
family.Siblings: Apollo (close relationship despite cattle theft), Athena, Artemis, Dionysus, Ares, and all other children of Zeus

worship.sacredSites: Hermes was worshipped throughout Greece, particularly at crossroads and boundaries. Herms (stone pillars topped with his head and adorned with a phallus) marked roads, property boundaries, and city gates across the Greek world. Major sanctuaries stood on Mount Cyllene in Arcadia (his birthplace) and in the gymnasium and agora of every Greek city, where he presided over commerce and athletic training.
festivals: Hermaea: Festivals honoring Hermes featured athletic contests, particularly foot races celebrating his legendary speed.
Daily Honors: Travelers and merchants made offerings at herms before journeys and business dealings.
worship.offerings: Hermes received offerings of honey cakes, wine, and incense at herms and crossroads. Merchants dedicated a portion of profits to him. Travelers left shoes, staffs, and small tokens asking for safe passage. Young men offered locks of hair when entering adulthood. Libations were poured before important speeches, invoking his gift of eloquence.

sources: Homeric Hymn to Hermes, Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, Apollodorus's Bibliotheca, Pausanias's Description of Greece, Ovid's Metamorphoses

name: Hestia
subtitle: Virgin Goddess of the Hearth, Home, and Sacred Fire

family.Parents: Cronus (Titan king) and Rhea (Titaness, Mother of Gods)
family.Siblings: Zeus, Hera, Demeter, Poseidon, Hades
family.Status: Eternal virgin by sacred oathâ€”no consort, no children

sources: Homeric Hymn to Hestia (Hymns 24 and 29), Hesiod's Theogony, Apollodorus's Bibliotheca, Pausanias's Description of Greece, various philosophical texts (particularly Neoplatonists), scattered references throughout Greek literature

name: Persephone
subtitle: Queen of the Underworld, Goddess of Spring and Vegetation
description: Daughter of Demeter and Zeus, Persephone embodies the cycle of life, death, and rebirth. Abducted by Hades to become Queen of the Underworld, she spends half the year below with the dead and half above bringing spring's renewal, creating the seasons through her eternal journey between realms.

attributes.Titles: Kore (The Maiden), Despoina (The Mistress), Queen of the Underworld, Bringer of Spring
attributes.Domains: Spring, vegetation, the dead, underworld, seasons, renewal, mystery rites
attributes.Symbols: Pomegranate, torch, flowers (especially narcissus), grain, wreath of flowers

family.Parents: Zeus (king of gods) and Demeter (goddess of harvest)
family.Consort: Hades (Lord of the Underworld, her uncle)
family.Children: Few or none in most traditions (sometimes credited as mother of the Erinyes or Zagreus in Orphic traditions)

sources: Homeric Hymn to Demeter, Ovid's Metamorphoses, Apollodorus's Bibliotheca, Pausanias's Description of Greece

name: Poseidon
subtitle: God of the Sea, Earthquakes, and Horses
description: One of the three great sons of Kronos who divided the cosmos, Poseidon commands the vast oceans, shakes the earth with his mighty trident, and created the first horses. Known as the Earth-Shaker and Lord of the Seas, he embodies the dual nature of water itself: life-giving sustenance and terrifying destruction. Sailors, fishermen, and coastal peoples throughout the ancient world honored this tempestuous deity.

attributes.Greek Titles: Petraios (of Rocks), Hippios (of Horses), Ennosigaios (Earth-Shaker), Gaieochos (Holder of the Earth), Asphalios (Steadfast)
attributes.Domains: Seas, oceans, storms, earthquakes, horses, navigation, floods, springs, coastal regions
attributes.Symbols: Trident, dolphins, horses, bull, chariot, anchor, fish, seashells
attributes.Sacred Animals: Horse, dolphin, bull, hippocampus (sea-horse), fish, ram
attributes.Colors: Sea blue, teal, ocean green, deep navy, white foam

myths.title: The Division of the World
myths.content: After the Titanomachy, Zeus, Poseidon, and Hades drew lots to divide the conquered cosmos. Zeus claimed the sky, Hades the underworld, and Poseidon received dominion over all seas, lakes, rivers, and springs. The earth and Olympus were shared by all three brothers. Though equal in divine stature, Poseidon sometimes chafed under Zeus's supreme authority.

myths.title: Rivalry with Athena over Athens
myths.content: Poseidon and Athena competed for patronage of the greatest city in Attica. Poseidon struck the Acropolis with his trident, creating a saltwater spring (or, in some versions, the first horse). Athena planted an olive tree, symbolizing peace and prosperity. The citizens judged Athena's gift more valuable, and she became the city's patron. Poseidon, furious at his loss, flooded the Attic plain before eventually accepting the outcome.

myths.title: Creation of Horses
myths.content: Poseidon is credited with creating the first horse. In some myths, he shaped it from the crashing waves to impress Demeter; in others, he brought it forth during the contest for Athens. As Hippios (of Horses), he was patron of horse-racing and equestrian arts. His own chariot was drawn by golden-maned hippocampiâ€”magnificent creatures with the forequarters of horses and serpentine fish tails.

myths.title: The Odyssey - Wrath Against Odysseus
myths.content: After Odysseus blinded Polyphemus, Poseidon's Cyclops son, the sea god pursued vengeance relentlessly. For ten years, Poseidon sent storms, shipwrecks, and disasters to prevent Odysseus from returning home to Ithaca, demonstrating his implacable grudges and absolute power over sea travel.

myths.title: The Walls of Troy
myths.content: Poseidon and Apollo were once forced to serve King Laomedon of Troy, building its legendary walls. When Laomedon refused to pay them, Poseidon sent a sea monster to ravage the land and later supported the Greeks during the Trojan War, seeking Troy's destruction.

worship.sacredSites: Poseidon was worshipped throughout the Greek world, especially in coastal cities and islands. His most famous temple stood at Cape Sounion, perched dramatically on cliffs overlooking the Aegean Sea, where sailors offered prayers for safe voyages. The sanctuary at Corinth (Isthmia) hosted the Isthmian Games in his honor. Other major cult centers included Helike (destroyed by earthquake and tsunami in 373 BCE, seen as divine punishment), Onchestos, Tainaron (with a legendary entrance to the underworld), and temples throughout the Peloponnese.
festivals: Isthmian Games: Held every two years at the Isthmus of Corinth in honor of Poseidon. One of the four pan-Hellenic games, athletes competed for crowns of pine (later wild celery). The games featured chariot racing, reflecting Poseidon's association with horses, alongside athletic contests and musical competitions.
Poseidonia: Festivals celebrated throughout Greek cities, particularly in winter when seafaring was most dangerous. Sacrifices ensured calm seas for the coming sailing season.
Poseideion: The month named after Poseidon (roughly December), when rites were performed seeking his favor for the year ahead.
worship.offerings: Sailors poured libations of wine into the sea before voyages and offered thanksgiving sacrifices upon safe return. Black bulls and stallions were particularly sacred offerings to Poseidon, sometimes drowned in the sea rather than burned on altars. Fishermen offered first catches, and coastal cities held regular processions to his shrines. Pine branches, sea salt, and water were used in purification rituals. After safe voyages, sailors dedicated votive anchors, ship models, and oars at his temples.

sources: Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, Hesiod's Theogony, Homeric Hymn to Poseidon, Apollodorus's Bibliotheca, Pausanias's Description of Greece, Ovid's Metamorphoses

name: Prometheus
subtitle: The Fire-Bringer, Champion of Humanity
description: The rebellious Titan whose name means "Forethought," Prometheus defied the will of Zeus to bring the gift of fire to humanity. His story embodies the eternal struggle between divine authority and the advancement of civilization, between tyranny and the liberation of knowledge.

attributes.Titles: Forethought, Fire-Bringer, Mankind's Benefactor, The Chained One
attributes.Domains: Forethought, craft, fire, civilization, rebellion against tyranny, prophecy
attributes.Symbols: Torch, fennel stalk, fire, chains
attributes.Sacred Plant: Fennel (Ferula communis) - the stalk that carried divine fire
attributes.Associated Concepts: Foresight, cunning intelligence, sacrifice, suffering for principle

family.Parents: Iapetus (Titan) and Clymene (Oceanid) or Themis (Titaness of Divine Law)
family.Brothers: Epimetheus ("Afterthought"), Atlas (bearer of the heavens), Menoetius (struck down by Zeus's thunderbolt)
family.Consort: Pronoia or Hesione (depending on tradition)
family.Son: Deucalion (survivor of the Great Flood, Greek equivalent of Noah)

sources: Hesiod's Theogony (lines 507-616) and Works and Days (lines 42-105), Aeschylus's Prometheus Bound, Apollodorus's Bibliotheca, Plato's Protagoras

name: Uranus
subtitle: Primordial Sky Father, First King of the Cosmos
sources: Hesiod's Theogony (primary source), Apollodorus's Bibliotheca, Hyginus's Fabulae, Cicero's De Natura Deorum, various other fragments

name: Zeus
subtitle: King of the Gods, God of Sky and Thunder
description: Supreme ruler of Mount Olympus and the Greek pantheon, Zeus commands the sky, hurls thunderbolts, and upholds cosmic justice. As father of gods and men, he embodies sovereignty, law, and divine authority.

attributes.Titles: Sky Father, Cloud Gatherer, Thunderer, Aegis-Bearer, King of Gods
attributes.Domains: Sky, thunder, lightning, law, order, justice, kingship, oaths
attributes.Symbols: Thunderbolt, eagle, oak tree, bull, aegis (shield)
attributes.Colors: Gold, royal blue, white, sky blue

myths.title: The Titanomachy
myths.content: Zeus led his siblings in a ten-year war against the Titans, overthrowing his father Kronos and establishing the Olympian order. He freed the Cyclopes and Hecatoncheires from Tartarus, who gifted him the thunderbolt, Poseidon the trident, and Hades the helm of darkness. After victory, Zeus divided the cosmos: sky for himself, sea for Poseidon, underworld for Hades.

myths.title: Birth and Concealment
myths.content: Kronos, warned that his children would overthrow him, swallowed each child at birth. Rhea saved Zeus by giving Kronos a stone wrapped in swaddling clothes, hiding the infant in a cave on Crete where he was nursed by the goat Amalthea and protected by the Kouretes, whose dancing and shield-clashing drowned his cries.

myths.title: The Gigantomachy
myths.content: After defeating the Titans, Zeus faced the Giants, monstrous sons of Gaia who sought to overthrow Olympus. Prophecy declared the Giants could only fall to a combined force of gods and mortals; thus Zeus recruited Heracles, and together they defeated the uprising, establishing Olympian supremacy.

family.Parents: Kronos (Titan of Time) and Rhea (Titaness, Mother of Gods)
family.Consort(s): Hera (official wife and Queen of Olympus), plus numerous mortal and divine lovers including Leto, Maia, Semele, DanaÃ«, Leda, Europa, Alkmene, Demeter, Metis
family.Children: By Hera: Ares, Hebe, Eileithyia, Hephaestus (disputed). By others: Athena (from Metis), Apollo and Artemis (from Leto), Hermes (from Maia), Dionysus (from Semele), Persephone (from Demeter), Perseus (from DanaÃ«), Heracles (from Alkmene), Helen and Polydeuces (from Leda), the Muses (from Mnemosyne), plus countless other heroes and demigods.
family.Siblings: Hestia, Demeter, Hera, Hades, Poseidon (all swallowed and regurgitated by Kronos)

worship.sacredSites: Zeus's most famous oracle was at Dodona in Epirus, where priestesses interpreted the rustling of sacred oak leaves. The Olympic sanctuary at Olympia housed his massive gold and ivory statue by Phidias (one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World) and hosted the Olympic Games every four years in his honor. Major temples also stood at Athens, Sparta, and throughout the Greek world. Mount Olympus itself, though rarely visited by mortals, was considered his primary dwelling.
festivals: Olympic Games: Held every four years at Olympia beginning in 776 BCE, these pan-Hellenic athletic contests honored Zeus. Athletes competed for olive wreaths and eternal glory, and a sacred truce halted all wars during the games.
Diasia: Athenian festival in early spring featuring sacrifices of sheep and pigs. Celebrated Zeus Meilichios (Zeus the Gentle), seeking his benevolence for the coming agricultural season.
worship.offerings: Zeus received the grandest sacrifices: hecatombs (literally "hundred oxen," though the number was often symbolic) of cattle and bulls, their fat and bones burned on altars while choice portions were consumed by worshippers in communal feasts. White animals were preferred. Libations of wine accompanied prayers. Oaths were sworn in Zeus's name with dire consequences for oath-breakers. Suppliant branches were laid at his altars when seeking protection or justice.

sources: Homer's Iliad and Odyssey, Hesiod's Theogony and Works and Days, Homeric Hymn to Zeus, Apollodorus's Bibliotheca, Pausanias's Description of Greece

name: Brahma
description: The divine architect who creates the universe at the beginning of each cosmic cycle, bringing forth all worlds, beings, and sacred knowledge from the primordial waters of creation.

attributes.Titles: Prajapati (Lord of Creatures), Vedanatha (Lord of Vedas), Chaturmukha (Four-Faced)
attributes.Domains: Creation, Knowledge, Time, Sacred Speech, Arts
attributes.Symbols: Lotus, Four Vedas, Kamandalu (water pot), Prayer beads, Sruva (ladle)
attributes.Colors: Red, Gold, White - representing creation, knowledge, and purity

myths.title: Birth from the Golden Egg
myths.content: At the beginning of creation, a golden egg (Hiranyagarbha) floated in the cosmic waters. After a thousand years, Brahma emerged from the egg and split it in two, creating heaven and earth. He then meditated to bring forth the material world, gods, demons, and all living beings.

myths.title: The Fifth Head
myths.content: Originally, Brahma had five heads. When he became infatuated with his own creation, Shatarupa, and gazed at her inappropriately, Shiva became angry at this impropriety and cut off his fifth head with his trident. This is why Brahma now has four heads and why he is rarely worshipped - cursed by Shiva for his arrogance.

myths.title: The Race with Vishnu
myths.content: Brahma and Vishnu once argued about who was supreme. A massive pillar of fire (Shiva's lingam) appeared before them. They agreed whoever found its end would be greater. Vishnu dove down as a boar, Brahma flew up as a swan. After searching in vain, Vishnu admitted defeat honestly, but Brahma lied, claiming he found the top. Shiva appeared and cursed Brahma to have no temples for his dishonesty.

family.Parents: Self-born from Hiranyagarbha or born from Vishnu's navel lotus
family.Consort: Saraswati (Goddess of Knowledge, Arts, and Wisdom)
family.Children: The Prajapatis (lords of creatures), Manu (first man), Four Kumaras (mind-born sons), Daksha, Narada
family.Siblings: None (self-created), though part of Trimurti with Vishnu and Shiva

festivals: Kartik Purnima: Full moon in Kartik month (October-November), celebrated especially at Pushkar with a grand fair and ritual bathing in Pushkar Lake.
Vasant Panchami: While primarily dedicated to Saraswati, honors Brahma as lord of knowledge and learning.
worship.offerings: White flowers (especially lotus), fruits, milk, ghee, honey, and white sweets. Offerings of sacred texts, books, and writing implements. Vedic chants and hymns from the four Vedas. Water from the Pushkar lake is particularly sacred.

sources: Rigveda (Hymn of Creation - Nasadiya Sukta), Brahma Purana, Shiva Purana, Mahabharata, Manusmriti

name: Dhanvantari
description: Dhanvantari is the divine physician and god of Ayurveda, who emerged from the churning of the cosmic ocean holding the pot of amrita (nectar of immortality).

name: Durga
description: The fierce warrior goddess born from the combined energies of all the gods to defeat the buffalo demon. She rides a lion, wields weapons in her ten arms, and represents the divine feminine power (Shakti) that protects dharma and destroys evil.

attributes.Titles: Mahishasura-Mardini (Slayer of Mahishasura), Durgatinashini (Remover of Difficulties), Shakti (Divine Power), Devi (The Goddess)
attributes.Domains: Protection, Warfare, Motherhood, Feminine Power, Victory over Evil, Courage
attributes.Symbols: Trishula (trident), Chakra (discus), Bow and Arrows, Sword, Lotus, Conch Shell
attributes.Sacred Animals: Lion (or Tiger) - her vahana, representing courage and royalty
attributes.Sacred Plants: Bilva leaves, Red Hibiscus, Lotus, Durva grass, Banana plant

festivals: Navaratri/Durga Puja: Nine nights celebrating Durga's victory over Mahishasura (September-October). Especially grand in Bengal, Odisha, and Assam. The tenth day, Vijayadashami/Dussehra, celebrates her final victory.
Chaitra Navaratri: Spring celebration of the goddess (March-April), less prominent than autumn Navaratri but equally sacred.
Durga Ashtami: The eighth day of Navaratri, when the battle reached its climax.

name: Dyaus Pita
description: Dyaus Pita is the ancient Vedic sky father deity, consort of Prithvi (Earth Mother).

name: Ganesha
description: The beloved elephant-headed god who is invoked at the start of all new ventures, journeys, and sacred rituals. As the guardian of thresholds and the master of intellect, Ganesha clears the path for success while embodying wisdom, arts, and auspicious beginnings.

attributes.Sanskrit Titles: Ganapati (Lord of the Ganas), Vinayaka (Supreme Leader), Vighnaharta (Remover of Obstacles), Ekadanta (Single-Tusked), Lambodara (Pot-Bellied)
attributes.Domains: Wisdom, Success, New Beginnings, Intellect, Arts, Writing, Learning, Prosperity, Removal of Obstacles
attributes.Symbols: Broken Tusk, Modaka (sweet), Ankusha (elephant goad), Pasha (noose), Axe, Lotus
attributes.Sacred Animals: Mushika (mouse/shrew - his vahana), Elephant (his head represents cosmic wisdom)
attributes.Sacred Plants: Durva grass, Red flowers, Hibiscus, Eranda (castor plant)

myths.title: The Birth of Ganesha
myths.content: According to the most popular account in the Shiva Purana, Parvati created Ganesha from the sandalwood paste she used for her bath, breathing life into the figure to guard her privacy while she bathed. When Shiva returned and found a young boy barring his entry, the two clashed. Not recognizing the boy as his son, Shiva severed his head in anger. Upon discovering the truth, Parvati was devastated. To restore his son, Shiva sent his ganas to bring the head of the first creature they encountered facing north - an elephant. Thus Ganesha was reborn with an elephant head, symbolizing wisdom, foresight, and the ability to see beyond obstacles.

myths.title: The Broken Tusk - Ekadanta
myths.content: There are several accounts of how Ganesha lost his tusk. In the most celebrated version, the sage Vyasa approached Ganesha to transcribe the great epic Mahabharata as he dictated it. The task was immense, and Ganesha agreed on the condition that Vyasa never pause. When his writing instrument broke, Ganesha broke off his own tusk to continue writing without interruption, demonstrating his dedication to knowledge and the preservation of sacred texts. In another version, he threw his broken tusk at the moon for laughing at him, which is why the moon waxes and wanes.

myths.title: The Race Around the World
myths.content: Once, Shiva and Parvati challenged their sons Ganesha and Kartikeya to a race around the world. Kartikeya immediately mounted his peacock and flew around the globe. Ganesha, with his humble mouse vehicle, simply walked around his parents, explaining that they represented his entire world. Pleased by his wisdom, Shiva and Parvati declared him the winner, symbolizing that true knowledge lies in understanding what is most important.

myths.title: Guardian of Thresholds
myths.content: Ganesha's original role guarding his mother's door established him as the lord of all thresholds - physical, spiritual, and psychological. He stands at the boundary between the known and unknown, the mundane and sacred, helping devotees transition safely between states. This is why he is invoked first in all Hindu ceremonies, weddings, and new undertakings.

family.Father: Shiva - The Destroyer/Transformer of the Trimurti
family.Mother: Parvati/Uma - The Divine Mother, Shakti personified
family.Brother: Kartikeya/Skanda/Murugan - God of War, Commander of the Divine Armies
family.Consorts: Siddhi (Achievement/Spiritual Power), Buddhi (Wisdom/Intellect), Riddhi (Prosperity) - in some traditions
family.Sons: Kshema (Prosperity) and Labha (Profit) - in some Puranic accounts

festivals: Ganesh Chaturthi: The most important Ganesha festival, celebrating his birth. Lasting 10 days (typically August-September), devotees install clay idols of Ganesha in homes and public spaces, worship them with offerings and prayers, and on the final day immerse the idols in water (visarjan) symbolizing his return to Mount Kailash. This festival, particularly grand in Maharashtra, was popularized by Bal Gangadhar Tilak as a way to unite communities.
Sankashti Chaturthi: Monthly observance on the fourth day after full moon, dedicated to Ganesha. Devotees fast during the day and break their fast after sighting the moon.
Vinayaka Chavithi: Celebrated across South India with special prayers, offerings, and community gatherings.
worship.offerings: Modaka (sweet dumplings) are Ganesha's favorite offering, symbolizing the sweetness of the liberated soul. Other offerings include: durva grass (21 blades), red flowers (especially hibiscus), coconut, jaggery, bananas, and ladoos (sweet balls). Red sandalwood paste is applied to his image. Unlike most deities, Ganesha accepts food offerings with a broken coconut.

sources: Shiva Purana, Ganesha Purana, Mudgala Purana, Mahabharata, Brahmanda Purana

name: Hanuman
description: The divine vanara (monkey) warrior and supreme devotee of Rama, embodying perfect devotion, courage, strength, and selfless service. Born as the son of the wind god Vayu, Hanuman possesses supernatural powers including flight, shape-shifting, and immense strength. His unwavering dedication to Rama and his heroic exploits in the Ramayana make him one of the most beloved deities in Hinduism - the living symbol of bhakti (devotion) and the power that comes from complete surrender to the divine.

attributes.Sanskrit Titles: Anjaneya (Son of Anjana), Maruti (Son of Maruta/Vayu), Bajrangbali (One with Limbs Strong as Vajra/Thunderbolt), Kesari Nandan (Son of Kesari), Sankat Mochan (Remover of Difficulties), Mahavira (Great Hero), Pawanputra (Son of Wind)
attributes.Domains: Devotion (Bhakti), Strength, Courage, Loyalty, Service, Celibacy (Brahmacharya), Protection, Wisdom, Humility, Removal of Obstacles
attributes.Symbols: Mace (gada), Mountain (carried to Lanka), Rama's image on his chest (eternal devotion), Orange/red color, Flying/leaping pose
attributes.Powers: Flight, Superhuman strength, Size alteration (can become tiny or gigantic), Shape-shifting, Immortality, Invulnerability, Speed (faster than wind)
attributes.Sacred Plants: Sanjeevani herb (brought from Himalayas), Tulsi (holy basil), Betel leaves
attributes.Colors: Orange-red (devotion and strength), Golden (when depicted in powerful forms)

myths.title: Divine Birth
myths.content: Hanuman was born to Anjana (an apsara cursed to be born as a vanara) and Kesari (a vanara king), but his true father was Vayu, the wind god. When Anjana prayed intensely to Shiva for a child, the wind god Vayu carried the divine essence to her womb. Thus Hanuman is considered an avatar or son of Shiva in some traditions, and son of Vayu in all traditions. He was born with incredible strength and supernatural abilities, an auspicious birth foretold to be crucial for dharma's victory.

myths.title: Swallowing the Sun
myths.content: As a child, Hanuman was mischievous and unaware of his divine nature. Seeing the rising sun, he mistook it for a ripe fruit and leaped into the sky to eat it. Indra, seeing this threat to cosmic order, struck the child with his thunderbolt, injuring Hanuman's jaw (hence his name, which can mean "one with a broken jaw"). Enraged, Vayu withdrew all air from the world, suffocating all beings. The gods quickly apologized and granted young Hanuman numerous boons: immortality from Brahma, invulnerability in battle from Indra, and various powers from other deities. However, due to his mischief, he was cursed to forget his powers until reminded of them at the right time.

myths.title: Meeting Rama - The Purpose Revealed
myths.content: When Rama and Lakshmana searched for the abducted Sita, they met Hanuman on Mount Rishyamukha. The moment Hanuman beheld Rama, his life found its purpose. He instantly recognized him as his lord and master, and devoted himself completely to Rama's service. This meeting represents the soul (Hanuman) recognizing the divine (Rama) and surrendering completely. From this moment, Hanuman existed only to serve Rama, finding in this service his ultimate fulfillment.

myths.title: The Leap to Lanka
myths.content: When no one could cross the vast ocean to Lanka to find Sita, the vanaras despaired. Jambavan reminded Hanuman of his forgotten powers. Suddenly remembering his divine strength, Hanuman grew to enormous size and leaped across the ocean in one mighty bound - a distance of 100 yojanas (about 800 miles). This leap is one of the most iconic images in Hindu iconography, symbolizing the power that comes when one acts in service of the divine. During his flight, he was tested by various beings but overcame all obstacles through wit and strength.

myths.title: Finding Sita - The Perfect Messenger
myths.content: In Lanka, Hanuman made himself tiny to search undetected. He found Sita in the Ashoka grove, gave her Rama's ring as proof, and offered to carry her back. But Sita refused - she wanted Rama himself to rescue her and defeat Ravana, upholding dharma. Hanuman understood this wisdom perfectly. His role was not to solve the problem himself, but to serve Rama's larger purpose. This demonstrates perfect devotion - knowing when to act and when to step back, having no ego about being the hero.

myths.title: Burning of Lanka
myths.content: Before leaving, Hanuman allowed himself to be captured to meet Ravana. When the demons tied his tail with oil-soaked cloth and set it on fire, he broke free, made his tail grow enormously long, and used it to set fire to the golden city of Lanka, burning it down except for Sita's location. This act demonstrated his power and delivered a warning to Ravana of the destruction to come. The burning tail became another iconic image of Hanuman's might.

myths.title: Bringing the Sanjeevani Mountain
myths.content: During the great battle, when Lakshmana lay near death from an arrow, the only cure was the Sanjeevani herb from the Himalayas. Hanuman flew to the mountain, but unable to identify which herb it was in the darkness, he uprooted the entire mountain and carried it to Lanka. This extraordinary feat - carrying a mountain through the air across India - shows that for true devotion, nothing is impossible. His practical solution also demonstrates wisdom: when in doubt, bring everything needed.

myths.title: Rama in the Heart
myths.content: After Sita's rescue, when Sita gave Hanuman a pearl necklace as thanks, he broke it apart, examining each pearl. When asked what he was doing, he said he was looking for Rama - anything without Rama's name had no value to him. Some doubted his devotion, so Hanuman tore open his chest to reveal Rama and Sita literally inscribed on his heart. This is the ultimate image of bhakti - the beloved lord residing permanently in the devotee's heart.

myths.title: The Immortal Chiranjivi
myths.content: When the time came for Rama to leave his earthly form, Hanuman was overcome with grief. Rama blessed him to remain on earth for the entire Kali Yuga (current age), living wherever the Ramayana is sung and Rama's name is chanted. Thus Hanuman is considered a Chiranjivi (immortal being), and devotees believe he is invisibly present whenever his name or Rama's name is spoken with devotion.

myths.title: Meeting Krishna
myths.content: In the Mahabharata, when Bhima (another son of Vayu) tried to move what appeared to be an old monkey's tail blocking his path, he couldn't budge it. The old monkey revealed himself as Hanuman and blessed Bhima. Later, during the great war, Hanuman resided on Arjuna's chariot flag at Krishna's request, his roar terrifying enemies and protecting the Pandavas. This shows Hanuman serving both major avatars of Vishnu - Rama and Krishna.

family.Mother: Anjana - An apsara who was cursed to be born as a vanara
family.Divine Father: Vayu - God of wind, granting him speed and flight
