family.Lord and Master: Rama - His entire existence is devoted to Rama's service
family.Relationship with Sita: He is her devoted servant and protector, treating her as the divine mother
family.Brother: Bhima (both are sons of Vayu, though from different mothers)
family.Connection to Shiva: Considered an avatar or aspect of Shiva in some traditions

festivals: Hanuman Jayanti: Birthday celebration on the full moon of Chaitra month (March-April). Devotees fast, recite Hanuman Chalisa, and visit temples.
Ram Navami: Also celebrated as Hanuman's birth according to some traditions.
Every Tuesday: Special Hanuman worship day throughout the year.
worship.offerings: Red flowers (especially hibiscus), red cloth, Sindoor (vermillion - devotees smear it on his image and themselves for his blessings), Ladoos (sweet balls), Bananas, Besan ladoo (chickpea flour sweets), coconut, and sesame oil. Physical exercise, wrestling, and martial arts practice are also considered forms of worship, as is reading the Ramayana.

sources: Valmiki Ramayana, Tulsidas' Ramcharitmanas, Mahabharata, Hanuman Chalisa, Various Puranas

name: Indra
description: Indra is the king of the devas and lord of Svarga (heaven), wielding the vajra (thunderbolt) and commanding the rain and storms. A mighty warrior who defeated the demon Vritra to release the cosmic waters, Indra represents kingship, martial prowess, and the power of the storm.

attributes.Titles: Shakra (Mighty One), Devendra (Lord of Gods), Vajrapani (Wielder of Vajra), Meghavahana (Rider of Clouds)
attributes.Domains: Thunder, Lightning, Rain, War, Heaven, Kingship
attributes.Symbols: Vajra (thunderbolt weapon), Bow and arrows, Rainbow

myths.title: Slaying of Vritra
myths.content: When the demon Vritra enclosed the waters of the world, causing terrible drought, Indra consumed vast amounts of soma (divine nectar) to empower himself. With his vajra crafted by Tvashtri, he struck down Vritra and released the waters, making him the cosmic victor and savior of the world.

myths.title: The Thousand Eyes
myths.content: After committing brahmahatya (killing a brahmin - referring to Vritra who was technically the son of a sage), Indra was cursed. His body became covered with a thousand eyes as a mark of his sin, though later these were transformed into beautiful eyes across his body.

myths.title: Humbled by Krishna
myths.content: In later mythology, when Indra sent torrential rains to punish the people of Vrindavan for worshipping Krishna instead of him, young Krishna lifted Mount Govardhan on his little finger for seven days to shelter them, teaching Indra humility.

family.Parents: Son of Dyaus (Sky Father) and Prithvi (Earth Mother) in some accounts; son of Aditi in others
family.Consort: Shachi (also called Indrani), goddess of jealousy and beauty
family.Children: Jayanta (warrior son), Jayanti (daughter), Chitragupta (recorder of karma in some traditions)

worship.sacredSites: Indra has fewer dedicated temples in modern Hinduism compared to his prominence in Vedic times, though he remains important in ritual contexts.
worship.offerings: Soma (sacred drink), ghee, offerings to fire (through Agni as intermediary)

sources: Rigveda, Atharvaveda, Mahabharata, Ramayana, Puranas

name: Kali
description: The most fearsome and powerful form of the Divine Mother, Kali is the goddess who dances on corpses, wears a garland of skulls, and drinks the blood of demons. Yet paradoxically, she is also the ultimate liberator - the loving mother who destroys the ego and illusion to free souls from the cycle of rebirth. Dark as the night, tongue dripping blood, four-armed and wild-eyed, she represents time itself (Kala), which devours all things. Her fierce form terrifies the wicked but protects devoted children with boundless maternal love. She is Parvati's most intense manifestation, the raw power of Shakti unleashed for cosmic transformation.

attributes.Sanskrit Titles: Kalika (The Black One), Mahakali (The Great Kali), Bhavatarini (Redeemer of the Universe), Adya Kali (The Primordial Kali), Dakshina Kali (Benevolent Form), Chamunda (Destroyer of Chanda and Munda demons)
attributes.Domains: Time, Death, Destruction, Transformation, Liberation (Moksha), Dissolution of Ego, Protection, Tantric Power, Ultimate Reality Beyond Form
attributes.Symbols: Severed head, Sword (Khadga), Skull bowl (Kapala), Garland of skulls, Blood, Tongue protruding, Dark skin, Corpses, Cremation grounds
attributes.Sacred Places: Kalighat (Kolkata - one of 51 Shakti Peethas), Dakshineswar Temple, Cremation grounds (she dwells where death is present)
attributes.Offerings: Red hibiscus, Meat and fish (in certain Tantric traditions), Alcohol (representing transformed poison), Blood substitutes
attributes.Colors: Black/Dark blue (primordial void, infinite time), Red (blood, energy, transformation)

myths.title: Emergence from Durga
myths.content: The most famous origin story comes from the Devi Mahatmya. During the battle with demons, the asuras Chanda and Munda attacked Durga. In her fury, she knit her brows and from her forehead emerged Kali - black as night, with a lolling tongue, hollow eyes, and carrying a skull-topped staff. She instantly devoured the demon army, crushing skulls with her teeth and drinking their blood. After destroying Chanda and Munda, she earned the name Chamunda. This shows Kali as the ultimate destructive aspect that emerges when evil becomes intolerable.

myths.title: The Battle with Raktabija
myths.content: The demon Raktabija had a boon that whenever a drop of his blood touched the earth, a new demon identical to him would spring up. As Durga fought him, thousands of Raktabijas multiplied from his spilled blood, threatening to overwhelm the gods. Durga summoned Kali, who spread her tongue across the battlefield like a carpet, catching every drop of blood before it hit the ground and drinking it. Meanwhile, she devoured all the duplicate demons. Her blood-drinking is not vampirism but a cosmic function - preventing the multiplication of evil, consuming negativity before it can reproduce. This story explains her protruding tongue, one of her most distinctive features.

myths.title: The Dance of Destruction (Tandava)
myths.content: After slaughtering all the demons, Kali became intoxicated with bloodlust and began her terrible dance of destruction, the Tandava, dancing wildly on the battlefield littered with corpses. The earth shook, the cosmos trembled, and it seemed she would destroy everything in her fury. The gods despaired. Hoping to stop her, Shiva lay down among the corpses. When Kali stepped on him, she suddenly recognized her beloved husband. Shocked at what she had done, she bit her tongue in shame (another explanation for her protruding tongue), and the destruction ceased. This famous image - Kali standing on Shiva's chest - represents multiple profound teachings: that Shakti (power/energy) standing on Shiva (consciousness) creates and destroys the world; that unlimited power must be tempered by consciousness and love; that even the fiercest divinity responds to devotion; that the active feminine principle animates the passive masculine principle.

myths.title: Kali and Shiva's Relationship
myths.content: Unlike other goddesses who are consorts to their male counterparts, Kali's relationship with Shiva is unique. While she is technically Parvati's fierce form, when manifested as Kali, she appears more powerful than Shiva himself. She stands atop him, and in some traditions, they engage in a dance competition where she eventually wins by lifting her leg higher than modesty would permit (which Shiva, bound by dharma, cannot do). She represents the supreme power beyond all conventional limits, even those of her consort.

myths.title: Kali Yuga - The Age of Kali
myths.content: The current cosmic age is called Kali Yuga (age of Kali) - though this Kali is grammatically masculine and refers to the demon Kali, not the goddess. However, the association is meaningful: we live in the age of dissolution, where the old order breaks down, where materialism and ego dominate, and where the fierce mother must eventually intervene to destroy the old and prepare for renewal. The goddess Kali is especially relevant in this age of darkness.

myths.title: Ramakrishna's Devotion
myths.content: The 19th-century saint Ramakrishna was Kali's greatest modern devotee. He served as a priest at the Dakshineswar Kali Temple and would go into ecstatic trances during her worship. He saw her not as terrifying but as the loving mother, calling her "Ma" (Mother). He would weep like a child calling for his mother until he had her vision. Once, driven mad with devotion and suicidal at her absence, he grabbed a sword to kill himself, and she appeared to him, filling him with bliss. His relationship with Kali showed the world her loving maternal nature beneath the terrifying exterior. He taught that her blackness represents the infinite - just as the dark night sky contains all stars, the dark mother contains all existence.

sources: Devi Mahatmya (Markandeya Purana), Kalika Purana, Devi Bhagavata Purana, Mahabhagavata Purana, Tantric texts

name: Kartikeya
description: Kartikeya (Skanda, Murugan) is the god of war and commander of divine armies.

name: Krishna
description: Krishna is the eighth avatar of Vishnu, the divine cowherd who revealed the Bhagavad Gita.

name: Lakshmi
description: The radiant goddess of wealth, prosperity, and abundance who emerges eternally from the churning of the cosmic ocean. Seated upon a lotus with gold coins flowing from her hands, Lakshmi is the divine consort of Vishnu and the embodiment of material and spiritual fortune. She represents not only worldly success but also the grace, beauty, and auspiciousness that illuminate life.

attributes.Sanskrit Titles: Sri (Auspiciousness), Shridevi (Goddess of Fortune), Padma (Lotus), Kamala (Lotus-Dwelling), Indira (Radiant), Lokamata (Mother of the World), Narayani (Consort of Narayana/Vishnu)
attributes.Domains: Wealth, Prosperity, Fortune, Beauty, Fertility, Abundance, Material Success, Spiritual Fulfillment, Generosity, Auspiciousness
attributes.Symbols: Lotus flower (purity rising from mud), Gold coins (wealth), Conch shell (purity), Pot of gold (abundance), Rice/grain (nourishment)
attributes.Sacred Animals: White elephants (two elephants often flank her, bathing her in water - Gajalakshmi form), Owl (in some traditions - representing wealth coming in darkness)
attributes.Sacred Plants: Lotus (especially pink and white), Tulsi (holy basil), Bilva leaves, Coconut, Betel leaves
attributes.Colors: Gold (wealth and radiance), Pink (grace and compassion), Red (auspiciousness), White (purity)

myths.title: The Churning of the Cosmic Ocean (Samudra Manthan)
myths.content: The most famous origin story of Lakshmi comes from the churning of the cosmic ocean, Kshira Sagara. The devas (gods) and asuras (demons) joined forces to churn the ocean of milk using Mount Mandara as a churning rod and the serpent Vasuki as a rope, seeking the nectar of immortality (amrita). From this cosmic churning emerged fourteen precious treasures, and among them arose Lakshmi, seated upon a fully bloomed lotus, radiating beauty and light. She held lotuses in her hands, and two elephants bathed her with sacred water from golden vessels. The gods and sages sang hymns in her praise. Lakshmi chose Vishnu as her eternal consort, garlanding him and taking her place beside him. This story establishes her as the goddess who emerges from the depths of the cosmic process, bringing abundance to the world.

myths.title: Eternal Consort of Vishnu
myths.content: Lakshmi is inseparably connected to Vishnu, the preserver of the universe. While he lies upon the cosmic serpent Shesha in the ocean of milk, she massages his feet, symbolizing their eternal partnership. Whenever Vishnu incarnates on earth as an avatar to restore dharma, Lakshmi incarnates alongside him as his companion: as Sita when he was Rama, as Rukmini and Radha when he was Krishna, and as Padmavati when he was Venkateswara. This eternal partnership represents the union of preservation (Vishnu) with prosperity (Lakshmi) - the cosmos cannot be sustained without both.

myths.title: The Fickleness and Stability of Fortune
myths.content: Though Lakshmi is benevolent, Hindu philosophy recognizes that fortune is unstable - she is said to be "chanchala" (restless), never staying in one place long. Stories tell of her leaving those who become proud, greedy, or unrighteous. The demon king Bali, despite his devotion, lost her favor when he became arrogant. The Pandava brothers in the Mahabharata maintained her favor through their adherence to dharma, even in exile. This teaching emphasizes that wealth and prosperity must be earned and maintained through virtue, humility, and generosity. Lakshmi favors those who work hard, remain ethical, and use their prosperity for the benefit of others.

myths.title: Lakshmi and the Lotus
myths.content: The lotus is Lakshmi's primary symbol, representing purity and spiritual perfection rising from the mud of material existence. She is often depicted sitting or standing on a fully bloomed lotus, holding lotus buds in her hands. This symbolizes that true prosperity blooms beautifully even amidst worldly challenges, and that spiritual wealth is the highest form of abundance. The lotus also never gets wet despite growing in water, teaching that one should live in the world of wealth without becoming attached to or corrupted by it.

myths.title: Alakshmi - The Shadow Side
myths.content: In some traditions, Lakshmi has a shadow counterpart called Alakshmi or Jyeshtha, the goddess of misfortune and poverty who dwells in quarrelsome households, dirty places, and where dharma is violated. This duality teaches that prosperity and misfortune are two faces of the same force - one must actively create conditions that attract Lakshmi (cleanliness, harmony, generosity, hard work) and repel Alakshmi (conflict, laziness, uncleanliness, greed).

myths.title: Kubera's Lesson
myths.content: Kubera, the god of wealth and treasurer of the gods, once became arrogant about his riches. Lakshmi visited him in disguise as a humble woman. Kubera failed to show her proper respect and honor. She revealed herself and left him, teaching that wealth without humility and grace is hollow. True prosperity includes inner qualities: generosity, respect, beauty of character, and compassion.

family.Eternal Consort: Vishnu - The Preserver, Lord of Vaikuntha
family.Father: Bhrigu (in some traditions) or born directly from the cosmic ocean
family.Sister: Alakshmi/Jyeshtha (goddess of misfortune, her shadow counterpart)
family.Incarnations: Sita (wife of Rama), Rukmini/Radha (consorts of Krishna), Padmavati (wife of Venkateswara)

festivals: Diwali (Deepavali): The most important Lakshmi festival, celebrated on the new moon night in October/November. On this night, homes are cleaned, lit with oil lamps (diyas), and decorated with rangoli to welcome Lakshmi. It's believed she visits clean, well-lit homes and blesses them with prosperity for the year ahead. Business account books are blessed, new ventures begun, and gambling is considered auspicious as it attracts fortune.

Varalakshmi Vratam: Celebrated by married women (primarily in South India) on the Friday before the full moon in the month of Shravana (July-August). Women pray for the wellbeing of their families and worship the goddess with elaborate offerings.
Kojagari Purnima/Sharad Purnima: The autumn full moon when Lakshmi is believed to descend to earth and visit homes, bestowing blessings on those who stay awake all night.
Mahalakshmi Vrat: An eight-day festival in the month of Bhadrapada (August-September) dedicated to propitiating the goddess.
worship.offerings: Lotus flowers (pink or white), gold ornaments, coins, sweets (especially kheer - rice pudding), coconut, betel leaves and nuts, turmeric, kumkum (red powder), sandalwood paste, fruits (particularly bananas), and rice. Silver or gold coins are traditional offerings. Offering food to the poor and practicing generosity are considered the highest forms of Lakshmi worship.

sources: Vishnu Purana, Bhagavata Purana, Padma Purana, Ramayana, Mahabharata, Sri Sukta (Rigveda), Lakshmi Tantra

name: Parvati
description: The supreme mother goddess and embodiment of Shakti, the divine feminine creative power that animates the universe. As Shiva's eternal consort, she completes the cosmic dance of creation and destruction. Known by many names - Uma, Gauri, Ambika - she manifests in forms ranging from the gentle, nurturing mother to the fierce warrior goddesses Durga and Kali. She is the divine mother of Ganesha and Kartikeya, the mountain princess who won the ascetic god through devotion.

attributes.Sanskrit Titles: Uma (Light, Peace), Gauri (The Fair One), Ambika (Mother), Aparna (Leafless - she who fasted without even eating leaves), Lalita (The Playful One), Bhavani (Giver of Life), Shailaja/Shailaputri (Daughter of Mountains)
attributes.Domains: Divine Feminine Power (Shakti), Motherhood, Love, Devotion, Fertility, Harmony, Beauty, Marital Felicity, Asceticism, Power, Nourishment
attributes.Symbols: Trishula (trident when in Durga form), Lotus, Mirror, Rosary beads, Kamandalu (water pot), Red silk sari, Vermillion (sindoor)
attributes.Sacred Animals: Lion (in Durga form), Tiger (in fierce forms), Bull Nandi (Shiva's mount, shared symbolism)
attributes.Sacred Plants: Bilva leaves (sacred to Shiva, offered by Parvati), Lotus, Red flowers, Turmeric, Sandalwood, Durva grass
attributes.Colors: Golden (as Gauri), Green (association with nature and fertility), Red (as Shakti/power), White (purity as Uma)

myths.title: Reincarnation of Sati
myths.content: Parvati is the reincarnation of Sati, Shiva's first wife. Sati had immolated herself in her father Daksha's sacrificial fire after he insulted Shiva by not inviting him to a great yajna. Grief-stricken, Shiva withdrew from the world into deep meditation. Sati was reborn as Parvati, daughter of Himavan (the personified Himalayas) and Mena. Even as a child, she was devoted to Shiva, having memories of her previous life. This story establishes Parvati as the eternal feminine principle that is Shiva's inseparable complement across lifetimes.

myths.title: Winning Shiva Through Tapas
myths.content: The gods needed Shiva to marry and produce a son who could defeat the demon Taraka. Knowing Parvati's devotion, they sent Kamadeva (god of desire) to shoot his flower arrow at the meditating Shiva. Disturbed, Shiva opened his third eye and burned Kamadeva to ash. Parvati then undertook severe austerities herself - standing on one leg, fasting for years, exposed to harsh elements, earning the name Aparna ("leafless") because she abstained even from eating leaves. Her devotion and tapas (spiritual austerity) were so intense that even the ascetic Shiva was compelled to acknowledge her. He tested her in disguise, criticizing himself to see if her devotion was true. When she defended him fiercely, he revealed himself and accepted her as his wife. This story demonstrates that the divine feminine wins the divine masculine not through mere beauty but through spiritual power, devotion, and determination.

myths.title: Creation of Ganesha
myths.content: While Shiva wandered as an ascetic, Parvati desired a child of her own. From the sandalwood paste and turmeric she used for her bath, she fashioned a beautiful boy and breathed life into him - Ganesha. She instructed him to guard the door while she bathed. When Shiva returned and the boy refused him entry, Shiva beheaded him in anger. Parvati's grief and rage were so terrible that the entire universe trembled. Shiva, recognizing the power of her maternal love and fury, immediately agreed to restore the child with an elephant's head. This story reveals Parvati as the creative mother goddess whose power rivals even Shiva's, and whose love and protection for her children is absolute.

myths.title: Manifestation as Durga
myths.content: When the demon Mahishasura terrorized the three worlds with a boon that no man or god could kill him, the gods pooled their energies, which manifested as the warrior goddess Durga - an emanation of Parvati's Shakti. Riding a lion, wielding weapons from all the gods, she battled Mahishasura for nine days before slaying him. This demonstrates that when evil becomes too great, the gentle mother transforms into the fierce warrior to protect dharma. Durga is not a separate goddess but Parvati herself manifesting her protective, martial aspect.

myths.title: Transformation into Kali
myths.content: In some accounts, during the battle with demons, Durga's fury became so intense that she manifested Kali from her forehead - the darkest, most terrifying form of Shakti. Kali went into a destructive frenzy, dancing on corpses, drinking blood, threatening to destroy the entire universe. Only when Shiva lay down among the corpses and she realized she was stepping on her husband did she stop, biting her tongue in shock. This shows the ultimate power of the goddess - she can destroy everything, but love and relationship bring her back to balance.

myths.title: The Divine Play at Kailash
myths.content: Numerous stories depict the domestic life of Parvati and Shiva on Mount Kailash - they play dice, argue playfully, raise their children, and demonstrate an ideal marriage partnership. Once, Parvati playfully covered Shiva's eyes, plunging the universe into darkness, showing that she holds equal cosmic power. When she won all his possessions in a dice game, Shiva bet himself and lost, becoming her possession. These stories humanize the divine couple while revealing deep philosophical truths about the balance and complementarity of masculine and feminine principles.

myths.title: Teaching Shiva to Dance
myths.content: While Shiva is known as Nataraja (Lord of Dance), some traditions say that Parvati taught him the arts of music and dance. As Shivakami, she is the consort who brings culture, beauty, and refinement to the wild ascetic god. She civilizes him without diminishing his power, bringing him from the cremation grounds to the family home, from solitary meditation to engaged relationship.

family.Eternal Consort: Shiva - The Destroyer/Transformer, Lord of Kailash
family.Father: Himavan/Himavat - Personification of the Himalaya mountains
family.Sister: Ganga - The sacred river goddess (in some traditions)
family.Sons: Ganesha (remover of obstacles) and Kartikeya/Skanda (god of war)
family.Previous Life: Sati - First wife of Shiva, daughter of Daksha

festivals: Navaratri: Nine nights celebrating the goddess in all her forms, culminating in Durga Puja (worship of her warrior form) and Vijayadashami (victory day).
Teej Festival: Celebrated by married women, especially in North India, for marital happiness and the wellbeing of husbands. Unmarried girls pray for a husband like Shiva.
Gauri Tritiya: Celebrating her auspicious Gauri form, especially in Maharashtra and Karnataka.
Gangaur: Rajasthani festival celebrating Gauri (Parvati) alongside Gan (Shiva), honoring marital love and fidelity.
worship.offerings: Red flowers (hibiscus, rose), turmeric, kumkum (vermillion), sandalwood paste, bilva leaves (sacred to Shiva, offered by her), fruits, sweets, coconut, incense. Fasting and austerities are considered particularly pleasing to her, as she herself won Shiva through tapas.

sources: Shiva Purana, Devi Bhagavata Purana, Skanda Purana, Linga Purana, Kalika Purana, Devi Mahatmya

name: Prithvi
description: Prithvi (Bhudevi) is the Earth Mother goddess representing fertility and abundance.

name: Rati
description: Rati is the goddess of love, desire, and passion, consort of Kamadeva (god of love).

name: Saraswati
description: Saraswati is the goddess of knowledge, music, arts, wisdom, and learning. Dressed in pure white, she rides a white swan or peacock and plays the veena (a stringed musical instrument). As the consort of Brahma, she represents the creative power of knowledge that shapes the universe.

attributes.Titles: Vak Devi (Goddess of Speech), Sharada (Giver of Essence), Brahmi (Consort of Brahma), Mahavidya (Great Knowledge)
attributes.Domains: Knowledge, Music, Arts, Learning, Wisdom, Speech, Memory
attributes.Symbols: Veena (musical instrument), Books, Prayer beads, Lotus

myths.title: Creation of the Vedas
myths.content: Saraswati is credited with creating Sanskrit, the sacred language, and the Vedas themselves flowed from her essence. She gave Brahma the knowledge to create the universe in an ordered, meaningful way.

myths.title: The Sacred River
myths.content: The ancient Saraswati River, now largely dried up, was said to be her earthly manifestation. Where it joins the Ganges and Yamuna at Prayagraj (Allahabad), it forms the Triveni Sangam, a most sacred confluence.

myths.title: Rivalry with Lakshmi
myths.content: In some tales, Saraswati and Lakshmi (goddess of wealth) compete for devotees' attention, representing the eternal tension between spiritual knowledge and material prosperity.

family.Consort: Brahma (the Creator god)
family.Forms: Sometimes identified with Gayatri and other knowledge deities

worship.sacredSites: Major temples include the Saraswati Temple at Basara (Telangana), Mookambika Temple (Karnataka), and temples at educational institutions across India.
festivals: Vasant Panchami: The spring festival celebrating Saraswati, when students place their books and instruments before her for blessings
Navratri: She is worshipped during the final days as one of the divine feminine aspects
worship.offerings: White flowers, especially jasmine and lotus, fruits, honey, milk, and yellow/white colored sweets. Students offer their books and educational tools.

sources: Rigveda, Puranas, Devi Mahatmya

name: Shiva
description: The cosmic dancer who dissolves the universe at the end of each cycle, yet embodies both destruction and regeneration. The great ascetic who meditates in the Himalayas, wearing ashes and draped with serpents, the ultimate yogi from whom all transformation flows.

attributes.Titles: Mahadeva (Great God), Nataraja (Lord of Dance), Mahakal (Lord of Time), Bholenath (Simple/Innocent Lord), Neelkanth (Blue-Throated)
attributes.Domains: Destruction, Transformation, Yoga, Meditation, Time, Death, Regeneration, Asceticism
attributes.Symbols: Trishula (trident), Damaru (drum), Third Eye, Crescent Moon, Ganga (river), Lingam
attributes.Sacred Animals: Nandi (bull - his vahana), Serpents (worn as ornaments), Tiger (skin used as seat)
attributes.Sacred Plants: Bilva (bael) leaves, Datura, Cannabis, Rudraksha seeds

myths.title: The Drinking of Halahala
myths.content: During the churning of the cosmic ocean, the deadly poison halahala emerged before the nectar. It threatened to destroy all creation. Shiva, to save the universe, drank the poison but held it in his throat with yogic power, turning his throat blue. This earned him the name Neelkanth (Blue-Throated) and demonstrated his role as the protector who takes on the world's suffering.

myths.title: The Tandava - Dance of Destruction
myths.content: As Nataraja, Shiva performs the Tandava, the cosmic dance that destroys the universe at the end of each cycle. He dances within a ring of fire (representing cosmic energy), standing on the demon Apasmara (representing ignorance). His drum beats out the rhythm of time, his hand gestures promise protection and liberation. This dance is not mere destruction but transformation - clearing away the old so the new can emerge.

myths.title: The Burning of Kamadeva
myths.content: When the god of love Kamadeva shot his arrow at Shiva to break his deep meditation and make him notice Parvati, Shiva opened his third eye in anger and reduced Kamadeva to ashes. This demonstrated Shiva's power over desire and attachment. Later, moved by Kamadeva's wife's grief and Parvati's devotion, Shiva allowed Kamadeva to be reborn, showing his compassion alongside his fierceness.

family.Parents: Born from Brahma's forehead or self-manifested; Rudra in the Vedas
family.First Consort: Sati (daughter of Daksha) - who self-immolated when her father insulted Shiva
family.Current Consort: Parvati/Uma (Sati reborn) - The Divine Mother, Shakti personified
family.Children: Ganesha (elephant-headed remover of obstacles), Kartikeya/Skanda (god of war), Ashokasundari (daughter)
family.Siblings: Part of Trimurti with Brahma and Vishnu

festivals: Maha Shivaratri: "The Great Night of Shiva" - the most important Shiva festival, celebrating his marriage to Parvati or the night he performed the Tandava. Devotees fast and keep vigil all night, offering bilva leaves and milk to the Shiva Lingam.
Pradosham: The 13th day after new/full moon, twilight time sacred to Shiva. Special pujas performed.
Shravan Month: The entire month (July-August) is sacred to Shiva. Devotees observe Monday fasts and offer water to Lingam.
worship.offerings: Bilva (bael) leaves in sets of three (representing the Trimurti or three eyes of Shiva), milk, honey, yogurt, ghee, water (especially Ganga water), vibhuti (sacred ash), rudraksha beads, white flowers, datura flowers. Shiva accepts simple offerings from sincere devotees - even water is enough. The Rudra Abhishekam (ritual bathing of the Lingam) is particularly sacred.

sources: Rigveda, Shiva Purana, Linga Purana, Skanda Purana, Mahabharata, various Agamas (Shaivite texts)

name: Vishnu
description: The sustainer of the universe who maintains cosmic order and descends to earth in various avatars whenever dharma is threatened. Blue-skinned deity of infinite compassion and divine protection.

attributes.Titles: Narayana (Cosmic Man), Hari (Remover of Sins), Madhava (Lord of Knowledge), Vasudeva (Indwelling Spirit)
attributes.Domains: Preservation, Dharma, Compassion, Protection, Cosmic Order, Divine Love
attributes.Symbols: Sudarshana Chakra (discus), Panchajanya (conch), Kaumodaki (mace), Padma (lotus)
attributes.Sacred Animals: Garuda (divine eagle), Shesha/Ananta (cosmic serpent), Kamadhenu (wish-granting cow)

myths.title: The Churning of the Cosmic Ocean
myths.content: When the gods lost their immortality, Vishnu advised them to churn the ocean of milk to obtain amrita (nectar of immortality). Taking the form of a giant turtle (Kurma avatar), he supported Mount Mandara as the churning rod. During the churning, many treasures emerged including Lakshmi (who chose Vishnu as her consort), the deadly poison halahala (swallowed by Shiva), and finally the amrita.

myths.title: The Cosmic Sleep
myths.content: Between each cycle of creation, Vishnu sleeps on the thousand-headed serpent Shesha, floating on the cosmic ocean. During this yoga-nidra (cosmic sleep), the universe is in potential form. When he awakens, a new cycle of creation begins with a lotus sprouting from his navel, upon which Brahma sits to create the world anew.

myths.title: The Three Strides of Vamana
myths.content: When the demon king Bali conquered the three worlds, the gods appealed to Vishnu. He incarnated as Vamana, a dwarf brahmin, and asked Bali for just three paces of land. When Bali agreed, Vamana expanded to cosmic size and covered earth with one step, the heavens with another, and asked Bali where to place the third. Humbled, Bali offered his own head, and Vamana pushed him to the netherworld, restoring cosmic balance while honoring Bali's devotion.

family.Parents: Son of Sage Kashyapa and Aditi (in some traditions); self-existent in others
family.Consort: Lakshmi (Goddess of Prosperity and Fortune) - incarnates with him in various forms
family.Children: Kamadeva (God of Love), and various children through his avatars
family.Siblings: Part of Trimurti with Brahma and Shiva

festivals: Vaikuntha Ekadashi: The day when the gates to Vaikuntha (Vishnu's abode) are believed to be open. Devotees fast and keep vigil.
Rama Navami: Birthday of Lord Rama (9th day of Chaitra month, March-April).
Krishna Janmashtami: Birthday of Lord Krishna (8th day of Bhadrapada, August-September), celebrated with fasting, singing, and reenacting Krishna's childhood.
Diwali: Celebrates Rama's return to Ayodhya after 14 years of exile.
worship.offerings: Tulsi leaves (most sacred to Vishnu), yellow flowers, butter, milk, honey, fruits (especially bananas), betel leaves, panchamrita (mixture of milk, yogurt, ghee, honey, sugar). Devotional songs, recitation of Vishnu Sahasranama (1000 names), reading of Bhagavad Gita or Vishnu Purana.

sources: Rigveda, Vishnu Purana, Bhagavata Purana, Bhagavad Gita, Ramayana, Mahabharata

name: Vritra
description: Vritra is the serpentine demon who imprisoned the cosmic waters, slain by Indra.

name: Yama
description: Yama is the god of death and the lord of dharma, presiding over the afterlife and judging souls based on their karmic deeds. Riding a black buffalo and wielding a noose to capture souls, he maintains cosmic justice and the cycle of rebirth. He is both feared and respected as the inevitable force that brings every life to its conclusion.

attributes.Titles: Dharmaraja (King of Dharma), Kala (Time), Antaka (The Ender), Mrityu (Death)
attributes.Domains: Death, Judgment, Justice, Dharma, Afterlife, Time
attributes.Symbols: Noose (pasha), Staff (danda), Book of destiny
attributes.Sacred Animals: Black buffalo (vahana), sometimes depicted with dogs
attributes.Realm: Yamaloka or Pitriloka (realm of the dead)

myths.title: The First Mortal
myths.content: Yama chose mortality, exploring the path of death to guide future souls. His twin sister Yami (later the river goddess Yamuna) pleaded with him not to die, but he accepted his fate.

myths.title: Savitri and Satyavan
myths.content: When Yama came to claim Satyavan's soul, his devoted wife Savitri followed them. Impressed by her devotion and wisdom, Yama granted her boons, ultimately returning her husband to life.

myths.title: Testing Yudhishthira
myths.content: In the Mahabharata, Yama tested Yudhishthira's adherence to dharma through various trials, including appearing as a dog and a yaksha with philosophical questions.

family.Parents: Son of Surya (sun god) and Saranyu
family.Consort: Dhumorna (representing smoke from funeral pyres)
family.Siblings: Manu (first man), Ashvins (divine physicians)

worship.sacredSites: Yama is rarely worshipped in dedicated temples, though shrines exist in South India. He is honored during ancestor worship rituals and funeral rites.
festivals: Yama Dwitiya (Bhai Dooj): The day celebrating the bond between brothers and sisters, commemorating Yama's visit to his sister Yami
worship.offerings: Black sesame seeds, food offerings for ancestors (shraddha), water libations

sources: Rigveda, Atharvaveda, Mahabharata, Puranas, Garuda Purana

name: Yami
description: Yami is the goddess of the sacred Yamuna River and the twin sister of Yama, the god of death. In Vedic mythology, she represents the feminine principle of life and continuity, contrasting with her brother's role as death. After Yama became the first to die, Yami grieved so deeply that the gods created night to help her forget.

attributes.Titles: Yamuna (River Goddess), Sister of Death
attributes.Domains: Rivers, Life, Continuity, Sisterly Love
attributes.Symbols: Yamuna River, Water pot, Lotus

name: Jibreel Gabriel
subtitle: The Angel of Revelation - Ruh al-Qudus (The Holy Spirit)

name: Prophet Muhammad
subtitle: Ù…Ø­Ù…Ø¯ - The Seal of Prophets (Khatam an-Nabiyyin)

name: Amaterasu-Omikami å¤©ç…§å¤§ç¥ž
subtitle: Great Divinity Illuminating Heaven
description: The supreme deity of Shinto, Amaterasu is the radiant sun goddess who rules over Takamagahara (the High Plain of Heaven) and serves as the divine ancestor of the Japanese Imperial line. Her light sustains all life, her wisdom guides the kami, and her sacred mirror remains the most treasured of Japan's Imperial Regalia. She embodies purity, benevolence, and the eternal cycle of renewal.

attributes.Primary Name: Amaterasu-Omikami (å¤©ç…§å¤§ç¥ž) - "Great August Kami Who Shines in Heaven"
attributes.Alternative Names: Ohirume-no-Muchi (å¤§æ—¥éœªè²´) - "Great Sun Female Deity", Tensho Daijin - Sino-Japanese reading
attributes.Epithets: Heaven-Shining Great Deity, Ancestress of the Imperial Line, Queen of the Kami, Lady of the Sun
attributes.Honorific: Omikami (å¤§ç¥ž) - "Great Kami" - the highest honorific given to any Shinto deity

myths.title: Birth from Izanagi's Purification
myths.content: After fleeing the underworld realm of Yomi, Izanagi purified himself in a river. As he washed his left eye, the sublime radiance of Amaterasu was born. She emerged fully formed, her brilliance so overwhelming that Izanagi immediately recognized her supremacy and bestowed upon her the rule of Takamagahara - the High Plain of Heaven. This birth through purification (misogi) establishes her as the embodiment of purity itself.

myths.title: The Cave of Heaven (Ama-no-Iwato)
myths.content: The most celebrated myth tells of Amaterasu's retreat into a cave. Enraged by Susanoo's destructive rampage in her realm - where he defiled her weaving hall, destroyed rice paddies, and killed one of her attendants with a flayed horse - Amaterasu sealed herself within the Heavenly Rock Cave. The world plunged into eternal darkness. The eight million kami gathered in desperate council. The cunning goddess Ame-no-Uzume performed an ecstatic, ribald dance that caused such divine laughter that Amaterasu's curiosity was piqued. When she opened the cave to peek, the kami Ame-no-Tajikarao pulled her out, and a sacred rope (shimenawa) was placed across the entrance to prevent her return. Light returned to the world, and this myth explains the origins of sacred dance (kagura) and many Shinto purification rituals.

myths.title: The Divine Mandate to Earth
myths.content: Amaterasu sent her grandson Ninigi-no-Mikoto to pacify and rule the terrestrial realm. She bestowed upon him the Three Sacred Treasures (Sanshu no Jingi): the mirror Yata no Kagami ("so that you may see me within it"), the sword Kusanagi, and the jewels Yasakani no Magatama. These treasures became the Imperial Regalia, validating the divine authority of every Japanese emperor as Amaterasu's descendant.

myths.title: The Conflict with Susanoo
myths.content: Before his banishment, Susanoo challenged Amaterasu to a contest of creation. Each deity used the other's possessions to create offspring - Amaterasu chewed Susanoo's sword and breathed forth five male deities; Susanoo used her jewels to create three female goddesses. Amaterasu declared victory because the males came from her breath, but Susanoo's subsequent violence showed his rejection of civilized divine order.

family.Father: Izanagi-no-Mikoto - The male creator deity who gave birth to her through purification
family.Mother: Born not from Izanami but from Izanagi's left eye during his misogi purification rite
family.Brothers: Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto (Moon God, born from right eye), Susanoo-no-Mikoto (Storm God, born from nose)
family.Children by Contest: Five male kami created from Susanoo's sword - including Ame-no-Oshihomimi, ancestor of the Imperial line
family.Grandson: Ninigi-no-Mikoto - sent to rule Earth, great-grandfather of first Emperor Jimmu

festivals: Kannamesai (October 17): The most important festival at Ise, offering first rice harvest to Amaterasu
Niinamesai (November 23): The Emperor offers new rice to Amaterasu - one of the most important imperial rites
Shikinen Sengu: The 20-year shrine rebuilding ceremony, most recently in 2013
New Year (Shogatsu): Millions visit shrines to receive Amaterasu's blessing for the year

sources: Kojiki (Record of Ancient Matters, 712 CE), Nihon Shoki (Chronicles of Japan, 720 CE), Kogo Shui (Gleanings from Ancient Stories), Engishiki (Procedures of the Engi Era)

name: Fujin é¢¨ç¥ž
subtitle: God of Wind and Storms
description:
Fujin is the powerful Japanese god of wind, depicted as a fearsome oni-like deity carrying a massive
                bag of winds upon his shoulders. One of the most ancient forces in Shinto cosmology, Fujin controls
                the winds that bring both destruction and renewal to the world. Alongside his companion Raijin, the
                god of thunder, Fujin represents the elemental fury of storms and the life-giving breath of nature itself.

name: Hachiman å…«å¹…ç¥ž
subtitle: God of War and Divine Protector
description: Hachiman is the powerful syncretic deity of war, archery, and the samurai, revered as the divine protector of Japan and the Japanese people. A unique fusion of Shinto and Buddhist traditions, he is identified with the deified spirit of Emperor Ojin and embodies the warrior's code of honor, strength, and loyalty. With over 40,000 shrines dedicated to his worship, Hachiman stands as one of Japan's most widely venerated kami, the patron of warriors and the guardian of the nation's martial spirit.

attributes.Historical Identity: Emperor Ojin (å¿œä»å¤©çš‡) - 15th legendary emperor of Japan (late 3rd-early 4th century)
attributes.Epithets: Divine Protector of Japan, God of Warriors, Patron of the Samurai, Deity of Archery, Guardian of the Nation

family.Father: Emperor Chuai (14th emperor) - died during a military campaign
family.Mother: Empress Jingu (ç¥žåŠŸçš‡åŽ) - legendary warrior empress who led military campaigns while pregnant with Ojin, often enshrined alongside Hachiman
family.Children: Eight sons (according to legend), who became regional guardian kami

festivals: Reitaisai (Annual Grand Festival): Varies by shrine but typically in September, featuring processions, archery demonstrations, and mikoshi (portable shrine) parades
Yabusame: Mounted archery ceremonies performed at major Hachiman shrines, demonstrating samurai martial skills
Hojo-e (Liberation of Living Beings): A Buddhist-influenced ritual releasing captive animals, reflecting Hachiman's Buddhist aspects
Coming-of-age ceremonies: Young people and especially martial artists visit Hachiman shrines to pray for strength and success

sources: Shoku Nihongi (Chronicle of Japan Continued, 797 CE), Heike Monogatari (The Tale of the Heike, 13th century), Temple and shrine records from Usa Hachimangu, Iwashimizu Hachimangu, and Tsurugaoka Hachimangu

name: Inari Okami ç¨²è·ç¥ž
subtitle: The Rice Bearer - God of Prosperity, Foxes, and Abundance
description: Inari is one of the most popular and widely worshipped kami in Japan, with more than 30,000 shrines - more than any other deity. As the god of rice, agriculture, foxes, fertility, tea, sake, and general prosperity, Inari touches nearly every aspect of Japanese life and economy. Gender-fluid and multifaceted, appearing sometimes as male, sometimes as female, sometimes as androgynous, Inari embodies the productive forces of nature and the wealth they bring. White foxes (kitsune) serve as Inari's messengers and representatives, making fox statues a ubiquitous sight at Inari shrines across Japan.

attributes.Primary Name: Inari Okami (ç¨²è·ç¥ž) - "Great God of the Rice-Bearing Plant"
attributes.Alternative Names: O-Inari-sama (honorific), Inari Daimyojin (Great Bright Deity), Toyouke-no-Okami (in some traditions)
attributes.Epithets: Rice Bringer, Fox God, Prosperity Kami, Patron of Merchants, Guardian of Agriculture
attributes.Regional Variations: Sometimes identified with Uke-Mochi (food goddess), Toyouke-Hime, or Ukanomitama-no-Kami

festivals: Hatsu-Uma Festival (First Horse Day): Held on the first horse day of February (Inari's traditional descent date), this is the most important Inari festival celebrating the kami's blessing of crops.
Inari Matsuri: Various local festivals throughout the year, especially at planting and harvest times.
New Year (Shogatsu): Inari shrines receive massive crowds seeking blessings for prosperity in the coming year.

name: Izanagi-no-Mikoto ä¼Šé‚ªé‚£å²å‘½
subtitle: The Male Who Invites - Progenitor of the Gods
description: The primordial creator deity who, together with his divine consort Izanami, stirred the cosmic ocean to create the islands of Japan and gave birth to the myriad kami. His mythology encompasses the grandest themes: creation, love, death, loss, and rebirth. From his union with Izanami came the land itself; from his tears came grief; from his purification came the three most noble kami - Amaterasu, Tsukuyomi, and Susanoo. He is both the beginning of all things and the first to experience their ending.

attributes.Epithets: Progenitor of the Kami, Creator of the Islands, Father of the Sun, First Purifier, Opener of the Celestial Door

family.Origins: One of the first divine generations, created by or emerging from the primordial kami
family.Consort: Izanami-no-Mikoto - "She Who Invites," his divine sister-wife, now ruler of Yomi
family.Children with Izanami: The islands of Japan, countless kami of nature, and finally Kagutsuchi (fire god) whose birth killed her
family.Children from Misogi: Amaterasu (left eye), Tsukuyomi (right eye), Susanoo (nose) - the three noble children
family.Children from Garments: Various kami born as he removed his clothes for purification

festivals: Oharae (Great Purification): June 30 and December 31 purification rituals that trace directly to Izanagi's misogi, cleansing pollution accumulated over the half-year
Misogi-harae: Water purification rituals practiced at rivers and seas, following Izanagi's example
Taga Taisha Matsuri: Major festival at Taga Shrine celebrating Izanagi

sources: Kojiki (Record of Ancient Matters, 712 CE), Nihon Shoki (Chronicles of Japan, 720 CE), Sendai Kuji Hongi, Kogo Shui

name: Izanami-no-Mikoto ä¼Šé‚ªé‚£ç¾Žå‘½
subtitle: She Who Invites - Mother of Creation, Queen of the Dead
description: The primordial goddess who, with her divine husband Izanagi, gave birth to the islands of Japan and the myriad kami. Yet her story is one of tragic transformation: from creator of life to first divine corpse, from beloved wife to wrathful queen of the underworld. She embodies the terrible truth that creation and destruction are inseparable - the same divine womb that brought forth the world also brought forth death itself. Now she reigns over Yomi-no-Kuni, where all the dead must eventually come to her.

attributes.Alternative Names: Izanami-no-Kami, Yomotsu-Okami (Great Goddess of Yomi), Chishiki-no-Okami
attributes.Epithets: Mother of the Islands, First Death, Queen of Yomi, She of the Eight Thunder Gods, The Polluted One, Goddess of Creation and Destruction

family.Origins: One of the first divine generations, emerging from the primordial kami
family.Consort (Former): Izanagi-no-Mikoto - "He Who Invites," now divorced and separated by the boulder of Yomi
family.Children with Izanagi: The islands of Japan, countless nature kami, and finally Kagutsuchi whose birth killed her
family.Hiruko: The deformed "leech-child," first offspring from the improperly performed marriage ritual, set adrift
family.Children Born in Death: The Eight Thunder Gods, born from her decaying corpse

festivals: Izanami-related rites at Taga Taisha: Honoring both creator deities
Obon Festival: Though not specifically for Izanami, this festival of the dead acknowledges her realm
Purification rituals (Oharae): These counteract the pollution associated with death - pollution that originated from Izanami

sources: Kojiki (Record of Ancient Matters, 712 CE), Nihon Shoki (Chronicles of Japan, 720 CE), Sendai Kuji Hongi, Engishiki

name: Okuninushi-no-Mikoto å¤§å›½ä¸»å‘½
subtitle: Great Master of the Land
description: The benevolent deity of nation-building, agriculture, medicine, and magic, Okuninushi is the great civilizer who shaped the land of Japan and taught humanity the arts of survival and prosperity. Through cunning, perseverance, and compassion, he overcame impossible trials to win his bride and build a nation. Though he ultimately ceded rulership of the visible world to Amaterasu's descendants, he remains the supreme lord of the unseen realm, governing the mysterious forces of fate, healing, and the afterlife.

attributes.Original Name: Onamuji (å¤§å·±è²´) - "Great Name Possessor", his birth name before gaining power
attributes.Alternative Names: Ashihara-shiko-o (è‹åŽŸé†‰å­è‚‰çŽ‹) - "Ugly Male of Ashihara", Yachihoko (å…«åƒçŸ›) - "Eight Thousand Spears", Okuninushi-no-Kami (å¤§å›½ä¸»ç¥ž)
attributes.Epithets: Nation-Builder, Lord of the Unseen World, Master of Izumo, Deity of Compassion, God of Love and Marriage

myths.title: The White Rabbit of Inaba
myths.content: In his youth as Onamuji, he traveled with his eighty elder brothers (the Yasogami) to court Princess Yakami of Inaba. Along the road, they encountered a skinless rabbit suffering in agony. The cruel brothers told the rabbit to bathe in salt water, which only increased its pain. When Onamuji arrived, carrying his brothers' baggage like a servant, he showed compassion. He instructed the rabbit to wash in fresh water and roll in cattail pollen, which healed its wounds. The grateful rabbit revealed it was a divine messenger and prophesied that Onamuji, not his brothers, would win the princess. This tale establishes Okuninushi's core virtue: compassion for the suffering, which brings divine favor. The White Rabbit of Inaba remains one of Japan's most beloved mythological figures.

myths.title: The Trials of Susanoo
myths.content: After winning Princess Yakami, Onamuji faced the murderous jealousy of his brothers, who killed him twice (once by crushing him with a red-hot boulder, once by splitting him in a tree). Each time, his mother and divine intervention restored him to life. Seeking protection and greater power, he descended to Ne-no-Kuni (the Root Land) to meet the storm god Susanoo. There he encountered Suseri-hime, Susanoo's daughter, and the two fell deeply in love. Susanoo, testing the young god, subjected him to three impossible trials: sleeping in a room full of snakes, then scorpions and centipedes, then being trapped in a burning field while searching for an arrow. With Suseri-hime's help and his own cleverness, Onamuji survived each ordeal. On the final night, as Susanoo slept, Onamuji tied the storm god's hair to the rafters and fled with Suseri-hime, Susanoo's sword, bow, and koto (zither). When Susanoo awoke and gave chase to the border of the Root Land, he grudgingly acknowledged Onamuji's worthiness, bestowed the name "Okuninushi" upon him, and commanded him to build a great nation.

myths.title: Building the Nation of Izumo
myths.content: With Susanoo's weapons and blessings, Okuninushi returned to the mortal world and set about civilizing the land. He defeated his murderous brothers, established agricultural practices, taught medicine and healing arts, introduced sericulture (silk cultivation), and brought order to the chaotic landscape. Working alongside the dwarf deity Sukunabikona (a tiny kami of medicine, hot springs, and brewing), Okuninushi traveled throughout Japan, establishing shrines, creating rice paddies, and teaching humanity the skills of civilization. When Sukunabikona departed to the eternal land, Okuninushi completed the nation-building alone, weeping at the loss of his companion but continuing the sacred work.

myths.title: The Transfer of the Land (Kuniyuzuri)
myths.content: After Okuninushi had pacified and civilized the land, Amaterasu in Takamagahara determined that the terrestrial realm should be ruled by her descendants. She sent multiple messengers to demand that Okuninushi cede control. After his son Kotoshironushi agreed to the transfer and his other son Takeminakata was defeated in a contest of strength, Okuninushi negotiated the terms. He would yield rulership of the visible world (utsushiyo) but retain dominion over the hidden world (kakuriyo) - the realm of spirits, mysteries, fate, and the afterlife. In exchange, Amaterasu's descendants would build for him a magnificent shrine at Izumo. This myth explains the political ascendancy of the Yamato court (claiming descent from Amaterasu) while preserving the ancient religious significance of Izumo. It also establishes the dual nature of Shinto: the manifest world governed by imperial authority, and the hidden world of spirits governed by Okuninushi.

myths.title: The Many Wives of Okuninushi
myths.content: Okuninushi is unusual among Japanese kami for his many romantic relationships, which produced numerous divine offspring. His primary consort Suseri-hime remained his chief wife, but he also married Yakami-hime of Inaba, Nunakawa-hime of Koshi, and Takiri-bime-no-mikoto, among others. One famous myth tells of his journey to Koshi (modern Niigata) to court the beautiful Nunakawa-hime through poetry, demonstrating that eloquence and art, not just strength, define a true deity. These marriages symbolize the unification of various regional deities and clans under Okuninushi's nation-building project.

family.Father: Susanoo-no-Mikoto (according to most accounts) or alternatively a sixth-generation descendant of Susanoo
family.Mother: Kushinada-hime (the princess Susanoo saved from Yamata-no-Orochi) or Kamimusubi-no-kami
family.Grandfather/Father-in-law: Susanoo-no-Mikoto - the storm god who tested him with impossible trials
family.Chief Wife: Suseri-hime (Susanoo's daughter) - helped him survive the trials and fled with him from Ne-no-Kuni
family.Other Wives: Yakami-hime (Princess of Inaba), Nunakawa-hime (Princess of Koshi), Takiri-bime-no-mikoto, and several others
family.Children: Over 180 children according to some accounts, including Kotoshironushi-no-kami (god of oracles and fishing) and Takeminakata-no-kami (god of wind and hunting)
family.Brothers: The Yasogami (eighty gods) who persecuted him in his youth
family.Divine Companion: Sukunabikona-no-kami - tiny deity who helped build the nation before departing to the eternal land

festivals: Kamiari-sai (November): The Divine Assembly festival at Izumo Taisha welcoming the gathering of all kami
Reisai (May 14-16): The Grand Festival of Izumo Taisha with processions and sacred performances
Shinjiko Festival (August): Celebrating Okuninushi's nation-building and blessing of the harvest
Marriage Blessing Ceremonies: Year-round rituals for couples seeking Okuninushi's blessing for successful marriages

sources: Kojiki (Record of Ancient Matters, 712 CE), Nihon Shoki (Chronicles of Japan, 720 CE), Izumo Fudoki (Regional Chronicles of Izumo, 733 CE), Sendai Kuji Hongi (Ancient Chronicles)

name: Raijin é›·ç¥ž
subtitle: God of Thunder and Lightning
description: Raijin is the fearsome kami of thunder, lightning, and storms, one of the most visually striking deities in Japanese mythology. Depicted with demonic features, surrounded by a ring of drums (taiko) that he beats to create thunder, Raijin controls the awesome power of electrical storms. Often paired with Fujin, the wind god, in art and worship, Raijin serves as both a terrifying force of nature and a protective guardian against evil spirits. His image graces countless temples, scrolls, and tatami screens, embodying the raw elemental power that commands respect and fear.

attributes.Alternative Names: Kaminari-sama (é›·æ§˜) - "Honorable Thunder", Raiden (é›·é›») - "Thunder and Lightning", Narukami (é³´ç¥ž) - "Rumbling God"
attributes.Epithets: Master of Thunder, Drummer of the Heavens, Lord of Lightning, Guardian of the Storms
attributes.Iconographic Title: Raijin-sama - Respectful address acknowledging his terrifying power

family.Mother (possibly): Izanami-no-Mikoto - some traditions hold he was born from her corpse in Yomi
family.Divine Counterpart: Fujin - wind god, often depicted as his companion and partner in controlling storms
family.Atmospheric Kin: Various weather and storm kami who control rainfall, clouds, and atmospheric phenomena

worship.sacredSites: While Raijin doesn't have major shrines exclusively dedicated to him like some other major kami, he appears prominently in many Buddhist temples and Shinto shrines as a guardian figure:
festivals: Rain-summoning rituals (amagoi): During droughts, farmers would perform rituals invoking Raijin to bring thunderstorms
Storm appeasement ceremonies: Before harvest season, prayers offered asking Raijin to spare the crops from destructive lightning
Artistic veneration: Raijin appears in countless art forms - paintings, sculptures, woodblock prints, tattoos - as both subject of reverence and aesthetic power
Protective amulets: Charm papers (ofuda) invoking Raijin's protective power against evil and misfortune

sources: Kojiki (indirectly, through association with Izanami), Buddhist temple iconography, Edo-period art scrolls, Tawaraya Sotatsu's "Wind God and Thunder God" (early 17th century), regional folklore collections

name: Susanoo-no-Mikoto ç´ æˆ’é³´å°Š
subtitle: The Tempestuous God of Storms and Sea
description: Wild, powerful, and unpredictable, Susanoo embodies the untamable forces of nature. Cast out of heaven for his violence yet later redeemed as a hero and protector, he represents the dual nature of chaos - destructive yet necessary, fearsome yet ultimately generative. From slaying the eight-headed dragon Yamata-no-Orochi to becoming the ancestor of the Izumo clan, Susanoo's journey from divine outcast to revered protector mirrors the transformative power of storms themselves.

attributes.Primary Name: Susanoo-no-Mikoto (ç´ æˆ’é³´å°Š) - "His Swift Impetuous Male Augustness"
attributes.Epithets: Storm Lord, Sea Prince, Dragon Slayer, Lord of Yomi's Edge, The Impetuous One
attributes.Post-Redemption Titles: Gozu Tenno (Ox-Head Heavenly King) - syncretic Buddhist title, Protector against Plague

myths.title: Birth from Izanagi's Nose
myths.content: When Izanagi purified himself after fleeing Yomi, Susanoo was born from his nose - fitting origin for a god of howling winds. Unlike his siblings who accepted their celestial domains, Susanoo wept and raged, longing for his mother Izanami in the underworld. His uncontrollable grief caused mountains to wither and seas to dry up, prompting Izanagi to exile him from heaven before he ever properly ruled.

myths.title: The Destruction in Heaven
myths.content: Before his exile, Susanoo visited Amaterasu in Takamagahara, claiming peaceful intentions. Initially Amaterasu was suspicious, but after a divine contest of creation seemed to prove his sincerity, she lowered her guard. Susanoo then went on a destructive rampage: he broke down the ridges between Amaterasu's celestial rice paddies, defiled her sacred halls with excrement, and horrifically threw a flayed piebald horse through the roof of her weaving hall, killing one of her maidens. This violence drove Amaterasu into her cave, plunging the world into darkness.

myths.title: Exile and the Slaying of Yamata-no-Orochi
myths.content: Cast down from heaven with his beard cut off and nails torn out (symbolic mutilation), Susanoo wandered to Izumo Province. There he encountered an elderly couple weeping over their daughter Kushinadahime - their eighth and last child, as the eight-headed, eight-tailed dragon Yamata-no-Orochi had devoured the others. Susanoo agreed to slay the monster in exchange for Kushinadahime's hand. He transformed her into a comb (kushinada means "wondrous comb") for safety, then prepared eight vats of sake. The dragon, lured by the alcohol, stuck its eight heads into the vats and became drunk. Susanoo then hacked it to pieces with his sword. In the dragon's tail, he discovered the legendary sword Kusanagi-no-Tsurugi ("Grass-Cutting Sword"), which he presented to Amaterasu as a peace offering. This sword became one of the Three Imperial Regalia.

myths.title: Marriage and the Palace of Suga
myths.content: After slaying Orochi, Susanoo married Kushinadahime and built a palace at Suga in Izumo. Looking upon the rising clouds over his new home, he composed what is considered Japan's first waka poem: "Yakumo tatsu / Izumo yaegaki / Tsuma-gomi ni / Yaegaki tsukuru / Sono yaegaki wo" - "Many clouds arise / The clouds of Izumo / For the dwelling of husband and wife / I build a many-layered fence / Oh, that many-layered fence!" This moment marks his transformation from chaos-bringer to civilized being capable of beauty and creation.

myths.title: Lord of Ne-no-Kuni
myths.content: After his earthly adventures, Susanoo descended to rule Ne-no-Kuni (the Land of Roots), a realm sometimes identified with or adjacent to Yomi. There he later tested and eventually blessed the hero Okuninushi, who sought refuge with him, eventually giving Okuninushi his daughter and magical items to help him establish rule over Izumo.

family.Father: Izanagi-no-Mikoto - Born from his nose during purification
family.Mother: Izanami-no-Mikoto (spiritually, though born after her death) - His longing for her caused his initial exile
family.Siblings: Amaterasu-Omikami (elder sister, born from left eye), Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto (brother, born from right eye)
family.Consort: Kushinadahime (the princess he saved from Orochi)
family.Children: Yashimajinumi-no-kami, Suseri-hime (who married Okuninushi), and many others through various relationships
family.Descendants: The entire Izumo clan traces lineage to Susanoo; Okuninushi is often considered his son-in-law or descendant

festivals: Gion Matsuri (July, Kyoto): Japan's most famous festival, originally began as prayers to Susanoo (as Gozu Tenno) to avert plague. Features elaborate floats (yamaboko) and processions
Tsushima Matsuri: Summer festival with illuminated boats to ward off epidemics
Nagoshi no Harae (June 30): Purification festival where devotees pass through chinowa (grass rings) associated with Susanoo's blessing

sources: Kojiki (712 CE), Nihon Shoki (720 CE), Izumo Fudoki (733 CE), Sendai Kuji Hongi

name: Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto æœˆèª­å°Š
subtitle: God of the Moon and the Night
description: The enigmatic ruler of the night, Tsukuyomi is the most mysterious of the three noble children born from Izanagi's purification. Assigned to govern the realms of night alongside his sister Amaterasu's dominion of day, he dwells in eternal separation from the sun - a cosmic rift born of a single act of violence. Silent and silver, he counts the months and marks the passage of time, forever moving through the darkness in elegant solitude.

attributes.Name Meaning: "Tsuku" (moon) + "yomi" (reading/counting) - referring to counting months by lunar phases
attributes.Epithets: Lord of Night, The Silver One, Counter of Months, The Separated Brother, Guardian of Darkness

myths.title: Birth from Izanagi's Right Eye
myths.content: During the purification rite (misogi) at the river mouth of Tachibana in Himuka, Izanagi washed his face to cleanse the pollution of Yomi. As he washed his right eye, the luminous Tsukuyomi was born, complementing Amaterasu who emerged from the left eye. Izanagi assigned him to rule the realms of night, making him co-regent of the heavens with his sister. In some versions, he was born equal in beauty and brightness to Amaterasu, differing only in the coolness of his silver light.

myths.title: The Murder of Uke Mochi (The Goddess of Food)
myths.content: This myth explains the eternal separation of sun and moon. Amaterasu sent Tsukuyomi to visit Uke Mochi, the goddess of food, on her behalf. When Tsukuyomi arrived, Uke Mochi prepared a feast for him using her divine power: she faced the sea and spat out fish, faced the forest and expelled game from her mouth, and facing the rice paddies, coughed up bowls of rice. Though the food was divine and pure, Tsukuyomi was so disgusted by the manner of its creation that he drew his sword and killed her. From Uke Mochi's corpse sprang the five grains (rice, wheat, millet, beans, and hemp) as well as silkworms and cattle - blessings for humanity born from divine death. When Amaterasu learned of this killing, she was so horrified by his violence against a fellow kami that she declared she would never look upon his face again. From that moment, sun and moon have been separated - Amaterasu ruling day, Tsukuyomi banished to eternal night, forever chasing his sister across the sky but never catching her.

myths.title: The Counting of Time
myths.content: As the "Moon-Reader," Tsukuyomi's passage across the night sky became the basis for the lunar calendar. His waxing and waning mark the months, his cycles determining the timing of festivals, plantings, and ceremonies. This role as cosmic timekeeper makes him essential to the order of the world despite his isolation - even in exile, he serves a vital function in maintaining the rhythm of existence.

myths.title: The Moon Rabbit
myths.content: While not exclusively about Tsukuyomi, the Japanese moon-rabbit (Tsuki no Usagi) legend connects to his domain. The rabbit seen "pounding mochi in the moon" represents the kami's celestial court, companions to the lonely moon god in his eternal journey through the night.

family.Father: Izanagi-no-Mikoto - Born from his right eye during purification
family.Mother: None directly - born from Izanagi alone after Izanami's death
family.Sister: Amaterasu-Omikami - Sun goddess, born from left eye, now eternally estranged
family.Brother: Susanoo-no-Mikoto - Storm god, born from nose
family.Consort: Various accounts mention no consort, contributing to his solitary nature

festivals: Tsukimi (Moon-Viewing): The autumn moon-viewing festival, particularly on the fifteenth night of the eighth lunar month. Offerings of tsukimi dango (rice dumplings), susuki grass, and seasonal produce are made while viewing the harvest moon
Jusan-ya (Thirteenth Night): A second moon-viewing night about a month after the main Tsukimi
New Year lunar observations: Traditional calendrical calculations honoring Tsukuyomi's role as time-keeper

sources: Kojiki (712 CE), Nihon Shoki (720 CE), Man'yoshu poetry references, lunar calendar traditions

name: Ah Puch
subtitle: Ah Pukuh - "The Destroyer" / "The Fleshless One"
description:
The terrifying god of death, decay, and the underworld, Ah Puch rules over Xibalba,
                the Maya realm of the dead. Depicted as a skeletal figure with protruding ribs, exposed spine, and
                a bloated belly of corruption, he embodies the horror and inevitability of death. Yet the Maya
                understood death not as an end but as a transformation - and Ah Puch, however fearsome, was part
                of the cosmic cycle that made rebirth possible. His defeat by the Hero Twins established the
                pattern of death and resurrection at the heart of Maya religion.

attributes.Etymology: Ah (masculine prefix) + Puch/Pukuh (to destroy, to melt away)
attributes.Alternative Names: Kisin ("Stinking One"), Yum Kimil ("Lord of Death"), Hun Ahau ("One Lord")
attributes.Scholarly Designation: God A in the Schellhas classification system

sources:
Popol Vuh (K'iche' Maya), Dresden Codex, Madrid Codex,
                Diego de Landa's Relacion de las cosas de Yucatan, Archaeological evidence from Maya tombs

name: Chaac
subtitle: Chaahk - "Thunder" / "Lightning Strike"
description:
Among the oldest and most widely worshipped deities of the Maya, Chaac is the god of rain, thunder,
                and lightning. With his distinctive long nose and jade ornaments, he wields a great lightning axe
                to split the clouds and release the waters that sustain all life. As the lord of agriculture and
                fertility, Chaac was essential to Maya survival, his favor bringing bountiful harvests and his
                anger devastating droughts. His goggle-eyed visage adorns countless temples across the Maya world.

attributes.Scholarly Designation: God B in the Schellhas classification system
attributes.Aztec Equivalent: Tlaloc (both rain gods with goggle eyes)
attributes.Epithets: "Lord of the Waters," "He Who Splits the Sky"

sources:
Dresden Codex, Madrid Codex, Diego de Landa's Relacion de las cosas de Yucatan,
                Archaeological evidence from Uxmal, Kabah, Chichen Itza, Modern ethnographic studies of Maya rain ceremonies

name: Itzamna
subtitle: Itzamnaaj - "Iguana House" / "Lizard House"
description:
The supreme creator god of the Maya pantheon, Itzamna is the lord of the heavens, inventor of writing
                and the calendar, master of medicine and learning. Depicted as a wise, aged man or as a great cosmic
                caiman, he dwells in the highest of the thirteen heavens and is the father of countless gods. With
                his consort Ixchel, he presides over creation, knowledge, and the healing arts that sustain humanity.

attributes.Epithets: "Lord of the Heavens," "The One Who Receives and Possesses"
attributes.Glyph Classification: God D in the Schellhas classification system

sources:
Dresden Codex, Madrid Codex, Diego de Landa's Relacion de las cosas de Yucatan,
                Books of Chilam Balam, Classic period inscriptions from Palenque, Copan, and Tikal

name: Ixchel
subtitle: Ix Chel - "Lady Rainbow" / "She of the Rainbow"
description:
The great Moon Goddess of the Maya, Ixchel embodies the creative and destructive powers of feminine
                divinity. As goddess of the moon, childbirth, medicine, and weaving, she presides over the cycles
                of life, fertility, and death. Appearing both as a beautiful young woman and as a fearsome crone,
                she represents the transformative power of the feminine across all stages of life. Her sacred shrine
                on the island of Cozumel drew pilgrims from across the Maya world for centuries.

attributes.Alternative Names: Goddess I, Goddess O (scholarly designations), Chak Chel (Red/Great Rainbow)
attributes.Young Aspect: The Moon Goddess / Goddess I - beautiful young woman
attributes.Old Aspect: Chak Chel / Goddess O - powerful aged crone

sources:
Dresden Codex, Madrid Codex, Diego de Landa's Relacion de las cosas de Yucatan,
                Archaeological evidence from Cozumel and San Gervasio, Classic period ceramics and sculptures

name: Kukulkan
subtitle: K'uk'ulkan - "Feathered Serpent" / "Quetzal-Serpent"
description:
The great feathered serpent is one of the most important deities of Mesoamerica, worshipped from the
                earliest Olmec civilizations through the Maya and Aztec empires. As K'uk'ulkan among the Yucatec Maya
                and Q'uq'umatz among the K'iche', this winged serpent god brought knowledge, civilization, and the
                sacred calendar to humanity. His descent as a serpent of light at Chichen Itza each equinox remains
                one of the world's most spectacular archaeoastronomical phenomena.

attributes.Glyph Classification: Various serpent glyphs with feather elements

sources:
Popol Vuh (K'iche' Maya), Diego de Landa's Relacion de las cosas de Yucatan,
                Books of Chilam Balam, Archaeological evidence from Chichen Itza, Uxmal, and Mayapan

name: Baldr
subtitle: God of Light, Beauty, and Purity
description: The most beautiful and beloved of all the gods. Son of Odin and Frigg, killed by Loki's treachery through the blind god Hod. His death marks the beginning of the end, setting in motion the events that lead to Ragnarok.

attributes.Titles: The Beautiful, The Shining One, The Good
attributes.Domains: Light, beauty, purity, goodness, joy, peace
attributes.Symbols: Mistletoe, light, ships, white flowers

sources: Prose Edda (Gylfaginning), Poetic Edda (Baldrs draumar)

name: Eir
subtitle: Goddess of Healing
description: The goddess or valkyrie associated with healing and medicine. Eir possesses extraordinary medical knowledge and is invoked for healing wounds and curing illnesses. She is counted among the most skillful physicians in the Nine Realms.

name: Freyja Freya
subtitle: Goddess of Love, Beauty, Fertility, and Magic
description: The most renowned of the Vanir, Freyja is goddess of love, beauty, fertility, gold, death in battle, and seidr magic. She receives half of those who die in combat, rules from her hall Sessrumnir, and taught the Aesir the shamanic art of seidr. Beautiful and fierce, sensual and powerful, she embodies the Vanir's connection to both life's pleasures and its mysteries.

attributes.Titles: Lady (Freyja means "Lady"), VanadÃ­s (Vanir Goddess), MardÃ¶ll (Sea-Bright), Gefn (Giver), HÃ¶rn (Flax)
attributes.Domains: Love, beauty, fertility, sex, war, death, magic (seidr), gold, prophecy, cats, falcons
attributes.Symbols: Necklace BrÃ­singamen, falcon cloak (allows flight), boar HildisvÃ­ni, her chariot pulled by cats
attributes.Sacred Animals: Cats (pull her chariot), falcon (her cloak), boar HildisvÃ­ni, swine in general
attributes.Sacred Plants: Elder tree, Mugwort, roses, flax, primrose

myths.title: The BrÃ­singamen Necklace
myths.content: Freyja desired the beautiful golden necklace BrÃ­singamen, crafted by four dwarven brothers. To obtain it, she agreed to spend one night with each dwarf. Loki discovered this and told Odin, who ordered Loki to steal the necklace. Freyja furiously demanded its return, and Odin agreed on condition she stir up endless war between two human kings. This myth shows Freyja's willingness to use her sexuality to gain power, and her association with both desire and the violence of war.

myths.title: Freyja's Tears of Gold
myths.content: Freyja's husband Ã“Ã°r (possibly another name for Odin, or a separate figure) wandered away on long journeys. Freyja searched for him, weeping tears that turned to gold on land and amber when they fell into the sea. This establishes Freyja's connection to gold, amber, and the pain of lost love - showing even the goddess of love suffers from it.

myths.title: The Giant Who Wanted Freyja
myths.content: When the gods needed the walls of Asgard rebuilt, a giant offered to do it in exchange for the sun, moon, and Freyja as his bride. The gods agreed, thinking he couldn't finish in time. When he nearly succeeded (aided by his stallion), Loki transformed into a mare and lured the horse away, preventing completion. This myth repeatedly shows Freyja as the most desired being in all Nine Realms - so valuable the gods constantly use her as bait or bargaining chip, though she never actually becomes anyone's prize.

family.Parents: Njord (father, god of sea and wealth), mother unnamed (possibly Nerthus)
family.Consort(s): Ã“Ã°r (husband, often absent), possibly identical to or an aspect of Odin
family.Children: Hnoss and Gersemi (daughters), both described as extremely beautiful
family.Siblings: Freyr (twin brother, god of fertility and prosperity)

worship.sacredSites: Freyja was worshipped throughout Scandinavia, with particular devotion in Sweden where the Vanir cult was strongest. Her worship involved groves sacred to love and fertility, places where vÃ¶lvas practiced seidr, and sites associated with gold and amber. Unlike war gods honored with weapons, Freyja received offerings of flowers, honey, mead, and gold. Place names like FrÃ¶vi (Sweden) preserve her cult locations.
festivals: DÃ­sablÃ³t (Late Winter): Festival honoring female spirits and goddesses, with Freyja as chief DÃ­s (goddess/female spirit). Women played central roles in this festival, offering sacrifices and performing prophetic seidr.

Winter Nights (Autumn): Harvest festival particularly associated with Freyja and Freyr, thanking the Vanir for prosperity and fertility. Beginning of the dark half of the year when seidr magic was most powerful.
Spring Celebrations: Fertility rites invoking Freyja for the renewal of life, successful crops, and fruitful marriages.
worship.offerings: Freyja received offerings of mead, honey, flowers (especially primrose and roses), gold and amber jewelry, cakes and sweet foods, flax (sacred to her), and sometimes swine (her sacred animal). VÃ¶lvas practicing seidr in her name made offerings before trance work. Love charms and beauty spells invoked her name. Unlike the blood sacrifices given to Odin and Thor, Freyja's offerings emphasized beauty, sweetness, and sensuality.

sources: Poetic Edda (ÃžrymskviÃ°a, HyndluljÃ³Ã°, VÃ¶luspÃ¡), Prose Edda (Gylfaginning), Heimskringla (Ynglinga Saga)

name: Freyja
subtitle: Goddess of Love, Beauty, Fertility, and Magic
description: The most renowned of the Vanir gods. Goddess of love, beauty, fertility, gold, death, and seidr magic. She receives half the warriors slain in battle, the other half going to Odin's Valhalla. Taught seidr magic to the Aesir.

name: Frigg
subtitle: Queen of Asgard, Goddess of Marriage and Motherhood
description: Wife of Odin and queen of the Aesir, Frigg is goddess of marriage, motherhood, domestic life, and foresight. She knows all fates but speaks no prophecies. From her hall Fensalir, she spins the clouds and watches over families and households. The only goddess permitted to sit on Odin's throne Hlidskjalf, she shares his all-seeing vision across the Nine Realms.

attributes.Titles: Queen of Asgard, First of the Asynjur, Lady of Fensalir, Mistress of Foresight
attributes.Domains: Marriage, motherhood, domestic life, prophecy, foresight, clouds, weaving, protection of families
attributes.Symbols: Spindle, distaff, keys (household authority), clouds, mists, falcon cloak
attributes.Sacred Plants: Birch tree, mistletoe (tragically), flax, wool-bearing plants

myths.title: The Death of Baldr
myths.content: Frigg's most famous story is her attempt to save her son Baldr from his prophesied death. Troubled by Baldr's dreams of death, she traveled across all the Nine Realms extracting oaths from every creature, plant, and object never to harm her beloved son. She overlooked only the mistletoe, thinking it too young and harmless. Loki discovered this and fashioned a dart of mistletoe, which killed Baldr when thrown by his blind brother Hod. Frigg's grief was immeasurable, and she sent Hermod to Hel to bargain for Baldr's return.

myths.title: Frigg and Odin's Wager
myths.content: In one tale, Frigg and Odin each favored different sides in a human war. Odin supported the Winilers, while Frigg favored the Vandals. Frigg tricked Odin by moving his bed so when he woke facing a different direction, he saw the Vandals first and was compelled to grant them victory, having promised to favor whoever he saw first. This shows Frigg's cleverness and willingness to use cunning to protect those under her care.

myths.title: Keeper of Secrets
myths.content: Though Frigg knows all that will happen, she never speaks prophecies as vÃ¶lvas do. This restraint - knowing but not telling - reflects her role as wife and mother who must watch fates unfold even when she knows the outcome. Only once did she act on foreknowledge: trying to save Baldr, and even that failed.

family.Parents: FjÃ¶rgynn (father, obscure giant or deity), mother unknown
family.Consort: Odin (husband, king of Aesir)
family.Children: Baldr (beloved son), Hod (blind son), possibly others
family.Stepchildren: Thor, Vidar, Vali, and Odin's many sons by other mothers

worship.sacredSites: Frigg was worshipped throughout the Germanic world, though her cult is less well-documented than Odin's or Thor's. Place names preserve her memory, and she was invoked in domestic settings - the home itself was her temple. Married women particularly honored her, seeking her blessings for family harmony, children, and household prosperity.
festivals: Yule (Midwinter): As Odin's wife, Frigg presided over Yule celebrations alongside him. Spinning was forbidden during the twelve days of Yule - no one should spin while Frigg was spinning clouds
Wedding Ceremonies: Every marriage invoked Frigg's blessing. The bride was under Frigg's special protection from betrothal through the first year of marriage
Mother's Blessings: Childbirth rituals invoked Frigg for safe delivery and healthy children
